This publication covers general rules for filing your federal income tax return. It supplements the information in the instructions for your tax return. It explains the tax law to make sure you pay only the tax you owe.

The 17th edition refers to Form 1040 and Form 1040-SR and their three schedules 1 through 3. The 17th edition is divided into four parts. Each part is further divided into several chapters, most of which discuss the lines of the forms or one of the three schedules. The introduction at the beginning of each part lists the schedules to be discussed. The index on the cover, the descriptions of each part, and the index on the back of the publication are useful tools to help you find the information you need.

This will help you determine your filing status, whether you can claim any dependents, and whether the income you receive is taxable. This publication will explain the standard deductions, the kinds of expenses you can deduct, and the various tax benefits that can reduce your tax. Throughout the publication, examples are provided to show how the tax law applies in typical situations. Throughout the publication, flowcharts and tables are also provided to show tax information in an easy-to-understand way. Many of the topics discussed in this publication are also discussed in more detail in other IRS publications. References to other publications are provided for your reference.

If you are self-employed or have other self-employment income (such as income from being a nanny or selling handmade crafts), see the following publications for more information. Publication 334, Small Business Tax Guide. Publication 225, Farmer's Tax Guide. Publication 587, Business Use of Home.

This section describes your rights as a taxpayer, and the procedures for review, appeal, collection, and refund.

Taxpayers have the right to request that the tax system consider facts and circumstances that may affect their potential liabilities, ability to pay, or ability to provide information in a timely manner. If taxpayers are experiencing financial difficulties, or IRS has not adequately and timely resolved their tax problems through its normal channels, they have the right to seek assistance from the Taxpayer Advocacy Service (TAS).
Taxpayers are entitled to pay only the legally required tax, including interest and penalties, and to allow the IRS to collect all taxes properly.

Taxpayers have the right to a fair and impartial administrative appeal of most IRS determinations (including many penalties) and to receive a written response to their appeal from the IRS Independent Office of Appeals. Taxpayers generally have the right to bring their case to court.

Taxpayers have the right to require that any IRS inquiry, examination, or enforcement action be conducted in a lawful manner, that it not exceed the necessary scope, and that it respect all due process rights, including search and seizure protection, and that it provide for a hearing in due course in the applicable circumstances.

Taxpayers have the right to request, unless authorized by the taxpayer or the law, that no information they provide to the IRS be disclosed. Taxpayers have the right to request that action be taken against employees, tax filers, and other persons who misuse or disclose taxpayer tax information.

Taxpayers have the right to retain their chosen authorized representative to represent them with the IRS. If taxpayers cannot afford a representative, they have the right to seek assistance from the Low Income Taxpayer Clinic.

We accept most taxpayers' returns. If we ask about your return or select it for review, it does not mean you are dishonest. Asking or reviewing may or may not result in more taxes. We may close without making a change; or, you may receive a refund. The process of selecting a return for review usually begins in one of two ways. First, we use computer programs to identify returns that may have incorrect amounts. These programs may be based on tax return information (such as Form 1099 and W-2), past reviews we have done, or compliance cases we have determined certain issues. Second, we use information from external sources to indicate that a return amount may be incorrect. These sources may include newspapers, public records, and individuals. If we determine that the information is accurate and reliable, we can use it to select a return for review. Publication 556, Examination of Returns, Appeal Rights, and Claims for Refunds, explains the rules and procedures we follow in our examinations. The following sections describe how we conduct examinations.

If you disagree with the examination officer's suggestions for change, you can appeal to the IRS Independent Office of Appeals. Most differences can be resolved without costly and time-consuming court trials. Publication 5, Your Appeal Rights, and Publication 556, If You Disagree With How to Prepare a Protest, and Publication 556, Your Appeal Rights, explain your appeal rights in detail. If you do not want to appeal to the IRS Independent Office of Appeals or do not agree with its findings, you can submit your case to the United States Tax Court, the United States Court of Federal Claims, or the United States District Court where you reside. If you submit your case to a court, keep adequate records to show your tax liability, cooperate with the IRS, and meet certain other conditions, the IRS will have the burden of proof. If the court in your case agrees with you on most of the issues and finds that our position is largely unreasonable, you may be entitled to some of your administrative and litigation costs. Unless you try to resolve your case through the administrative process, including the appeals system, and you provide us with the information necessary to resolve your case, you will not be eligible to recover these costs.
In the 1660th edition of the 'Right to Appeal' section, your right to appeal is detailed.

Generally, you and your spouse are jointly and severally liable for the full amount of the tax, interest, and penalties due on the joint return. However, if you qualify for the innocent spouse relief, you may be relieved of all or part of the joint liability. To claim the relief, you must file Form 8857, Request for Innocent Spouse Relief. For more information on the innocent spouse relief, see Publication 971, Innocent Spouse Relief, and Form 8857.

If you think you have paid too much tax, you can ask for a refund. Generally, you must file your original return within 3 years after the date you filed your return, or within 2 years after the date you paid the tax (whichever is later). The law generally provides that if you do not receive a refund within 45 days after you file your return or request a refund, you may be entitled to interest on the refund. More information about refunds is available in Publication 556. If your refund is due but you have not filed a tax return, you generally must file a return by the due date for filing your return, including any extensions, to get your refund.

TAS is an independent organization within the IRS that can help protect your taxpayer rights. If your tax problems have caused you distress, or you have tried and still cannot resolve IRS issues, they can help you. If you qualify for their assistance (always free), they will do their best to help you. Visit TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov (English) or call 877-777-4778.

IRS provides the following sources of information, forms, and publications. Internet: IRS.gov. Tax Law Questions: IRS.gov/Help/Tax-Law-Questions (English) and How to Get Tax Help. Forms and Publications: IRS.gov/Forms (English) and IRS.gov/OrderForms. Taxpayer Advocate Service: Small businesses can participate in the regulatory process by calling 888-REG-FAIR and commenting on IRS enforcement actions. The Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration (TIGTA) You can call 800-366-4484 to report IRS employee misconduct, waste, fraud, or abuse. Deaf, hard of hearing, or speech-impaired individuals using TTY/TDD (teletypewriter/teletypewriter device) equipment may call 800-877-8339. You can remain anonymous.
If you have tax questions, need help preparing your tax return, or want to download free publications, forms, or instructions, visit IRS.gov to find the resources that can help you right away.

After receiving all your wage and income statements (W-2, W-2G, 1099-R, 1099-MISC, 1099-NEC, etc.), unemployment compensation statements (via mail or electronic format), and other government payment statements (1099-G), as well as interest, dividends, and retirement statements (1099) from banks and investment companies, you can choose from several ways to file and submit your tax return. You can file your taxes yourself, see if you qualify for free filing, or hire a tax professional to file your taxes.

You need an IRS online account (OLA) to fill out the forms that require a signature. You can choose to file the forms online or download a copy to mail in. You need your scanned documents to support your filing. Go to IRS.gov/MobileFriendlyForms (English) for more information.

Please visit IRS.gov/Account to securely access information about your federal tax account. View your balance due, and categorize by tax year. View payment plan details or apply for a new payment plan. Make a payment or view your 5-year payment history and any pending or scheduled payments. Access your tax records online, including key data and tax form copies from your most recent tax return. View copies of IRS notices for your record. Approve or deny tax preparer authorization requests. View your address on file or manage your communication preferences.

Through your online account, you can access a variety of information to help you during tax season. You can get your W-2, view your most recently filed tax return, and get your adjusted gross income. Go to IRS.gov/Account to set up or access your online account.
This tool allows your tax professionals to submit an authorized request to access your personal tax filer IRS OLA. For more information, visit IRS.gov/TaxProAccount.

E-filing your tax return and choosing direct deposit is the safest, easiest way to file your return. It can safely and electronically transfer your refund directly to your financial account. Direct deposit also avoids the possibility of your check being lost, stolen, damaged, or returned undelivered to the IRS. 80% of taxpayers choose to file their returns with direct deposit. If you don't have a bank account, visit IRS.gov/DirectDeposit to learn more about where you can find a bank or credit union that offers online account opening.

IRS will not contact taxpayers by email, text message (including short links), phone or social media channels to request or verify personal or financial information. This includes requesting personal identification number (PIN), password or credit card, or other financial account information. Visit the IRS IdentityTheft Center web page at IRS.gov/IdentityTheft to get information about identity theft and data security protection for taxpayers, tax professionals and businesses. If your SSN is lost or stolen, or you suspect you are a victim of tax-related identity theft, you can learn what actions you should take.

IRS cannot issue refunds to taxpayers who have filed tax returns claiming the EITC or the additional child tax credit (ACT) before mid-February. This applies to all refunds, not just the parts of the refunds related to these tax benefits.

U.S. tax payments must be made in U.S. dollars to the IRS. We do not accept digital assets. Visit IRS.gov/Payments to learn about using any of the following methods to make a payment. IRS Direct Pay (Direct Pay): Pay your personal tax bill or estimated tax by check or savings account without any fees. Debit card, credit card, or digital wallet: Choose an approved payment processor and pay online or by phone. Electronic Funds Withdrawal (EFW): Set up a payment when filing your federal tax return using tax software or through a tax professional. Electronic Federal Tax Payment System (EFTPS): This is the best option for businesses. You must register. Check or money order: Mail your payment to the address listed in the notice or instructions. Cash: You can pay your tax bill in cash at a retail store where you file your tax return. Wire Transfer: You can make a same-day wire transfer from a financial institution. Contact your financial institution to determine availability, fees, and timeframes.

Please visit IRS.gov/Payments to get more information about your choice. If you can't pay your taxes in full today, you can apply for an Online Payment Agreement (IRS.gov/OPA) to pay your tax bill over time. After you complete the online process, you will immediately receive a notice telling you whether your agreement has been approved. Use the Compromise Offer in Lieu of Payment (English) to see if you can pay less than the amount you owe in taxes. For more information about the Compromise Offer in Lieu of Payment program, visit IRS.gov/OIC.
Please visit IRS.gov/WMAR to track your Form 1040-X amended tax return. It may take up to 3 weeks for your amended return to show up in our system and up to 16 weeks to process your return.

The Taxpayer Advocacy Service (TAS) is an independent organization within the IRS that helps taxpayers resolve problems with the IRS, makes administrative and legislative recommendations to prevent or correct problems, and protects taxpayers' rights. We strive to ensure that every taxpayer is treated fairly and that you know and understand your rights under the Taxpayer Bill of Rights. We are your voice at the IRS.

TAS can help you resolve problems you can't solve on your own with the IRS. Be sure to try to solve your problem with the IRS first, but if you can't, go to TAS. Our service is free. TAS helps all taxpayers (and their representatives), including individuals, businesses, and tax-exempt organizations. If your IRS problem results in financial difficulty, if you have tried but cannot solve your problem with the IRS, or if you think the IRS system, processes, or procedures are not working properly, you may be eligible for TAS assistance. To get help with general tax topics at any time, visit www.TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov (English). That website can help you with common tax problems and situations, such as what to do if you made a mistake on your tax return or if you received a notice from the IRS. TAS is committed to solving large-scale (systemic) problems that affect many taxpayers. You can report system problems at www.IRS.gov/SAMS. The Taxpayer Rights Act describes the 10 basic rights of all taxpayers when dealing with the Internal Revenue Service. The IRS is committed to serving limited English proficient (LEP) taxpayers through the OPI service. OPI service is a federally funded program that is available at Taxpayer Assistance Centers (TACs), most IRS offices, and at every VITA/TCE tax site. OPI service is available in over 350 languages.

This publication provides general information about federal tax laws that apply to self-employed individuals and statutory employees. It contains information about business income, business expenses, and tax deductions that can help small business owners prepare their income tax returns.
The box 13 on the W-2 form for statutory employees has a check mark. Statutory employees use Schedule C to report their income and expenses.

If you and your spouse jointly own and operate a non-legal business and share profits, you are partners in the partnership regardless of whether you have a formal partnership agreement. Do not use Schedule C. File Form 1065, U.S. Partnership Return of Income. For more information, see Publication 541, Partnerships. Exception - Joint Income. If you and your spouse own as community property under the community property laws of a state, foreign country, or U.S. territory a non-legal business, you may treat the business as a sole proprietorship or a partnership. States that have community property laws include Arizona, California, Idaho, Louisiana, Nevada, New Mexico, Texas, Washington, and Wisconsin. A change in your filing status will be treated as a change in the entity. See Publication 555 for more information about community property laws. Exception - Qualified Joint Venture (QJV). If you and your spouse are the only members of a business that you jointly own and operate and you are substantially involved in the business and you file a joint return for the tax year, you may elect to treat the business as a QJV instead of a partnership for that tax year. This option allows you to avoid the complexity of Form 1065 while still allowing your spouse to receive Social Security credits based on the number of Social Security points earned. For the definition of substantially involved, see the instructions for Schedule G (Form 1040), line G. This option is only available for a business that is owned and operated by your spouse as a community property owner (not as a legal entity under state law). Therefore, a business owned and operated by your spouse through an LLC does not qualify for the QJV option.

Below are some of the tax changes for 2024. Top-tier net income. The highest net self-employment income corresponding to the Social Security part of self-employment tax for 2024 is $168,600. There is no cap for the Medicare part of self-employment tax. Accelerated depreciation. In 2024, the step-down of the accelerated depreciation deduction under section 168(k) remains in effect, with the applicable deduction limit falling from 80% to 60%. Standard mileage rate. For 2024, the standard mileage rate for the business use of automobiles, vans, pickup trucks, or cargo vans increases to 67 cents per mile for the 2024 tax year. For more information, see Chapter 8, Automobile and Truck Expenses. Bad debts. Publication 535, Business Expenses, is no longer used. The bad debt information previously provided in Publication 535 is now included in Publication 334, Chapter 8, Bad Debts.

Below are some tax changes for 2025. For more information on other changes, go to IRS.gov. Highest net self-employment income. In 2025, the highest net self-employment income for Social Security tax purposes is $176,100. Standard mileage rate. In 2025, the standard mileage rate for business use of an automobile, van, pickup truck, or truck with a box is 70 cents per mile.

If you need more information, see Form 8886 instructions or Abuse of Tax Shelters and Transactions (English). Small Business and Self-Employed Tax Center. The Gig Economy Tax Center. The gig economy (also known as the on-demand, sharing, or access economy) refers to the range of activities people engage in to earn income by providing on-demand work, services, or goods. Visit IRS.gov/Gig to learn more about the tax consequences of participating in the gig economy.

After you calculate your gross income and gross expenses, you can calculate your business's net profit or net loss. You can subtract gross expenses from gross income to calculate net profit or net loss. If your expenses are less than your income, the difference is net profit and is included as part of line 3 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040). If your expenses are more than your income, the difference is net loss. You usually can deduct net loss from line 3 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040) total income. However, in some cases, your loss is limited. This chapter briefly describes three of those situations. Other possible limitations on your loss are explained in the instructions for Schedule C, lines G and 32.

Your trade or business losses may be limited. If you have a loss, use Form 461 to determine the amount of your excess business loss. Your excess business loss will be reported as income on Schedule 1 (Form 1040) line 8p and is considered a net operating loss (NOL), which you must carry forward and deduct in the following year. For more information about the limits on excess business losses, see Form 461 and its instructions.

The most common reason for a net operating loss is operating losses from running a business. For more information on net operating loss, see 536. This publication explains how to calculate net operating loss, when to use net operating loss, how to claim net operating loss deductions, and how to calculate net operating loss carryovers.

If your purpose in engaging in business is not for profit, then you may be limited in the amount of deduction you can claim. You cannot offset losses from other income. Your hobbies or main sports or entertainment activities are subject to this limitation. For more information about non-profit activities, see Hobby or Business: What You Need to Know.
Regardless of your age, even if you've already received Social Security and Medicare benefits, self-employment tax rules still apply.
Generally, if your net self-employment income is $400 or more, you must pay self-employment tax and file Form 1040, Schedule SE. Use Schedule SE to figure your net self-employment income.
If you are a self-employed sole proprietor or independent contractor, you usually use Schedule C (Form 1040) to figure the income subject to self-employment tax.
"English": "The self-employment tax rate for 2024 is 15.3% (12.4% Social Security tax plus 2.9% Medicare tax).",

If your net self-employment income exceeds the highest amount (depending on your filing status), you may owe an additional 0.9% Medicare tax. For more information, see Chapter 1, Self-Employment Taxes (Form 1040, Schedule SE, and instructions for Form 8959).

Generally, under the same rules applicable to U.S. citizens, tax law defines residents who must pay self-employment tax. Non-tax law residents do not have to pay self-employment tax unless an effective Social Security Agreement (also called Totalization Agreement) determines that they are covered by the U.S. Social Security system. However, residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, Guam, the Northern Mariana Islands, or American Samoa are required to pay self-employment tax because they are considered U.S. residents for self-employment tax purposes. For more information about foreigners, see Publication 519, Foreign Tax Guide.

If you have income from multiple trades, businesses, or professions that you must pay self-employment tax on, you must combine the net income (or loss) from each trade to determine your total self-employment tax income. A loss from one trade will reduce the profit from another trade.

If any income from trade or business (other than a partnership) is income that is subject to state community property laws, that income should be included in the spouse who engages in the trade or business in determining the self-employment tax to be paid by that spouse.

Do not include in self-employment income any income or loss from the disposition of property held mainly for sale to customers, whether or not the property is inventory. It does not matter whether the disposition is a sale, exchange, or involuntary conversion.

If you are self-employed and you reduce or stop your business activity, you should include in your self-employment income any amounts you receive from insurance or other sources to compensate for business income lost. If you are not working when you receive the payment, the payment is still related to your business and should be included in your self-employment income, even if your business is temporarily inactive.

If you are employed by a church or a qualified church-controlled organization (pastors, religious group members, and Christian Science practitioners are excluded) and you receive $108.28 or more in compensation from the church or organization, you must pay self-employment tax. For more information, see Publication 517, Church Employee's and Minister's Social Security and Other Information.

If you are a crew member of a vessel that catches fish or other aquatic life and you meet all of the following conditions, your income is subject to self-employment tax. 1. You do not receive any compensation for your work other than your share of the catch or the proceeds from the sale of the catch, unless the compensation meets all of the following conditions. 1. The compensation for each trip does not exceed $100. 2. The compensation is only paid when the minimum catch is reached. 3. The compensation is used only to pay for other duties (such as the first mate, engineer, or cook), and in the fishing industry, additional cash compensation is a traditional practice. 2. You will receive a share of the catch or the proceeds from the sale of the catch. 3. Your share depends on the catch. 4. The vessel's crew is typically less than 10 people. (If the average number of crew members for all trips during the past four calendar quarters was less than 10, the crew is typically considered to be less than 10 people.)

You provide services as a notary public and charge a fee for doing so, which you report on Schedule C, but you do not have to pay self-employment tax (see the instructions for Schedule SE (form 1040)).
If you are an employee of a state or local government and are compensated only on a fee basis and are not covered by the federal-state Social Security agreement, you must pay self-employment taxes.

If both of the following conditions are true, you must pay self-employment tax. 1. You are a U.S. citizen employed by a foreign government, a foreign government's wholly owned entity, or an international organization in the United States, Puerto Rico, Guam, the U.S. Virgin Islands, American Samoa, or the Northern Mariana Islands. 2. Your employer does not withhold Social Security and Medicare taxes from your wages.

If you are a self-employed U.S. citizen or resident as defined by the tax code, in most cases you must pay self-employment tax. In calculating self-employment tax, your self-employed foreign income cannot be reduced by the foreign income exemption portion.

The United States has social security agreements with many countries to eliminate double taxation between the two social security systems. Under these agreements, you usually pay social security and Medicare taxes only to the country where you live. The country where you pay taxes will issue a certificate to show that you are exempt from social security taxes in another country. For more information, see the instructions for Schedule SE (form 1040).

When you have a loss or a small net income and any of the following situations apply, you may want to use the optional method (discussed later). You want to earn Social Security benefit points. You incur child or dependent care expenses that qualify for a deduction (optional method may increase your income and thus your deduction). You are entitled to the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) (optional method may increase your income and thus your deduction). You are entitled to the Additional Child Tax Credit (ACTC) (optional method may increase your income and thus your deduction).

Using optional methods may increase your self-employment tax. Paying more self-employment tax may make you eligible for higher benefits when you retire. Because half of your self-employment tax is deducted from your AGI on Form 1040 or 1040-SR, using optional methods may also reduce your AGI, which may affect the amount of deductions, credits, or other items that are limited by your AGI. Calculate your AGI using and not using the optional methods to determine whether the optional methods are advantageous for you. If you use either or both of these methods, you must calculate and pay self-employment tax based on these methods, even if you could pay less tax or no tax using the regular method. Optional methods may be used only to calculate your self-employment tax. To calculate your income tax, include your actual income in your total income, regardless of which method you use to determine your self-employment tax.

To calculate net income using the regular method, multiply your self-employment income by 92.35% (0.9235). For net income calculated using the regular method, see line 4a of Schedule SE (form 1040). Net income calculated using the regular method is also called actual net income.

Only use the non-farm optional method for non-farm income. If you meet all of the following tests, you can use this method. 1. You are a continuous self-employed individual. This means that, in the 3 tax years before you use this method, you had net self-employment income of $400 or more. For this purpose, the net income for the previous year can come from farm or non-farm income or both. 2. You use this method for less than 5 years. (There is a 5-year use limit.) The years do not have to be consecutive. 3. Your non-farm net profit is: 1. less than $7,493, and 2. less than 72.189% of your total non-farm income.
But, if you are a general partner or if you are a loss, you may need to adjust the amounts reported on Schedule K-1.
Your nonfarm total income is usually the sum of the following amounts: Line 7 of Schedule C (Form 1040); and Box 14, code C (from nonfarm partnership businesses) of Schedule K-1 (Form 1065).

If you use a tax year other than the calendar year, you must use the tax rates and highest income limits that are in effect at the beginning of the tax year. Even if the tax rates or highest income limits change during your tax year, you must continue to use the same tax rates and limits for the entire tax year.

Use Schedule SE (Form 1040) to calculate and report your self-employment taxes. If you file Form 1040 or 1040-SR, enter your self-employment taxes on Schedule 2, line 4, and attach Schedule SE to your return. If you file Form 1040-SS, enter your SE tax on line 3 and attach Schedule SE to your return. If you must pay self-employment taxes, you must file Form 1040, 1040-SR, or 1040-SS (with Schedule SE) even if you don't have to file a federal income tax return.

Even if you file a joint tax return, you can't file a combined Schedule SE. This applies whether you or your spouse have self-employment income. If you both have self-employment income, you each must file a separate Schedule SE. Attach both schedules to your joint tax return.

If you have multiple trades or businesses, you must combine the net income (or loss) from each business to figure your self-employment tax. A loss from one business will reduce the income from another business. File a Schedule SE showing your self-employment income, but file a separate Schedule C or F for each business.

If we reviewed the same item on your tax return in either of the previous two years and advised you that your tax liability should not change, please contact us as soon as possible so that we can confirm whether we should stop reviewing.

If you disagree with the reviewer's proposed changes, you can appeal to the Internal Revenue Service Independent Office of Appeals. Most disputes can be resolved without expensive and time-consuming court trials. Your right to appeal is explained in Publication 5, Your Right to Appeal and How to Prepare a Protest, and Publication 556, Your Right to Appeal and How to Prepare a Protest. If you do not wish to use the Office of Appeals or disagree with its findings, you can take your case to the United States Tax Court, the United States Court of Federal Claims, or the United States District Court in the district where you live. If you take your case to court, the IRS will have the burden of proving certain facts. If the court agrees with you on most of the issues in your case and finds that our position is largely unreasonable, you may be able to get some of your administrative and litigation costs back. Unless you try to resolve your case through the administrative process, including the appeals system, and you provide us with the information needed to resolve your case, you will not be eligible for this reimbursement.
Your right to appeal is detailed in the 1660th edition of the collection appeal rights.

Generally, you and your spouse are jointly and separately liable for all taxes, interest, or penalties due on your joint return. To seek relief from any obligations related to your spouse (or former spouse), you must file Form 8857, Request for Innocent Spouse Relief. In some cases, Form 8857 may need to be filed within 2 years of the first date the IRS attempts to collect taxes from you. Do not file Form 8857 with Form 1040 or 1040-SR. For more information, see Publication 971, Innocent Spouse Relief, and Form 8857, or call the Innocent Spouse Office toll-free at 855-851-2009.

If you think you have paid too much tax, you can claim a refund. You usually have to claim a refund within 3 years of the date you filed your original return or 2 years of the date you paid the tax (whichever is later). For more information about refunds, see Publication 556. If you are entitled to a refund but did not file a return, you must file a refund claim within 2 years after you paid the tax. The law generally provides that if a refund is not paid to you within 45 days of the date you filed your return or claimed a refund, interest will be charged on the refund.
If you have tax questions, need help filing your tax return, or want to download free publications, forms, or instructions, visit IRS.gov and find the resources that can help you right away.

After you receive all your wage and income statements (W-2, W-2G, 1099-R, 1099-MISC, 1099-NEC, etc.), unemployment compensation statements (mailed or electronic format), other government payment statements (form 1099-G), and interest, dividends, and retirement income statements (form 1099), you have several choices for filing and submitting your tax return. You can file your own tax return, check to see if you qualify for free tax preparation services, or hire a tax professional to prepare your tax return for you.

Taxpayers who need information about accessible services can call 833-690-0598. The accessible help line can answer questions about current and future accessible products and services provided in alternative media formats (such as braille, large print, audio, etc.). The accessible services help line does not have access to your IRS account. If you need help with tax laws, refunds or account-related issues, visit IRS.gov/LetUsHelp.

This tool allows your tax professionals to submit an authorized request to access your personal taxpayer IRS online account. For more information, visit IRS.gov/TaxProAccount.

The safest and easiest way to get your refund is to file electronically and choose direct deposit. This way, you can safely deposit your refund directly into your financial account electronically. Direct deposit also avoids the possibility of lost, stolen, damaged, or undeliverable checks to the IRS. Eight out of ten taxpayers use direct deposit to get their refund. If you don't have a bank account, go to IRS.gov/DirectDeposit to find out where to find a bank or credit union that offers online accounts.

The IRS will not contact taxpayers via email, text message (including short links), phone or social media to request or verify personal or financial information. This includes requests for personal identification numbers (PINs), passwords or similar information for credit cards, bank accounts or other financial accounts. Visit IRS.gov/IdentityTheft, the IRS Identity Theft Center webpage, to learn about identity theft and data security for taxpayers, tax professionals and businesses. If your Social Security number is lost or stolen, or you suspect you are a victim of tax-related identity theft, you can learn what steps to take. Obtain a set of Identity Protection Personal Identification Numbers (IP PINs). Identity Protection PINs are six-digit numbers assigned to taxpayers to help prevent their Social Security numbers from being used in fraud to file federal income tax returns. When you have an Identity Protection PIN, you can prevent others from using your Social Security number to file a tax return. For more information, visit IRS.gov/IPPIN.

U.S. tax payments must be made in U.S. dollars to the IRS. We do not accept digital assets. Visit IRS.gov/Payments to learn about using any of the following methods to make a payment. IRS Direct Pay: Pay your personal tax bill or estimated tax from your check or savings account directly, and without additional fees. Debit card, credit card, or digital wallet: Choose an approved payment processor and pay online or by phone. Electronic Funds Transfer (EFT): Provide instructions to pay when using tax software or through a tax professional to file your federal tax return. Federal Tax Electronic Payment System (EFTPS): This is the best option for businesses. You must register. Check or money order: Mail your payment to the address listed on your notice or explanation. Cash: You can pay your taxes in cash at participating retail stores. Wire transfer: You may be able to make a same-day wire transfer from your financial institution. Contact your financial institution to learn about feasibility, fees, and timeframes.

Please visit IRS.gov/Payments to learn more about your options. Apply for an Online Payment Agreement (IRS.gov/OPA) to pay your tax bill in monthly installments (if you can't pay your tax bill in full today). After you complete the online process, you will immediately receive a notice telling you whether your agreement has been approved. Use the Online Offer in Compromise (OIC) Pre-Screening Tool (English) to determine if you may be eligible to settle your tax debt for less than the amount you owe. For more information about the OIC program, visit IRS.gov/OIC.

The Taxpayer Advocacy Service (TAS) is an independent organization within the IRS that helps taxpayers resolve problems with the IRS, makes administrative and legislative recommendations to prevent or correct problems, and protects taxpayers' rights. We strive to ensure that every taxpayer is treated fairly and that you know and understand your rights under the Taxpayer Bill of Rights. We are your voice at the IRS.

TAS can help you resolve problems you can't solve on your own with the IRS. Be sure to try to solve your problem with the IRS first, but if you can't, go to TAS. Our service is free. TAS helps all taxpayers (and their representatives), including individuals, businesses, and tax-exempt organizations. If your IRS problem results in financial difficulty, if you have tried but cannot solve your problem with the IRS, or if you think the IRS system, processes, or procedures are not working properly, you may be eligible for TAS assistance. To get help with general tax topics at any time, visit www.TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov (English). That website can help you with common tax problems and situations, such as what to do if you made a mistake on your tax return or if you received a notice from the IRS. TAS is committed to solving large-scale (systemic) problems that affect many taxpayers. You can report system problems at www.IRS.gov/SAMS. (Please do not include any personal identifying information.)

The Small Business Administration (SBA) provides training and educational programs, business counseling, financial planning, and contract assistance to small business owners. The SBA also provides publications and videos on a variety of business topics. The following is a brief description of the assistance provided by the SBA.

SBDC provides consulting, training, and technical assistance to current and potential small business owners who cannot afford private consultants. Help is available in starting, improving, or expanding a small business.

SCORE provides business counseling and training to current and potential small business owners. SCORE is made up of current and former business professionals who provide professional expertise and knowledge to help people start, run and grow small businesses. SCORE also offers a variety of small business workshops.
You can visit the SBA website: SBA.gov (English). When you visit the SBA website, you can find a variety of information that is of interest to small business owners.
Please call 800-U-ASK-SBA (800-827-5722) to contact the SBA's Answer Desk for general information about programs that may be of assistance to small business owners.
You can seek assistance for your small business at the SBDC. To find one near you, visit the SBA website or call the SBA Help Line.

This chapter explains the business taxes you may owe and the forms you may need to file. It also discusses tax identification numbers (TINs). Table 1-1 lists the benefits of filing electronically. Table 1-2 lists the federal taxes you may owe, the due dates for filing, and the forms used to report them. Table 1-3 provides a checklist of the most commonly used forms and schedules that may need to be filed when you are closed. You may want to get Publication 509, Tax Calendar. It has a tax calendar that tells you when to file your return and pay your tax.

In general, you should use your SSN as your Tax Identification Number (TIN). You must write the number on every individual income tax return you file, such as Form 1040 and its schedules. To apply for an SSN, use Form SS-5, Application for a Social Security Number. You can get the form from a Social Security Administration (SSA) office or by calling 800-772-1213. You can also get the form from the SSA website at SSA.gov/forms/ss-5 (English).

If you are a resident for tax purposes or a resident for tax purposes and you do not have an SSN and do not qualify for an SSN, the IRS will issue an ITIN. If any taxpayer fails to file a federal income tax return for three consecutive years (or the taxpayer is listed as a dependent on another taxpayer's return), the taxpayer's ITIN will expire. Generally, if you need to obtain an ITIN, you must attach Form W-7, Application for IRS Individual Taxpayer Identification Number, to your signed, original, properly completed tax return and any other necessary documentation, and mail them to the address specified in the instructions for Form W-7. The instructions cover certain exceptions. If you need to include another person's SSN on your tax return and that person does not have and cannot obtain an SSN, enter that person's ITIN. The form is also available in Spanish. The form can be obtained at IRS.gov/FormW7. An ITIN is for tax purposes only, and it does not entitle the holder to social security benefits or change the holder's employment or immigration status.

When running a business, you may make payments that must be reported on tax returns. These payments will be discussed in the tax returns section of this chapter. You must provide a statement to the payees (recipients) showing the total amount paid during the year. You must list the payee's identification number and your identification number on the statement and on the return.

If you have employees, you must obtain each employee's SSN. Keep a record of the employee's name and SSN as shown on the Social Security card. If the employee's name is incorrect on the card, the employee should request SSA to issue a new card. If the employee's name changes due to marriage or divorce, this may occur. Form W-4, Employee's Withholding Allowance Certificate, is to be completed by each employee so that the correct amount of federal income tax is withheld from the employee's pay. If an employee does not have an SSN, the employee should file Form SS-5 with SSA.

If you make a payment to someone who is not your employee, you must report these payments on your tax return, so get that person's SSN. If you must report payments to an organization (such as a corporation or partnership), you must get its EIN. To get the recipient's SSN or EIN, use Form W-9, Request for Taxpayer Identification Number and Certification. If the recipient does not give you an identification number, you may have to withhold backup withholding. For more information about backup withholding, see the instructions for Form W-9 and the general instructions for the tax return forms you use.
This section explains whether you need to file a tax return and when to file it. It also explains how to pay your taxes.

If your net self-employment income is $400 or more, you must file a 2024 income tax return. If your net self-employment income is less than $400, but you meet any other filing requirements listed in the instructions for Form 1040, you still must file an income tax return.

By filing Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR, submit the tax return and attach Schedule C. On Schedule 1 (Form 1040), enter the net profit or loss from Schedule C. Use Schedule C to calculate your business's net profit or loss. If you operate more than one business as a sole proprietorship, you must file a separate Schedule C for each business.

Paperless filing is easier than you think, and it's available to most filers who file electronically - including first-time filers 16 years of age or older by the end of 2024. If you use tax preparation software or a tax professional to file, you'll use the IRS e-file Self-Select PIN method to sign your return. If you choose to file married filing jointly, you and your spouse each need to establish a PIN and enter it as your electronic signature. To establish a PIN, you'll need to get your Adjusted Gross Income (AGI) from your original 2023 tax return (not from an amended return, Form 1040-X, or a Math Error Notice you received from the IRS). You'll also need to provide your date of birth (DOB). Make sure your DOB is correct and matches the information on your SSA record before e-filing. To do this, check your annual Social Security Statement. If you use the Self-Select PIN method, you don't need to sign or mail any paperwork - not even a W-2. For more information about the Self-Select PIN method, go to IRS.gov.

You can choose to have your refund check mailed to you, or have your refund deposited directly into your checking or savings account. Using IRS e-file, refund processing time is half that of paper filing. Most refunds are issued within 21 days.

The IRS cannot issue refunds for tax returns claiming the EITC or ACTC until mid-February 2025. This applies to the entire refund amount, not just the portion related to the tax credits.

If your tax return shows that you owe taxes, you must pay the taxes (ignoring any filing extensions) before the tax return due date to avoid paying late payment penalties and interest. For 2024, file by April 15, 2025. You have several payment options, including setting up an electronic funds withdrawal from your checking or savings account, or making a payment using a debit or credit card. For more information about payment options, go to IRS.gov/Payments.

You only need a computer that can access the Internet to file your tax return using IRS e-file. When you use a personal computer, you can file your tax return at any time of the day or night from your home using e-file. To complete this process, sign your tax return electronically using the PIN you choose. You do not need to submit a signed copy of your tax return or send a W-2 form.
If your AGI is $84,000 or less in 2024, you can use free tax software to file your tax return and e-file your return.

The public-private partnership between the IRS and tax software providers enables about a dozen brands of commercial tax software products and e-file to be provided to taxpayers at no cost. Visit IRS.gov/FreeFile for details. You can view the free-file standards for each software provider, or use the online tool to find out which free products are available to you. Some software providers offer free state tax filing services.

The IRS also provides electronic versions of IRS paper forms. These electronic forms can be filed electronically (e-filed) for free. Free file forms can be used by anyone who wants to file their own tax return. These forms are not limited by income. Free file forms can perform basic math. This method only supports federal tax forms.

Some companies offer free e-file to employees, members, or clients. Others charge for this service. Ask your employer or financial institution if they offer IRS e-file as a benefit to employees, members, or clients.

For calendar year 2024, Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR is due by April 15, 2025. If you use fiscal year (explained in Chapter 2), your tax return is due by the 15th day of the 4th month after your fiscal year ends. If you file late, you may owe penalties and interest. If you cannot file on time, use Form 4868, Application for Automatic Extension of Time to File U.S. Individual Income Tax Return, to request an automatic 6-month extension. For calendar year taxpayers, this will extend the filing due date to October 15. Filing an extension request will not extend the time to pay your taxes, it will only extend the time to file your return.

Federal income tax is a pay-as-you-go tax. You must pay taxes on income you earn or receive during the year. Income tax for employees is usually withheld from their paychecks. If you don't have taxes withheld from your income or you don't pay enough tax this way, you may have to pay estimated tax.

If you expect to owe $1,000 or more in taxes (including self-employment tax, discussed later) when you file your return, you generally must pay estimated tax. Use Form 1040-ES to figure and pay your tax. If you don't have to pay estimated tax, you can pay any tax due when you file your return. For more information about estimated tax, see Publication 505.
Other options include deducting any overpayment of your 2023 tax return from your 2024 estimated tax payments, or mailing a check or money order with your 1040-ES payment voucher.

Self-employment tax is primarily for individuals who work for themselves. It is similar to the Social Security and Medicare taxes that are withheld from most wage earners' paychecks. If you are a statutory employee earning income, you do not have to pay self-employment taxes on that income. Social Security and Medicare taxes should be withheld from that income.

As with wage earners, self-employed individuals are eligible for social security benefits. Your self-employment tax ensures that you receive benefits within the scope of the social security system. Social Security Insurance provides you with retirement benefits, disability benefits, survivor benefits, and medical insurance benefits. Make sure to report all of your self-employed income. If you don't report all of your self-employed income, your social security benefits may be reduced when you retire.

Before you start receiving Social Security benefits, you must have earned Social Security credits. If you have the required credits (also called quarters), you have earned credits. We'll discuss this later.

In 2024, your income of $1,730 (2025: $1,810) per Social Security tax filing will earn you one work point (up to four work points). Therefore, if your 2024 Social Security tax filing income (self-employment income and wages) is $6,920, you will earn four work points (6,920 / 1,730). For an explanation of the points needed to qualify for Social Security benefits and the benefits available to you and your family, consult the Social Security office nearest you. Making false statements to obtain or increase Social Security benefits may result in a penalty.

Generally, the IRS will only award points for self-employment income that you report on tax returns filed within 3 years and 3 months and 15 days after the tax year in which you earned the income. If you file a tax return or report a change to your self-employment income after this deadline, the Social Security Administration may change its records, but only remove or reduce the amount. The Social Security Administration will not change its records to increase your self-employment income.
Regardless of your age, even if you have received Social Security or Medicare benefits, self-employment tax rules still apply.
Net income is taxed at 15.3% (12.4% Social Security tax plus 2.9% Medicare tax).

You are a self-employed individual in the tax and finance domains. You must pay a 12.4% self-employment tax on the first $168,600 of your 2024 combined wages, tips, and net income. You must also pay a 2.9% self-employment tax on all of your combined wages, tips, and net income. If you are an employee and receive wages and tips that are subject to Social Security or Railroad Retirement Tax (RRT) Grade 1 or both, and the total is at least $168,600, you do not have to pay the 12.4% self-employment tax on any of your net income. However, you must pay the 2.9% self-employment tax on all of your net income. On line 15 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040), deduct half of the self-employment tax as an income adjustment.

If you have both salary and self-employment income, the highest amount of self-employment income tax that you must pay will be reduced by the amount of your salary (but not less than zero). Use form 8959 - Additional Medicare Tax to calculate the tax.

Instead, report the credits as income. To help you determine whether someone you work with is your employee, see Publication 15-A. The information listed in this publication can help you determine whether a person is an independent contractor or an employee. The federal business tax reported on Form 720 includes the following tax categories. Environmental tax on the sale or use of chemicals that deplete the ozone layer and on imported products containing these chemicals or produced using these chemicals. Communications and air transportation tax. Fuel tax. Tax on the first retail sale of heavy trucks, trailers, and tow vehicles. Tax on the sale or use of various goods. Tax on indoor tanning services.

If you are filing Form 720, Quarterly Business Income Tax Return, you may need to deposit business income tax. For more information on depositing business income tax, see the instructions for Form 720.

The IRS compares the payments shown on your tax return with the income tax returns of the individuals who received the payments to see if the payments are included in their income. You must give a copy of the tax return you file to the payee or payor. In addition to the forms listed below, you may need to use other forms to report certain types of payments or transactions.
