Regardless of the amount of payment, you must file a 1099-NEC form for each individual for whom you withheld federal income tax under the backup withholding rules in box 4. If you use a 1099-NEC form to report total sales of $5,000 or more of consumer goods, you must file the form with the IRS by January 31.

You must file a W-2 form to report income you received from your employer, such as wages, tips, and other compensation; and income tax withheld, Social Security tax, and Medicare tax. You can file a W-2 form online. For more information about W-2 forms, see General Information About Form W-2 and Form W-3.

If you did not file a 1099-MISC, 1099-NEC, or W-2 form, or did not report the correct information, you are subject to the following penalties. For more information, see the General Instructions for Certain Tax Return Forms. Failure to file. If you do not file a tax return by the due date, do not include all necessary information, or report incorrect information, you are subject to this penalty. Failure to provide correct payee statement. If you do not provide the necessary statement to the payee by the required date, do not include all necessary information, or report incorrect information, you are subject to this penalty.

If you receive more than $10,000 in cash in one transaction or in two or more related business transactions, you must file a 8300 form (Report of Cash Payments of More Than $10,000 Made to or for a Single Person or for a Business). Cash includes U.S. and foreign currency. Cash also includes certain financial instruments, such as bank notes, travelers checks, and money orders. Cash does not include checks drawn from a person's personal account (personal checks). For more information, see Publication 1544, Report of Cash Payments of More Than $10,000 Made to or for a Single Person or for a Business.

You must calculate your taxable income and file an income tax return for the tax year. Similarly, you must consistently use a clear accounting method that reflects your income and expenses for the tax year.

Unless you have a prescribed tax year, you will adopt the tax year by filing the first income tax return for that tax year. A prescribed tax year is a tax year prescribed under the Internal Revenue Code or the Income Tax Act.

If you filed your first income tax return using the calendar year tax year, and subsequently operate as a sole proprietor, you must continue to use the calendar year, unless you obtain IRS approval to change or are allowed to change without IRS approval. For more information, see Change Tax Year. If you use the calendar year tax year, you must keep books and records, and report income and expenses for the period from January 1 through December 31 each year.

A fiscal year is any 12-month period ending on the last day of any month other than December. A 52- to 53-week fiscal year is a fiscal year that is 52 to 53 weeks long but does not end on the last day of a month. If you use a fiscal year, you must keep books and records and use the same fiscal year to report income and expenses. If you want to know more about fiscal years, including 52- to 53-week fiscal years, see Publication 538.

Generally, you must file Form 1128, Application to Adopt, Change, or Retain Tax Year, to request the IRS to approve a change to your tax year. See the instructions for Form 1128 for exceptions. If you qualify for automatic approval, you do not have to pay a user fee. If you do not qualify for automatic approval, you must request a determination. If you request a determination, see the instructions for Form 1128 for information about the user fee.

Accounting methods are a set of rules that determine when and how to report income and expenses. Your accounting method includes not only the complete accounting method you use, but also the accounting treatment you use for any significant items. When you file your first income tax return (including the Schedule C for your business), you choose an accounting method for your business. If you later want to change your accounting method, you usually must get IRS approval. See Change of Accounting Method.
You must use the same accounting method to calculate your taxable income and to record it. Similarly, you must use an accounting method that clearly reflects your income.

Several taxpayers may change their accounting methods without the approval of the IRS. If a taxpayer complies with the automatic change procedure, the IRS will grant approval for the change year in which the taxpayer files the request. Applications submitted under the automatic change procedure, as generally described in Revenue Procedure 2015-13, 2015-5 I.R.B. 419, are not subject to a user fee. The procedure is available at IRS.gov/IRB/2015-05_IRB#RP-2015-13 (English) (or its successor procedure). Generally, you must use Form 3115 to request an automatic change. For more information, see the instructions for Form 3115.

You can use different accounting methods to handle business and personal items. For example, even if you use cash accounting for your personal items, you can use accrual accounting for your business income.

If you have two or more separate and distinct businesses, you can use different accounting methods for each business if the accounting methods clearly reflect the income of each business. Only if you keep complete and separate books and records for each business will they be considered separate and distinct.

Most individuals and many non-inventory sole proprietors use cash accounting because they find it easier to maintain cash accounting records. However, if you need inventory to calculate your income, you usually must use accrual accounting for the items you buy and sell, except for small business taxpayers (see the definition in the later part of this chapter). For more information, see Inventory.

In accordance with cash basis, please include all income items that you actually or estimatedly received during the tax year in your total income. If you received property or services, you must include their fair market value in your income.

In the absence of restrictions, when a sum of money is credited to your account or is made available to you, you are deemed to have received it. You do not need to possess the money. If you authorize someone to act as your agent and to collect income for you, when your agent receives income, it is deemed to have been received by you.

You cannot carry over a check from one tax year to the next, or hold similar property from one tax year to the next to avoid paying income tax. You must report the income from the property in the year you receive or are provided with the property, without restriction.
If you receive a valid check during a tax year, it is assumed that you have received income during that year, even if the check cannot be cashed or deposited until the following year.

If your debt has been repaid by someone else or has been cancelled by the creditor, you may have to include part or all of the debt as income. If you receive income in this way, you are considered to have received income when the debt is cancelled or repaid. For more information, see the section on cancelled debts in chapter 5, under the heading Income from cancelled debts.

If you include an amount in your income and later in the same year repay all or part of that income, you can usually deduct the amount you repay in the year you repay it. If you repay more than $3,000, special rules apply. For more information about these special rules, see 17, Chapter 8, Repayment.

Under the cash method, you generally deduct expenses in the tax year in which you actually pay them. This includes expenses you dispute as business debts. However, you may not be able to deduct prepaid expenses, or you may need to capitalize some costs, as explained later in the uniform capitalization rules.

Under accrual accounting, you typically report income in the year you earn it and deduct expenses in the year you incur them, or capitalize them. The purpose of accrual accounting is to match income and expenses in the appropriate years.

Under the accrual method, you generally include in your total income an amount that you can reasonably estimate you will receive in the tax year in which you have the right to receive the income. If the taxpayer has applicable financial statements or the secretary may specify other financial statements, it is considered to have passed the all events test no later than in the consideration of the total income item in the applicable financial statement or other such financial statement.
Below are special rules for payment schedules for advance payments, estimated income, and changes of service.

If you include a reasonable estimate of the amount in your gross income and subsequently determine the exact amount is different, consider the difference in the tax year in which you determine the exact amount.

If you provide services at the basic rate specified in the contract, even if you agree to charge at a lower rate before completing the service and receiving the additional fee, you must calculate your income at the basic rate.

Generally, you report the advance payments as income in the year you receive them. However, if you receive advance payments, you can choose to include them in income in the following tax year. You cannot include any payments after the tax year. For more information, see the 538th and 451st notices.

Under the accrual accounting system, in the following two cases, you usually have to deduct business expenses or capitalize business expenses. 1. The test of all events has passed. The following situations indicate that the test has passed: 1. All events that determine the fact of the liability have occurred, and 2. The liability amount can be determined reasonably accurately. 2. Economic performance has been generated.

Before generating economic benefit, you generally cannot deduct business expenses or capitalize business expenses. If your expenses are for property or services provided to you, or for using property, then economic benefit will be generated when the property or services are provided to you or when you use the property. If your expenses are for property or services provided to others, then economic benefit will be generated when you provide the property or services. Certain types of recurring expenses may be treated as having occurred in the tax year even though they have not yet generated economic benefit. For more information about economic benefit, see 538 Publication, Section 1, Economic Benefit.

In your business, when production, purchase or sale of goods is a factor in generating income, unless you are a small business taxpayer, you generally must consider inventory in the tax year beginning and ending. If you must account for inventory, you generally must use accrual accounting for the items you buy and sell. For more information, see Inventory.

You cannot deduct business expenses and interest that you owe to related parties until you have made a payment and the corresponding amount is included in the total income of the related party when using cash accounting. Due to this rule, please also determine such a relationship at the end of the tax year in which you can deduct expenses or interest. If this rule does not allow you to deduct expenses or interest, even if the relationship with the party ends before the expenses or interest can be included in the total income of the party, the rule will continue to apply. Related parties include your immediate family, including siblings (with complete or half blood relationship), your spouse, ancestors and descendants. For a list of other related parties, please refer to Section 267 of the Internal Revenue Code.

Generally, you can use the cash method, accrual method, or special accounting method of combining, provided that the combining method clearly reflects your income and expenses and you consistently use the same combining method. However, the following conditions apply. If you must consider inventory when calculating your income, you usually must use the accrual method for the items you buy and sell. (But see Inventory.) You may use the cash method for all other income and expense items. If you use the cash method when calculating your income, you must use the cash method when reporting your expenses. If you use the accrual method when reporting your expenses, you must use the accrual method when calculating your income. If you use a combining method that includes the cash method, treat that combining method as the cash method.
Generally speaking, if your business produces, purchases or sells goods, you must keep inventory and use accrual accounting for the goods you buy and sell.

If you are a small business taxpayer, you may choose not to keep inventory, but still use a certain accounting method for inventory that clearly reflects your income. If you choose not to keep inventory and your accounting method for inventory treats inventory as non-merchandise or supplies, or is consistent with your financial accounting treatment of inventory, you will not be considered to have failed to clearly reflect income. Generally, if you produce, purchase or sell goods in your business, you must keep inventory and use accrual accounting for purchases and sales of goods.

If you (a) had average annual gross income of $3 million or less for the preceding 3 tax years and (b) are not a tax-exempt organization (as defined in section 448(d)(3)), you are eligible for the small business tax. If your business did not exist for the entire 3 tax years used to calculate average gross income, you calculate average gross income based on the period of existence. If your business (or predecessor entity) had a shorter tax year in any of the 3 tax years, you calculate your business's gross income for the shorter tax year as a pro-rated amount. See IRS Publication 538 for more information.

Your method of financial accounting for inventory will be determined after considering the accounting method you use in the applicable financial statement (as defined in Section 451(b)(3)) or, if you do not have an applicable financial statement, considering the accounting method you use in your accounting records and books.

If you need to calculate inventory, include the following items when you do the calculation. Goods or inventory in transactions. Raw materials. In products. Finished goods. Actual supplies that become part of the goods to be sold.

At the beginning and end of each tax year, you must value your inventory to determine your cost of sales (Schedule C, line 42). To determine the value of your inventory, you need to use the method of identifying inventory items and the method of valuing those items. For all types of businesses, inventory valuation rules cannot be the same. The method you use to value your inventory must be consistent with the generally accepted accounting principles used by similar businesses and must clearly reflect your income. Your inventory practices must be consistent over time.

Under the uniform capitalization rules, you must capitalize the direct and part of the indirect costs of production or resale activities. Include these costs in the base used to calculate the cost of the property you produce or purchase for resale, rather than deducting them as a current deduction. You can recover the cost of the property when you use, sell, or otherwise dispose of it by deducting depreciation, amortization, or the cost of goods sold.

These rules do not apply to the following: 1. Small business taxpayers, defined as inventory as discussed in the previous section. 2. Property you produce when your indirect production costs do not exceed $200,000.

Several income or expense items are accounted for using special accounting methods. These methods include: Depreciation, discussed in 225, Chapter 7. Bad debts, discussed in 453, Topic Bad Debt Deductions. Depreciation, discussed in 225, Chapter 7. Depreciation, discussed in 946, Topic How to Depreciate Property. Installment sales, discussed in 537, Topic Installment Sales. Accounting methods for long-term contracts. See 460.

If you dispose of business property, you may have taxable income or deductible losses to report on your tax return. However, in some cases, you may have non-taxable income or non-deductible losses. This section discusses whether you have disposed of property, how to calculate income or losses, and where to report income or losses.

Installment sales are property sales in which the taxpayer receives at least one payment after the tax year in which the sale is made. If you provide the money for the buyer to purchase your property instead of having the buyer obtain a loan or mortgage from a third party, you may be making an installment sale. For more information about installment sales, see Publication 537.

The sale of a business is not usually the sale of only one asset. Instead, all of the business's assets are sold. Generally, when this occurs, each asset is treated as being sold separately, in order to determine how the gain or loss is to be treated. The parties to the business sale must report to the IRS how the price of the sale is allocated among the business's assets. Use Form 8594, Statement of Assets and Liabilities of a Business Acquired in a Transaction in Which There Was a Transfer of Stock of a Corporation or an Interest in a Partnership or a Limited Liability Company, to provide this information. The parties should attach a copy of Form 8594 to their respective federal income tax returns for the year of the transaction. For more information about business sales, see IRS Publication 544.

Generally, the adjusted basis of property is the original cost or other basis plus certain additions and minus certain deductions, such as depreciation and losses from accidents. When determining gain or loss, expenses incurred in transferring property to a new owner (such as sales expenses) are added to the adjusted basis of the property.

Generally, your net proceeds from the disposition of property are the total of all cash received plus the fair market value of all property or services received. Your net proceeds also include any debts assumed by the purchaser of your property and any debts attached to the property you transfer, such as real property taxes or a mortgage.

For tax purposes, you generally recognize gains or losses from the disposition of property as income or losses. Recognized gains must be included in total income. Recognized losses can be deducted from total income. However, gains or losses from certain transactions are not recognized. Refer to the section on Non-taxable transactions. Similarly, you cannot deduct losses from the disposition of property held for personal use.

You must report your gains or losses as ordinary or capital gains or losses. You must do this to calculate net capital gains or losses. Generally, if you dispose of a capital asset, you will report capital income or loss. Usually, you own and use every asset for personal or investment purposes. A property you use in your business is not a capital asset. Income or loss from the disposition of the property is ordinary income or loss. However, if you hold the property for more than 1 year, you may be able to treat the income or loss as capital gains or losses. These are called Section 1231 gains and losses. For more information about ordinary and capital gains and losses, see IRS Publication 544, chapters 2 and 3.

If you have realized a capital gain or loss, you must determine whether it is long-term or short-term. A capital gain or loss is long-term or short-term depending on how long you held the property before you disposed of it. The time you held the property before you disposed of it is called the holding period.
Please use Schedule 4797. If you have taxable income, you may also need to use Schedule D (Form 1040).
Please use form 6252. You may also need to use form 4797 and schedule D (form 1040).

The tax benefit applies to the startup costs of new qualified fixed benefit or fixed contribution plans (including 401(k) plans), SIMPLE plans, or SEP plans. For more information, see IRS Publication 560, Retirement Plans for Small Businesses.

The tax credit is a non-refundable tax credit for eligible small businesses that pay or incur expenses to provide accessible facilities for the disabled. You must pay or incur expenses to comply with the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. For more information, see Form 8826.
The tax credit applies to wages paid to eligible employees for time off for home and family leave and for medical leave, but is subject to certain conditions. For more information, see form 8994.
The tax credit is generally available for each low-income building constructed after 1986. For more information, see Form 8586.
The tax credit is available for certain clean vehicles put into use during the tax year. For more information, see form 8936.
The tax credit is available for qualified rail track maintenance expenses incurred or paid during the tax year. For more information, see Form 8900.
The tax credit provides incentives to businesses to employ individuals from target groups with high unemployment rates or other special employment needs. For more information, see form 5884.

This benefit is generally equal to the portion of social security and medical insurance taxes that you (the employer) pay on tips received by your employees at your dining establishment (typically paid as tips). It applies whether the employee is eating at your establishment or elsewhere. For more information, see form 8846.
The tax credit provides incentives to employers to continue paying wages to employees who serve in the uniformed services for more than 30 days. For more information, see form 8932.
The tax credit is available for eligible expenses for employee child care services and eligible expenses for child care resources and referral services. For more information, see form 8882.
The tax credit applies to the cost of certain health insurance provided to a number of employees. For more information, see form 8941.

This chapter explains how to calculate business income, how to report business income on your tax return, which items are not treated as income, and provides guidelines for selecting a trade. If you receive any income related to your business, that income is business income. If it is clear that you would not make an income payment if you did not conduct the business, there is an association. Even if you do not conduct your business on a full-time basis, you may have business income. Income you receive from conducting a business in addition to your regular full-time work may be business income. For example, as a second job, you may conduct a business providing ridesharing services. You should report most of your business income on Schedule C, such as income from selling your products or services. However, you should report income from selling business assets (such as land and office buildings) on other forms, not on Schedule C. For more information about selling business assets, see Chapter 3.

Revenue from business operations includes amounts received by your business that are correctly shown on your 1099-NEC form. This includes amounts reported as nonemployee compensation in box 1 of the form. For more information, see the instructions for the form on the back of the 1099-NEC form.

NIL income can be classified as self-employment income. If you receive more than $600 of NIL income from any source (including non-cash income), you should receive a 1099-NEC or 1099-MISC form from that source, which shows the amount of income you must report on your tax return.

If you conduct business, you may receive a 1099-K form that reflects the total amount of all reportable payments made to you. This may not be the amount you report as income because it may not include all of your income items and may include income items that are not included in your income items (for example, sales tax).

Your income reported on Schedule C may be eligible business income, which may allow you to take a deduction on line 13 of Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. If you need to calculate your deduction (if any), see Form 8995-A or Form 8995.

Unless you are exempt from tax by law, you must report all income you receive from your business on your tax return, including income that the payer has not reported to you on a 1099 form. In most cases, your business income will be in the form of cash, checks, and credit card charges. Business income may also be in other forms, such as property or services. These and other types of income are explained below. If you are a U.S. citizen and you receive business income from sources outside the United States (foreign income), you must report this income on your tax return, unless you are exempt from tax by law. If you are a nonresident of the United States, you may be able to report less or none of your foreign business income. For more information, see Publication 54, Foreign Income and the Tax Law Definitions of a U.S. Citizen and a Resident Alien for Tax Purposes.

If you are a real estate trader who earns income from renting out real estate, or a hotel, motel, or other real estate owner who provides services to guests (such as a maid service), you must report rental income and expenses on Schedule C. If you are not a real estate trader or one of the above owners, you must report rental income and expenses on Schedule E. For more information, see Publication 527, Rental Income and Expenses.

If you are in the business of selling real estate to customers in order to make a profit from these transactions, you are a real estate trader. You must pay self-employment tax on the rent you receive from the real estate you hold for sale to customers. However, you do not have to pay self-employment tax on the rent you receive from real estate you hold for speculation or investment.

If you are a self-employed tow truck lot owner, you must pay self-employment tax on the rental income you receive from providing parking spaces and facilities and tangible services to your tenants. If the services are primarily for the convenience of your tenants, rather than for maintaining occupied parking spaces, you are generally treated as providing tangible services to your tenants. If the compensation for the services constitutes a substantial part of the tenants' rent, the services are considered tangible. Examples of services that are not generally considered to be for the convenience of your tenants include supervising and maintaining the entertainment hall provided by the lot, distributing monthly e-newsletters to tenants, operating a laundry facility, and assisting tenants in buying or selling a tow truck.

If you provide services to the tenant, you must report your rental income from the hotel, hostel or apartment that the tenant uses or occupies. Generally, if the services are primarily for the tenant's convenience and are not services that are normally provided with the rental of a room that is only for the tenant's use, you will be considered to be providing services to the tenant. One type of service that is not typically for the tenant's convenience is maid service. However, providing heat and light, cleaning stairways and hallways, and collecting garbage are typically services for the tenant's convenience.
The prepayment of a lease is income to you in the year in which you receive it. It is generally the same, no matter what accounting method or period you use.
Any income you receive from a rental agreement is income other than rent. You must include this income in the total income you received during the year.
Please include the amount you received from the tenant for the cancellation of the lease in your total income for the year in which you received it.

If your tenant makes payments to others under a contract to pay off your debt or liability, then include those payments in your gross income when the tenant makes the payments. A common example of this type of income is the tenant paying your property taxes on real property that is rented.

You receive income from the amount of money you receive from the tenant for restoring the rental property to its original condition. If the amount exceeds the adjustment base for repairing the rental property damaged, damaged, demolished or disassembled by the tenant, it is income.

If you are in the business of renting personal property (such as equipment, vehicles, or clothing), include the rent you receive in your gross income on Schedule C. As discussed in the discussion of real property rental income above, advance payments of rent and other payments may also be received from the rental of personal property. If you receive any of these amounts, include them in your gross income as discussed in the discussion of advance payments of rent and other payments above.
Interest earned on receipts from normal business operations is business income. If you are in the lending business, interest earned on loans is business income.

If the loan you are entitled to receive cannot be recovered within the tax year and you use accrual accounting, you generally must include the interest you accrue on the loan in your gross income until the loan becomes uncollectible. If you previously included interest that later becomes uncollectible, you may deduct bad debt. See chapter 8, Bad Debt.

If you charge little or no interest on installment sales contracts, you may have to treat part of each payment as undisclosed interest. See Revenue Ruling 537, Unstated Interest and Original Issue Discount (OID).

Generally speaking, dividends are the income of securities dealers. However, for most sole proprietors and statutory employees, dividends are non-business income. If you hold stocks as a separate investment from your business activity, dividends from stocks are non-business income. If you receive dividends from business insurance premiums you have deducted in the previous year, you must report all or part of the dividends as business income on your tax return. To determine the amount to report, see  Claiming Deductions That Were Previously Claimed , which is discussed in the following section Other Income .
The following explains the general rules and exceptions to the general rules that include debt cancellation in income.

Generally, if your debt is canceled or forgiven, you must include the canceled amount as part of your total income to pay taxes. If the debt is from your business, report the canceled amount on line 6 of Schedule C. If the debt is a nonbusiness debt, report the canceled amount on line 8c of Form 1040.

If you owe the seller money for the property you purchased, and the seller reduces the amount you owe, you usually won't receive income from the reduction in debt. Unless you are bankrupt or unable to pay, you should consider the reduced amount as a purchase price adjustment and lower your property base.
If repayment of the debt would result in a deduction, you won't get income from the cancellation of debt.

If the debt was incurred in a bankruptcy case and was not included in income, then it does not qualify for the exclusion under 2 through 5. If the debt was incurred when you were unable to repay it, and you were unable to repay it, then it does not qualify for the exclusion under 3 and 4.

You may elect to exclude a portion of your qualified real property business debt forgiveness (up to a certain limit). If you do, you must reduce the basis of your real property by the amount of the excluded portion. This reduction is made at the beginning of the tax year in which the forgiveness occurs. However, if you dispose of the property before that, you must immediately reduce its basis before the disposition.

Eligible non-farm business debt includes the debt refinanced as described in section 3 above, but only to the extent that it is less than the refinanced debt. If you are the owner of an ignored entity (e.g., a single-member limited liability company), see the 4681 Notice, Chapter 1, Qualified non-farm business debt, to determine whether you meet the exclusion. The amount you exclude cannot exceed the lesser of the following: 1. The difference between 1. The outstanding principal of eligible non-farm business debt (immediately before the cancellation of debt); and 2. The fair market value of commercial real property used as collateral for the debt (immediately before the cancellation of debt), minus the outstanding principal of any other eligible non-farm business debt secured by the same real property (immediately before the cancellation of debt). 2. The total adjusted basis of real property held by you immediately before the cancellation of debt. These adjusted bases are determined after any adjustments to the bases of real property acquired in exchange for the debt cancellation or cancellation of eligible farm debt. Do not consider real property acquired in exchange for the debt cancellation.

To make this choice, complete Form 982 and attach it to your tax return for the tax year in which the debt is canceled. You must file the return by the due date (including extensions). If you fail to file the return by the due date (including extensions) and do not make a choice, you may still make a choice by filing an amended return within six months after the due date (including extensions) of the return. For more information, see When to File in the instructions for Form 982.

In the following situations, you must deduct the amount of depreciation you claimed. This means that you must include in your income the amount of depreciation you claimed in a prior year, or all of it, if you claimed it all.

If, in the tax year after you place the property in use, your use of the property (explained in Section 8 Depreciation) falls to 50% or less, you may have to reverse part of the depreciation deduction. If you receive income from the sale or exchange of depreciable property, you may have to treat all or part of the depreciation as ordinary income. Calculate the income from depreciation deductions in Part III of Form 4797. For more information, see IRS Publication 544, Chapter 4.

Please report on Schedule C any sales or transactions of property held as trading stock or primarily for sale to customers. You generally report when you receive them the face amount (less any unstated interest) or issue price (for OID debt instruments) shown on them.

If you reduce or terminate your business activity, report on Schedule C any payments you receive from insurance or other sources because of lost business income. Even if you receive the payment while your business is inactive, report the payment on Schedule C.

You must include in your gross income any damages you received during the tax year for any of the following that are related to your business. Patent infringement. Breach of contract or loyalty. Antitrust damages.

You may be entitled to deduct from your income, if it compensates for your actual economic loss. Your deduction is the lesser of the amount of the loss you received or accrued during the tax year and the amount you paid or incurred during the tax year to recover the loss. If you receive any refunds, include them in your income on Schedule C. However, if you have already treated the refunds as a reduction in your related expenses, capital expenditures, or cost of goods sold, do not include them.

If you recover bad debts or any other items that you have deducted in a prior year, include the amount recovered in your gross income on Schedule C. However, if all or part of the amount deducted in an earlier year did not reduce your tax, you may not include that part of the amount recovered. If you do not include part of the amount recovered in your gross income, you must attach a statement to your return showing how you calculated the amount not included.

Any increase in the value of your property before you realize a gain from its sale or other taxable disposition is not income.

If a tenant builds a structure or improves your property, the increased value of the property from the improvement is not your income. However, if the facts show that the improvement is a way of paying you rent, the increased value will be income.

The sale of goods to others on your behalf is not a sale. Even after the consignee receives the goods, ownership of the goods remains with you (the consignor). Therefore, if you transport goods on a consignment basis, you will not incur any profit or loss before the consignee sells the goods. If you entered into a lease after August 5, 1997, and you received construction allowances from your landlord in either of the following circumstances, you do not include the construction allowances in your income. Under a short-term retail space lease. To construct or improve a qualified long-term real property for your business use.

Short-term leases are retail space leases (or other occupancy or use agreements) of 15 years or less. The following rules apply to determine whether a lease is 15 years or less. Retail space is the property (as a tenant) that you rent, occupy, or otherwise use for the purpose of carrying on a business of selling tangible personal property or services to the general public.
Qualified long-term real estate is any non-residential real estate that is part of or otherwise exists in your retail space, and is to be returned to the landlord upon the expiration of the lease.

Whether or not the income is reported on your tax return, you must report the income. If you meet all of the following conditions, you are a direct seller. 1. If you are an authorized real estate broker or direct seller and you meet both of the following conditions, you must report your income on Schedule C. You provide services under a written contract that states that you are not an employee for federal tax purposes.

If you are a futures commission merchant, you must report income and losses from transactions or sales of Section 1256 contracts (regulated futures contracts, foreign currency contracts, non-equity options, futures on securities, and futures on securities options) or property related to these contracts (such as stocks used to hedge options) on Schedule C. For more information, see Section 1256 and Section 1402(i).

If you are engaged in the business of buying and selling securities or commodities for your own account, you are a securities or commodities trader. As a securities or commodities (including if you made an election under section 475(f) to treat your securities or commodities trading as trading in a business) trader, you do not report your gains or losses from the disposition of securities or commodities on Schedule C. For more information about securities or commodities traders, see Revenue Ruling 55-603, Income from Trading in Securities and Commodities, and Topic 429 - Securities Traders.
If the expenses do not meet the above requirements, report these expenses on line 8z of Schedule 1 (1040 Form).

Insurance companies must report on Form C the income they pay to self-employed insurance agents before retirement based on the commission percentage. Public employees generally do not need to report income from public service on Schedule C. This rule applies to elected tax collectors who receive payments from state funds based on a fixed percentage of collected taxes. Public employees include any elected or appointed position in the United States or its territories, the District of Columbia, a state or a secondary political subdivision or higher. The methods used to account for income for income tax purposes may sometimes differ from the methods used for accounting purposes. This section discusses some of the more common differences that may affect business transactions. Calculate business income (see Chapter 2) for the tax year and your usual accounting method. If the sale of products is a factor in generating your business income, you generally must use inventory to clearly reflect your income. Real estate dealers may not use inventory. For more information about inventory, see Chapter 2.
You must pay tax on all income you earn. You cannot avoid tax by paying income to a third party.

You must use the selected method to apply all purchase discount each year. If you use another method, your account balance at the end of the tax year is your gross income. Under this method, you cannot reduce your cost of goods sold by the amount of the cash discount you receive. When you estimate the value of inventory at the end of the tax year, you cannot subtract the average or estimated discount received on the goods from the invoice price of the goods you have on hand at the end of the tax year.

Trade discounts are parts of list or catalog prices that are reduced, and are usually not written on the invoice or charged to the customer. Do not record these discounts in your ledger. Record only the net amount as the cost of the purchased goods. For more information, see Chapter 6 Trade Discounts.

If the purchaser of your property places part or all of the purchase price in a trust, do not include any part of the purchase price in your gross income until you actually or constructively receive the purchase price. However, you will have taxable income even if you do not receive the purchase price in the following year after you have performed the contract and the trust agreement.
In calculating gross sales, any allowances you give to customers for returns and any other allowances you give on sales should be deducted from total sales.
Special rules for accrual accounting involving prepayments are discussed in chapter 2, Accrual Accounting.

If you manufacture or buy goods to sell, you can deduct the cost of goods sold from your gross income on Schedule C. However, to determine these costs, you must estimate the value of your inventory at the beginning and end of each tax year. If you are a manufacturer, wholesaler, or carry on any business of producing, buying, or selling goods to make a profit, this chapter applies to you. This chapter does not apply to businesses that provide personal services, such as doctors, lawyers, carpenters, or painters. However, if you provide personal services and also sell or charge for materials and supplies that are used in your business, or that are used in the performance of your personal services, this chapter applies to you. There are some exceptions for small business taxpayers. These exceptions may change the way you calculate your business's cost of goods sold. See chapter 2 for more information.

If you donate inventory (i.e., property you sell in your business), you can claim a donation deduction equal to the smaller of the fair market value of the inventory on the date of donation or the inventory base in the year of donation. The base of donated inventory is the inventory you would have included in your beginning inventory at the beginning of the year, or in an earlier year, due to inventory costs. You must subtract your donation deduction from your beginning inventory. This is not part of your cost of goods sold. If the cost of donated inventory is not included in your beginning inventory, the base is zero, so you cannot claim a charitable donation deduction. Handle inventory costs according to your usual accounting method. For example, include the purchase price of inventory purchased and donated during the year in your cost of goods sold for that year.

The difference between the stated price of the goods and the actual price you pay for those goods is called a trade discount. When calculating the purchase cost, you must use the price you pay (not the stated price). Do not separately show the discount amount as a separate item in the total income. Automobile dealers must record the cost of inventory automobiles and subtract any manufacturer's trade discount.

Cash discount is the amount your supplier allows you to deduct from your purchase invoices to pay on time. There are two methods of recording cash discount. You can record the cash discount to a separate discount account on the debit side, or you can deduct the total amount of purchases in the year. Regardless of which method you use, you must consistently use it. If you want to change the method of recording inventory cost, you must submit form 3115. For more information, see Section 2 Changing Accounting Methods. If you record the cash discount to a separate account on the debit side, at the end of the tax year, you must include the balance of that account in your gross income. If you use this method, you cannot use the cash discount to lower your cost of goods sold.

If you take goods for personal or household use, you must deduct the cost of those goods from the total amount you paid for the goods you sold. Record the cost of the goods you take for personal or household use on the debit side of the purchase or sales account. You must also deduct that amount from your drawing account. The drawing account is a separate account you must keep to record the income you use to pay personal and household expenses. As mentioned above, you also use the drawing account to record goods you take for personal or household use. That account is also called a drawing account or personal account.

Direct labor costs are the wages you pay to employees who work full-time on the production of goods. These costs also include part of the wages you pay to part-time employees who work directly on the production of goods (if you can determine this part of the wages).

Indirect labor costs are the wages you pay to employees who perform general factory functions that are not directly or immediately related to the production of saleable products, but are an essential part of the production process.

Materials and supplies used in the production of goods (e.g., hardware and chemicals) are included in the cost of goods sold. Materials and supplies not used in the production of goods are treated as deferred expenses. You must deduct the cost of using these materials and supplies as an operating expense. Operating expenses are discussed in Chapter 8.

Management expenses include rent, heat, lighting, electricity, insurance, depreciation, taxes, maintenance, labor, and supervision. Management expenses incurred as a direct necessity of manufacturing operations are included in your cost of goods sold.

Year-end inventory is also called year-end or final inventory. Your final inventory usually becomes the beginning inventory of the next tax year.
When you subtract the cost of goods sold from the cost of goods available for sale (end-of-year inventory), the result is the cost of goods sold for the tax year.

After you have calculated the gross income (Chapter 5) and the cost of goods sold (Chapter 6) for your business, you can calculate your gross profit. You must determine your gross profit before deducting any operating expenses. These expenses will be discussed in Chapter 8.

First calculate net income, then calculate gross profit. Please subtract any refunds and allowances (Line 2) from total income (Line 1) to calculate net income (Line 3) on Schedule C. Refunds and allowances include cash refunds, discounts, and other allowances given to customers during the year. Then subtract net income (Line 3) from cost of goods sold (Line 4). The result is your gross profit.

If your sales activities are not a material part of your business income, you do not need to calculate your cost of sales. Your gross income and your net income are the same (total income minus any refunds, allowances, or other allowances). Most businesses and professions that sell services (rather than products) can calculate their gross income directly from net income in this way.

At the end of each business day, ensure that your records match the actual cash and deductions for that day. You may find that using a cash register helps you keep track of income. You should also use an appropriate invoicing system and open a separate bank account for your business.

Please verify, to ensure that your records show the correct amount of sales tax collected. If you are a seller of goods or services, you must include the amount you collect in your total income. If you must collect state and local sales tax from the buyer and remit it to the state or local government, you generally do not need to include these amounts in your income.

Please verify to ensure you have adequate inventory count procedures. These procedures should ensure that all items are included in inventory and that appropriate pricing techniques are used. Please use the inventory sheets and tally sheets as the only evidence of inventory. Inventory sheets may be obtained at office supply stores. These sheets have columns for recording description, quantity, unit price, and the value of each inventory item. Each page has blank space to record the person who performed the count, the person who priced the item, the person who performed the extension, and the person who verified the calculation. These sheets will help you confirm that the total inventory is accurate. These sheets will also provide permanent records to attest to their validity. Inventory is discussed in Chapter 2.

If you are in the retail or wholesale business, you can check the accuracy of your gross margin. First, divide your net income by your gross margin. The resulting percentage can measure the average price difference between your cost of goods sold and your selling price. Then, compare that percentage to your mark-up policy. If the two percentages are close or the same, then your gross margin is accurate. If the two percentages are significantly different, then it may indicate that you have not accurately calculated your sales, purchases, inventory, or other cost items. You should determine the cause of the discrepancy.

You run a retail business. Typically, you would add a markup to your products, so that you could earn 331/3% of the sales revenue. Your profit and loss statement shows a net income (total revenue minus returns and allowances) of $300,000. Your cost of goods sold is $200,000. Thus, you earn a $100,000 markup (300,000 - 200,000). To verify the accuracy of your performance for the year, you divide net income ($300,000) by markup ($100,000). The result of 331/3% proves that your 331/3% markup percentage is correct.

If your business receives income from sources other than normal business operations, enter the income on line 6 of Schedule C and add it to gross income. This is total business income. Examples include income from interest-bearing checking accounts, income from the sale of scrap, income from certain fuel tax credits and refunds, and income from bad debts recovered.

You may deduct business expenses. These expenses are called operating expenses. These expenses are expenses that are not capitalized or included in the cost of goods sold but may be deducted in the current year. To qualify for deduction, business expenses must be ordinary and necessary. Ordinary expenses are expenses that are common and recognized in the business field. Necessary expenses are expenses that are helpful and appropriate for the business. Expenses do not have to be necessary to be considered necessary. For more information about the general rules for deducting operating expenses, see section 162 and its regulations. If your expenses are partly for business use and partly for personal use, separate the personal part from the business part. The personal part is not deductible.

SEP, SIMPLE, and eligible plans offer a tax-advantaged way for you and your employees to save for retirement. You can deduct your contributions to the plan on line 19 of Schedule C. If you are self-employed, you can deduct your contributions on line 16 of Form 1040. If your contributions do not cover the trustee's fees, you can deduct those fees. Income from contributions to a plan generally is not taxed until distributions are made to you or your employees. If you start a new eligible fixed contribution or fixed benefit plan (including a 401(k) plan), you may be able to claim a tax benefit. For more information about this tax benefit and the tax benefit for automatic enrollment and military spouse participation, see Form 8881 and its separate instructions. Under certain plans, your employees may allow you to make a small amount of pre-tax salary contributions to the plan. These amounts (and income earned on them) are generally not taxed until distributions are made to your employees. For more information about small business retirement plans, see Publication 560. Publication 590-A, Individual Retirement Accounts (IRAs), discusses other ways to save for retirement in a tax-advantaged way.

Rents are any amounts you pay for the use of property that you do not own. Generally, you can deduct rent only if it is for property that you use in your business. If you have or will acquire an interest in or ownership of property, you cannot deduct rent.

You cannot claim a deduction for rental income that is not reasonable. Generally, if you and the landlord are related, there will be a question of reasonableness. If you pay the same amount of rent to a related person as you would to a stranger who uses the same property, it is reasonable. Rent is not unreasonable simply because it is calculated as a percentage of your total income. Related persons include your immediate family, including siblings (with complete or half blood relationship), your spouse, your ancestors and your descendants. For a list of other related persons, see Internal Revenue Code § 267.

If you rent your home and use part of it for business, you can deduct the rent you pay for that part. You must meet the requirements for using your home for business. For more information, see Your home office.

Generally, rental payments made in the course of your business may be deducted in the year in which they are paid or accrued. If you pay your rent in advance, you may only deduct the amount that applies to the property you use during the tax year. You may only deduct the remaining portion of the payment in the applicable period.

You can deduct your business's direct state taxes from your gross income (not net income) on Schedule C. If you list each deduction separately, you can deduct other state and local income taxes on Schedule A (1040 form). Do not deduct federal income taxes.

You may deduct as taxes the Social Security, Medicare, and FUTA taxes that you pay as an employer with your own funds. Employment taxes are discussed in Chapter 1. You may also deduct as taxes payments you make as an employer to the state unemployment compensation fund or to the state disability benefits fund. Treat these payments as taxes.
您可以在附表 C 上扣除州或地方政府對您的企業中使用的動產徵收的任何稅款。 您也可扣除在州或本地範圍內財產使用權的登記費。

Please treat any sales tax you pay on a service or on the purchase or use of property as part of the cost of the service or property. If the service, cost, or property is used for a business expense that is deductible, you can deduct the tax as part of the service or cost. If the property is a commodity purchased for resale, the sales tax is part of the cost of the commodity. If the property is depreciated, add the sales tax to the depreciated base. For information about property base, see Publication 551. Do not deduct sales tax collected from the purchaser. You must collect and formally pay this sales tax to the state or local government. Do not include this tax in your gross income or total sales.
You may deduct all business taxes that are ordinary and necessary to the operation of your business on Schedule C. Business taxes are discussed in Chapter 1.

Taxes on gasoline, diesel, and other motor fuels used in your business are usually included in your fuel costs. Do not deduct these taxes as a separate item. You may be able to get a tax benefit or refund for the federal excise tax paid on fuel used for certain purposes. For more information, see Publication 510.

You can usually deduct the amount of travel and meal expenses that you have reported as business expenses. The amount you can deduct and the way you can deduct the expenses depend on whether you are reporting expenses under a cash-or-accrual plan or a noncash-or-accrual plan. For more information, see Publication 15. Publication 15 explains the cash-or-accrual plan and the noncash-or-accrual plan, and tells you whether you must report the expenses on your employee's Form W-2.
