Once you make an initial choice, it cannot be revoked by the IRS without your consent. If you do not follow the procedures discussed in this publication for making an initial choice, you will be treated as a nonresident for 2023. However, if you can show by clear and convincing evidence that you took reasonable actions to understand the filing procedure and to comply with the important steps of that procedure, this will not apply.

You usually make this choice when you file your combined return. However, you can also make this choice by filing Form 1040-X, Amended U.S. Individual Income Tax Return. Attach Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR, and enter 'Amended version' at the top of the revised return. If you choose to amend your return, you and your spouse also must amend any returns you filed after you made the choice that year. You usually must file the revised combined return within 3 years of the date you filed your original U.S. income tax return, or within 2 years of the year you paid the income tax, whichever is later.

Attach the required statement to your income tax return. If you do not need to file a tax return, mail the statement to: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Center Austin, TX 73301-0215 You must file the statement by the due date or before the due date. The due date is shown in Chapter 7. If you do not file the statement as required above, you will not be able to claim the foreign tax credit for the year in which you are a nonresident alien. If you can show by clear and convincing evidence that you took reasonable steps to understand the filing requirements and the important steps to comply with those requirements, this does not apply.

If you are married and one spouse is a U.S. citizen or resident for tax purposes and the other is not, you can choose to treat your nonresident spouse as a resident. This includes the case where at the beginning of your tax year, one spouse is not a resident for tax purposes, but becomes a resident for tax purposes by the end of the year, and the other spouse is not a resident for tax purposes at the end of the year. If you make this choice, you and your spouse are treated as residents for the entire year for income tax purposes. You and your spouse cannot claim relief under any tax treaty as a nonresident. You will be taxed on your foreign income. You must file a joint return for the year in which you make the election, but you and your spouse may file a joint or separate return in subsequent years.

You usually make this choice when you file your combined return. However, you can also make the choice by filing an amended combined return on Form 1040-X. Attach Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR, and enter 'AMENDED' on the top of the revised return. If you choose to amend your return, you and your spouse also must amend any returns you filed after you made the choice. You usually must file the amended combined return within 3 years of the date you filed your original U.S. income tax return, or 2 years of the year you paid the income tax, whichever is later.

If both spouses are not U.S. citizens or tax law residents at any time during the tax year, then they will be considered tax law residents for any tax year (after the year in which you make the election) and will be treated as tax law residents for that year. This means that if either spouse meets the filing requirements of the non-tax law residents discussed in Chapter 7, then each spouse must file separately as a non-tax law resident for that year.

Once a choice is made, the choice to be considered a resident applies to all subsequent tax years unless suspended (as described in the suspended choice section above) or terminated in one of the following ways. If the choice is terminated in one of the following ways, both spouses cannot make this choice in any subsequent tax year. 1. Rescind. Either spouse can rescind the choice for any tax year, provided the rescission is made before the filing deadline for that tax year. The rescinding spouse must attach a signed statement declaring that the choice is being rescinded. The statement must include the names, addresses, and TINs of both spouses. (If one spouse has died, include the name and address of the spouse who is rescinding the choice.) The statement must also include a list of any states, foreign countries, and property in which the spouse resides or from which the spouse receives income. Submit the statement as follows. 1. If the rescinding spouse must file a return, attach the statement to the return for the year to which the choice applies. 2. If the rescinding spouse need not file a return but does file a return (for example, to receive a refund), attach the statement to the return. 3. If the rescinding spouse need not file a return and has not requested a refund, mail the statement to the IRS service center where you filed your last combined return. 2. Death. The death of either spouse will terminate the choice, beginning with the tax year after the spouse's death. However, if the surviving spouse is a U.S. citizen or resident and is entitled to file as a surviving spouse, the choice will terminate when the last year in which the combined tax rates may be used ends. If both spouses die in the same tax year, the choice will terminate on the first day of the tax year after both spouses die. 3. Legal separation. A legal separation under a divorce decree or separation maintenance order will terminate the choice as of the tax year in which the legal separation occurs. 4. Insufficient records. If either spouse fails to keep adequate books, records, or other information necessary to determine the correct amount of income tax liability or to give the IRS adequate access to these records, the IRS may terminate the choice for any tax year.

Tax law residents are taxed on their income in the same way as US citizens. If you are a tax law resident, you must report all interest, dividends, wages or other services, rental property or royalty income, and other types of income on your US tax return. You must report these amounts from sources both within and outside the United States.

Non-tax-law residents are taxed only on their income from the U.S. and on certain income related to trade or business in the U.S. (see Chapter 4). The general rules for determining U.S. source income for most non-tax-law residents are discussed in Table 2-1. The following discussion covers the general rules and the exceptions to those rules. Not all items of U.S. source income are taxable. See Chapter 4, Section 3.

Real estate is land and buildings, and generally any items that are built on, grow on, or are attached to land. From the U.S., total income includes income from gains, profits, and the sale or other disposition of U.S. real property.

Sales of property located in the United States and sales of or located in a foreign country and sales of or located in the United States of any farm, mine, oil or gas well, other mineral, or timber products are part of income from the United States. For information on determining the part, see Regulation § 1.863-1(b).

Your tax residence is the overall area of your main business, work or job location, wherever your family home may be. Your tax residence is the place where you permanently or indefinitely work as an employee or self-employed person. If your work nature does not have a fixed or main business location, then your tax residence is the place where you usually live. If you do not fall into either of these two categories, you will be considered as a mobile population, your work location is your tax residence.

Inventory property refers to property that is held for sale or is primarily used in your trade or business and is sold to customers in the normal course of your trade or business. Revenue from the sale of inventory property is derived from the sale of the property. Generally, this is the place where ownership of the property is transferred to the buyer. For example, in the United States, income from the sale of inventory is U.S. source income, whether you purchase the inventory in the United States or abroad. You earn revenue from the sale of inventory property in the country where the property is produced. Even if your tax residence is not in the United States, these rules apply.

If you are to determine the source of any gain from the sale of depreciable personal property, you must first calculate the portion of the gain that is not in excess of the total depreciation adjustment. You will allocate this portion of the gain to the U.S. source by applying the ratio of U.S. depreciation adjustment to total depreciation adjustment. The remainder of the gain will be considered to be from a source other than the U.S. For this purpose, 'U.S. depreciation adjustment item' is depreciation allowed in computing taxable income from property based on depreciation. However, if the property is primarily used in the U.S. during the tax year, all depreciation deductions allowed for that year are treated as U.S. depreciation. However, there are certain exceptions for property used in international transportation, communications, and other activities. As stated above, the source of gain from the sale of depreciable assets is inventory assets. The source of loss is the same as the source of depreciation deduction. However, if the property is primarily used in the U.S., the entire loss will be reduced from U.S. income. The cost basis of property is generally the amount you paid for the property (money plus the fair market value of other property or services). Depreciation is the amount you deduct to recover the cost of trade or business assets or other basis. The amount you can deduct depends on the cost of the property, the time you begin to use the property, the time required to recover the cost, and the depreciation method you use. Depreciation deductions are any deductions for depreciation or amortization, or any other allowed deduction that treats a capital expenditure as a deductible expense.

Non-tangible property includes patents, copyrights, trade secrets or formulas, goodwill, trademarks, trade names, or other similar property. The proceeds from the sale of depreciable or amortizable non-tangible assets, to the extent of previously allowed depreciation or amortization, are from the same source as the original deduction. This is the same as the rules for the source of income from the sale of depreciable assets. See the section on Depreciable Property in the following text for details on how to apply this rule. If the income from the sale is dependent on the productivity, use, or disposal of the property, then the excess of the depreciation or amortization deduction is from the country where the property is used. If the income is not dependent on the productivity, use, or disposal of the property, then the income is from your tax residence (as discussed in the preceding text). If payments for goodwill are not dependent on its productivity, use, or disposal, then its source is the country where the goodwill is created.

Regardless of any earlier rules, if you do not have a tax home in the United States but have an office or other fixed place of business in the United States, income from the sale of any personal property (including inventory) may be attributed to that office or place of business as United States source income. However, if your office or other fixed place of business abroad is substantially involved in the sale, this rule does not apply to the sale of inventory used, disposed of, or consumed abroad. If you have a tax home in the United States but have an office or other fixed place of business abroad, income from the sale of personal property (other than inventory, depreciable property, or intangible assets) may be attributed to a foreign office or place of business as United States source income. If the income paid to a foreign country is less than 10 percent of the selling price, the income will be treated as United States source income. If a foreign country levies a tax on the sale resulting in a gain that is less than 10 percent, this rule also applies to losses.

Payment location or method is not important in determining the source of income. In securities lending or repurchase transactions, the source of interest paid to the securities lending party is the same as the interest on the securities being lent.

Interest from sources other than the U.S. is not included in the following items. 1. Interest on debt issued by a resident or domestic corporation on or before August 10, 2010, that is settled in the tax year of the payor in which the interest is paid, if the interest is at least 80% (0.80) of the total income of the payor in the 3 years before the interest is paid: 1. From sources outside the U.S. and 2. Attributable to a person or corporation that is actively engaged in trade or business in a foreign country or U.S. territory. However, if either of the following is true, the interest will be treated as U.S. source interest income. 1. The recipient of the interest is related to a resident or domestic corporation. See section 954(d)(3) for the definition of related persons. 2. The obligation has been substantially modified after August 9, 2010. Any extension of the obligation is considered a substantial modification. 2. Interest paid on deposit or withdrawal accounts in a foreign branch of a domestic corporation or a domestic partnership, if the branch is engaged in commercial banking. 3. Interest on deposits in a foreign branch of a domestic corporation or a domestic partnership, if the branch is engaged in commercial banking.

In most cases, dividends received from domestic companies are sourced from the U.S. Foreign company dividends are generally foreign source income. An exception to the second rule is discussed in the text below. In securities lending or sale – repurchase transactions, the source of the alternative dividend paid to the securities lender is the same as the distribution method of the securities being transferred.

If the taxpayer is the counterparty under the contract, the amount of the stock dividend equivalent is any total amount of the stock dividend equivalent referred to in the contract and is used to calculate any net amount transferred to or from the taxpayer under the contract. Therefore, even if the taxpayer made a net payment or did not pay any amount because the net amount was zero, the taxpayer may be considered to have received a stock dividend equivalent payment. For 2023, if the contract is a hedge of one, the designated nominal principal contract or the stock link instrument is usually a designated nominal principal contract or a designated stock link instrument. In general, the hedge value is the fair market value change of the designated nominal principal contract or the stock link instrument divided by the fair market value change of the contract's stock number. In general, the stock dividend equivalent amount for a specific designated nominal principal contract or a specific stock link instrument is the stock dividend amount per share multiplied by the contract's stock number multiplied by the contract's hedge value. Complex contracts are subject to special rules. For more information, see Section 1.871-15 of the regulations and Notice 2020-03.

All compensation provided in the United States is treated as coming from the United States. The only exception to this rule is for employees of foreign organizations or offices, and for crew members as discussed in the text below. If you are an employee and receive compensation for labor or personal services performed in the United States or elsewhere, special rules apply to determine the source of the compensation. Wages (except for certain additional benefits) are time-based. Certain additional benefits (such as housing and education) are region-based. Alternatively, you may be allowed to use an alternative basis to determine the source of compensation. See the text below for more information on alternative bases.

Specific companies sell products through multi-level marketing arrangements, for example, by sponsoring lower-level resellers, the upper-level resellers are entitled to receive payments from the company based on the specific activities of the lower-level resellers. Generally, these multi-level marketing companies pay the independent (non-employee) resellers (upper-level resellers) based on the sales or purchases made by the resellers they sponsor, which constitutes income for providing personal services to recruit, train and assist lower-level resellers. The source of this income is usually based on the location where the upper-level resellers provide services, and may be considered as multi-year salary income depending on the facts and circumstances. The income source is determined based on the period of time for which the services are provided as multi-year salary income.

If you are self-employed, you determine the source of self-employment or personal service income based on the facts and circumstances of your particular situation, in order to most accurately reflect the source of the income. In many cases, the facts and circumstances require an allocation by time, as described below.

The source of your annual salary is generally determined by the time base on which the salary is attributed. Annual salary is the amount of salary included in your income for a tax year that is attributed to a period of time that includes 2 or more tax years. You determine the period of time for which the salary is paid based on the facts and circumstances of the case. For example, the amount of salary attributed to a period of time that spans multiple calendar years is attributed to the entire years. The amount of salary from the United States is calculated by multiplying the total amount of annual salary by a fraction. The numerator of the fraction is the number of days (or less than a day unit, such as a partial day) you worked or provided personal services for the case in the United States. The denominator of the fraction is the total number of days (or less than a day unit, if appropriate) you worked or provided personal services for the case.
The amount of additional benefits must be reasonable, and you must prove them through adequate records or adequate evidence.

In addition to tax allowances and danger or hardship allowances, the above additional benefits are based on your main place of work as the source. Your main place of work is usually the place where you spend most of your working time. This can be your office, factory, store, outlet or other location. If you spend most of your working time in more than one place, your main place of work is the central place where you report for work or where the work content is based. If you have more than one job at any time, your main place of work is determined by the facts of each situation. The more important factors to consider are: the total time you spend at each place, the amount of work you do at each place, and how much you earn at each place.

The source of your education-related additional benefit depends on your principal place of work. Education-related additional benefit includes only amounts used to pay for the following elementary or secondary school education expenses. Tuition, fees, educational counseling, special needs services for special needs students, books, supplies, and other equipment. School-required or provided meals and uniforms related to enrollment or attendance.

Local transportation fringe benefits are based on your principal work location. Your local transportation fringe benefit is the amount of local transportation compensation you or your spouse or dependents receive for local transportation. The amount of local transportation fringe benefit is limited to the actual expenses incurred for local transportation and the fair rental value of any vehicle provided by the employer for local transportation that you, your spouse or your dependents primarily use for local transportation. Actual expenses do not include the cost of any vehicle purchased by you or on your behalf (including interest).

The source of compensation for moving expenses is usually determined by the location of your new principal place of work. However, if you provide sufficient evidence to show that the source is more appropriate based on the facts and circumstances of your case, the source will be determined by the location of your former principal place of work. Sufficient evidence usually requires a written statement from you and your employer, or a written statement from the company that was simplified into written form before the move and was established to encourage you or other employees to move to another country. The written statement or agreement must state that your employer will compensate you for moving expenses incurred before returning to your former principal place of work, whether you continue to work for your employer after returning to that location. It may include specific conditions for determining your right to compensation, provided that the standards for satisfying those conditions are clearly determinable and can only be satisfied before you return to your former principal place of work or after you have completed the move.

If you are an employee, if you can determine the alternative basis in a manner that is satisfactory to the IRS to determine your compensation source based on the facts and circumstances of your case, you may use the alternative basis for determination. If you use the alternative basis, you must keep (and have available for inspection) records to show why the alternative basis is more appropriate for determining your compensation source. In addition, if you receive total compensation of $250,000 or more from all sources, you must check the two boxes in line K of form 1040-NR (attachment OI) and attach a written statement to your return that explains the following. 1. Your name and Social Security Number (SSN) (enter at the top of the statement). 2. The specific compensation income or specific additional benefits that you used for the alternative basis. 3. For (2) above, the alternative basis used for each source of compensation. 4. For (2) above, the method of calculation used to determine the alternative allocation. 5. A comparison of the alternative basis and the time or place basis for U.S. compensation and foreign compensation.

Transportation income is from the use of vessels or aircraft or providing services directly related to the use of any vessel or aircraft. Whether the vessel or aircraft is owned, employed, or rented, it is so. As for the word 'vessel or aircraft', it means any container related to a vessel or aircraft. All transportation income that begins and ends in the United States is considered to be from a United States source. If transportation begins or ends in the United States, 50% of the transportation income is considered to be from a United States source. For transportation income from personal services, if transportation begins or ends in the United States and the United States territories, 50% of the transportation income is United States source income. For non-tax-defined residents, this only applies to income from aircraft or aircraft-related income. For information on how transportation income from the United States is taxed, see Chapter 4.

Generally, scholarships, grants, prizes and awards are sourced from the residence of the payor, regardless of who actually pays the funds. However, please see the content of the section on activities outside the United States in the text. For example, research or testing expenses paid by the United States, a non-U.S. resident or a domestic corporation are U.S. sources. Similar payments from a foreign government or a foreign corporation are foreign sources, even if the funds are paid through a U.S. agent. Payments made by entities designated as public international organizations under the International Organizations Immunities Act are foreign sources.

Non-taxable residents who receive scholarships, fellowships, grants, and achievement awards for activities conducted or to be conducted outside the United States are not considered U.S. source income. These rules do not apply to amounts received as other compensation for services rendered. See the discussion of personal services in the text below for the applicable source rules.

If you receive pension payments from a domestic trust for services provided in or outside the United States, part of the pension payments are from sources in the United States. This part is the income from the pension plan and the employer’s contributions for services provided in the United States. This applies whether the distribution is from qualified or nonqualified stock dividends, pension, profit-sharing, or annuity plans (whether or not funded). If you provide services as an employee of the United States, you may receive a distribution from a plan (such as a civil service retirement system) from the United States government that is considered a qualified pension plan. Your U.S. source income is the taxable amount of the distribution, which is attributed to your total U.S. government basic pay, excluding tax-free pay for services provided outside the United States.

If you need to file a U.S. federal income tax return, you may be eligible to take advantage of certain special disaster-related provisions regarding the use of retirement funds. For more information, see Publication 590-B (English). Also, visit IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief.

Special rules provide that taxpayers who suffer economic losses due to certain major disasters are allowed tax-favored distributions and loan repayments from certain retirement plans (including IRAs). For information on reporting qualified disaster distributions and loan repayments, see Form 8915-F, Qualified Disaster Distributions and Repayments, and its instructions.

Your U.S. source income includes rental income and royalties from property located in the U.S. or from any rights in such property. U.S. source income also includes rental income and royalties from the use or enjoyment of intangible property (such as patents, copyrights, trade secrets and formulas, goodwill, trademarks, franchise rights, and similar property) in the U.S.
In these circumstances, you and your spouse must report joint income as described below.

Spouse's income, other than trade or business income and partner's share of partnership income, is considered to be income from services earned by the spouse. The spouse must report all of this income when filing a separate return.

In addition to the partner's share of partnership income, trade or business income is considered to be income earned by a spouse engaged in trade or business. The spouse must report all of this income when filing a separate return.
The share of the partnership in the partnership's income (or loss) is treated as the partner's income (or loss). The partner must report all of this on his or her separate return.

Income from separate property of a spouse (not labor income, trade or business income or partnership share income) is treated as income of that spouse. That spouse must report all of it when filing a separate return. Use the appropriate community property law to determine what is separate property.
All other community property income is treated in accordance with applicable community property laws.

If residents and non-tax-law residents meet certain conditions, they can deduct from gross income. Excluded from gross income are generally the income you receive that is not included in your U.S. income and that you do not have to pay U.S. taxes on. This chapter covers some of the more common exceptions that allow residents and non-tax-law residents to deduct.
Tax law defines residents as being able to exclude the following items from their total income.

If you were physically present in a foreign country or countries for at least 330 days during any 12-month period during the 12-month period ending on the last day of the tax year for which you file your return, you may be eligible for the foreign earned income exclusion. The exclusion amount for 2023 is $120,000. In addition, you may exclude or deduct certain foreign housing amounts. If you are a foreign resident and a citizen or national of a country with which the United States has a tax treaty, you may also be eligible. For more information, see Publication 54 (PDF).
Non-tax law residents can exclude the following items from their total income.

If interest income is from the following sources, interest income unrelated to U.S. trade or business is not included in income: Bank employees' deposits (including certificates of deposit); Mutual savings banks, cooperative banks, credit unions, domestic building and loan associations, and other licensed and supervised savings and loan associations, or similar associations authorized by state or federal law (if the interest paid or credited to the association is deductible under the association's bylaws); and Insurance companies' holdings of money for payment of interest.

State or political subdivision, District of Columbia, or U.S. territory interest is generally not included in income. However, certain private activity bonds, arbitrage bonds, and certain unregistered bonds' interest is included in income.

Based on Sections 1441 through 1443, interest and original issue discount (OID) that qualify as investment-based interest are not subject to withholding under Chapter 3 of the Internal Revenue Code. However, if such interest is a qualified withholding payment, it may be subject to withholding, and the withholding under Chapter 4 of the Internal Revenue Code is not excepted. For more information, see the discussion of investment-based interest in Withholding on Certain Income in Section 515 of the Internal Revenue Manual. To qualify as investment-based interest, the interest must be for a debt issued after July 18, 1984, otherwise it will be subject to withholding. For bonds issued after March 18, 2012, investment-based interest does not include interest for non-registered debt payments. For bonds issued before March 19, 2012, if the debt meets the following requirements, investment-based interest includes interest for certain registered and non-registered (unregistered) bonds.

If in the future any debt can be converted to non-registered form at any time, then it should be considered as registered form debt at a specific time that is not considered to be in registered form. For more information on whether debt is considered registered form debt, see the discussion on specific income withholding on investment pool interest in Section 515 (English) of the publication.

Interest on non-interest-bearing debt does not need to be supported by documentation to be included in the interest income of your portfolio. However, in some cases, you may need to record it for the purposes of reporting on Form 1099 and providing a Form W-9 for withholding tax purposes.

Payment to a specific person and payments that are subject to interest do not constitute portfolio interest. Unless otherwise provided by treaty provisions or other exceptions, you must withhold tax on these payments at the statutory rate.

Interest earned on an investment portfolio is either included or is not included in interest. Or, interest is included if it is one of the following: 1. Interest is determined by reference to any of the following: the income, sales, or other cash flows of the debtor or an affiliate of the debtor; the income or profits of the debtor or an affiliate of the debtor; any change in the value of any property of the debtor or an affiliate of the debtor; or any dividends, partnership distributions, or similar payments made by the debtor or an affiliate of the debtor. For exceptions, see section 871(h)(4)(C). 2. Any other type of interest designated by the Secretary in regulations.

The following are considered related parties. Members of a family, including brothers, sisters, half-brothers, half-sisters, spouses, ancestors (parents, grandparents, etc.) and descendants (children, grandchildren, etc.). Any person in any arrangement that is made to avoid or favor an interest charge. Specific companies, partnerships, and other entities. For more information, see Section 2 of the 544th Edition (English) of the Tax Guide for U.S. Citizens and Residents Abroad.

Or interest not included in any fixed-term debt payments issued or accrued interest: 1993 April 7 or earlier; or, after 1993 April 7, under written binding contracts in effect at that date and at all times thereafter prior to the issuance of the debt.
The following stock dividends are exempt from 30% tax.
You do not have to pay a 30% tax on interest-related dividends received from U.S. sources. Mutual funds will specify in writing which dividends are interest-related.

You may not have to pay any 30% tax on certain short-term capital gains dividends you receive from a mutual fund or other RIC. A mutual fund will specify in writing which dividends are short-term capital gains dividends. If you are a U.S. resident for 183 days or more in the tax year, this tax exemption does not apply to you.
If your salary is paid by a foreign employer, your U.S. source income may be exempt from U.S. tax, but only if you meet one of the following situations.

If you do not satisfy all three conditions, your income from personal services provided in the United States is U.S. source income and is taxable under Chapter 4. If you receive more than $3,000 in payment for these services, the entire amount is income from U.S. trade or business. To determine whether your income exceeds $3,000, do not include any amount received from your employer for advance payment or reimbursement of business travel expenses (if you are required to do so and have informed your employer of these expenses). If the advance payment or reimbursement exceeds your expenses, include the excess amount in the amount received for these services. A 'day' is any period of time during which you are in the United States.

For non-tax law residents in the U.S. as a seaman on a foreign vessel (e.g., ship or boat) temporarily present in the U.S. in connection with U.S. and foreign or U.S. between transportation, the compensation property is not U.S. source income, exempt from U.S. tax. This exemption does not apply to compensation for services provided on a foreign aircraft.

Non-resident foreign students and exchange visitors who hold F, J, M, or Q visas may deduct from their total income the amount they received from a foreign employer. This group includes true students, scholars, interns, teachers, professors, research assistants, specialists, or leaders in a field of special knowledge or skill, or persons of similar description. It also includes the spouse and minor children of a foreign person if they come to the United States with the foreign person or later live with the foreign person.

If you are unsure whether the annuity is from a qualified annuity plan or a qualified trust, ask the payor.

Based on the treaties to which the United States is a party, any types of income exempt from United States taxation are not included in your total income. However, only income subject to taxation under the treaty is included in total income. See Chapter 9.
You can exclude from your total income any legitimate winnings from pari-mutuel betting on U.S. horse or dog racing that are initiated outside of the United States.

If you sell your principal residence, you can exclude up to $250,000 from the gain from the sale. If you are married and file a joint return, you can exclude up to $500,000. For information about this exclusion, see Publication 523 (PDF). If you follow the abandoned property tax rules discussed in Chapter 4, this exclusion does not apply.

If you are a degree candidate, you can deduct from your income the amount of your qualified scholarship that you receive. The rules discussed here apply to residents and nonresident aliens. If you are a nonresident alien and your scholarship is not from the United States, you do not have to pay United States tax. See discussion of scholarships, fellowships, grants, and awards in chapter 2 to determine whether your award is from the United States. Only in the following circumstances can a scholarship or fellowship be deducted from income: 1. You are a degree candidate of an eligible educational institution and 2. You use the scholarship or fellowship to pay qualified educational expenses.

If you meet the following conditions, you are a degree candidate: 1. Studying elementary or secondary school, or currently studying a bachelor's degree or higher at a college or university, or 2. Attending an accredited educational institution that is authorized to provide: 1. A program that offers all the credits required for a bachelor's degree or higher, or 2. A training program aimed at preparing students for paid employment in an accredited profession.

However, in order to make these eligible as educational expenses, the terms of any scholarship or research grant cannot require that they be used for other purposes, such as lodging, or specify that they cannot be used for tuition or course-related expenses.
Even if you must pay a fee to an institution as a condition of registration or attendance, this is the case. The amount of the scholarship or scholarship used to pay these fees is taxable.
The amount of the scholarship used to pay for any non-qualified expenses is taxable, even if the expense is a required condition for enrollment or attendance at the institution.

You cannot exclude from income any portion of any scholarship, fellowship, or tuition reduction that represents past, present, or future teaching, research, or other services. This is true even if all degree candidates are required to provide services as a condition of obtaining a degree.

Residents and non-tax-law residents are taxed differently. Tax-law residents are generally taxed in the same way as US citizens. Non-tax-law residents' taxation is based on their sources of income and whether their income is effectively related to US trade or business. The following discussion will help you determine whether your income for the tax year is effectively related to US trade or business and how it is taxed.

Tax law residents are generally taxed in the same way as US citizens. This means that their worldwide income is subject to US tax and they must report it on their US tax return. Tax law residents' income is taxed at the same progressive rates as US citizens. Tax law residents use the tax tables or tax computation worksheets described in the instructions for Form 1040, which are also used by US citizens.

These two categories differ in that effective-connection income is taxed at progressive rates after the allowed deductions are subtracted. These rates apply to U.S. citizens and residents. Ineffective-connection income is taxed at a 30% (or lower under a treaty) rate. If you were previously a U.S. citizen or tax-law-defined resident, these rules may not apply to you. See the discussion of exit taxes in the later section of this chapter.

Generally, you must be engaged in a trade or business in order to treat income you receive as effectively connected with that trade or business. Whether you are engaged in a trade or business in the United States depends on the nature of your activities. The following discussion will help you determine whether you are engaged in a trade or business in the United States.

If you provide personal services in the United States at any time during the tax year, you are generally considered to be engaged in trade or business in the United States. Foreign employers' payments to non-tax-defined residents for certain types of services are not included in gross income. For more information, see chapter 3, Services for Foreign Employers.

If you are a nonimmigrant temporary resident in the United States under a visa in F, J, M, or Q classification and are not engaged in trade or business in any other manner, you are considered to be engaged in trade or business in the United States if you receive income from a scholarship or fellowship grant described in section 1441(b). Any taxable portion of a scholarship or fellowship grant that is considered to be effectively connected with your trade or business in the United States is treated as income from trade or business in the United States.
If you are a beneficiary of a trust or estate that is engaged in trade or business in the United States, you will be considered to be engaged in the same trade or business.

If your only business activity in the U.S. is through a U.S. resident broker or other agent conducting stock, securities, or commodity transactions (including hedging transactions), you are not engaged in U.S. trading or business. For stock or securities transactions, this applies to any non-tax-defined resident, including stock and securities brokers or dealers. For commodity transactions, this applies to commodities that are typically traded on organized commodity exchanges and transactions that are typically made on such exchanges.

If you trade stocks, securities, or commodities in your own account, you are not engaged in trade or business in the United States. This applies even if the trades occur during your time in the United States or are executed by your employees, your broker, or other agents. If you are a trader in stocks, securities, or commodities, this does not apply to trades in your own account. However, this does not necessarily mean that as a trader, you are deemed to be engaged in trade or business in the United States. Each case will be decided on the facts and circumstances or under the above rules on trading in stocks, securities, and commodities.

If you are engaged in trade or business in the United States, all income, gains, or losses (except certain types of investment income) that you receive during the tax year from sources within the United States are treated as effectively connected income. This applies regardless of whether there is any connection between the income and the trade or business conducted in the United States. The two tests described in Investment Income below determine whether certain types of investment income (such as interest, dividends, and royalties) are treated as effectively connected to the trade or business. In limited circumstances, certain types of foreign source income may be treated as effectively connected to U.S. trade or business. For a discussion of these rules, see Foreign Income.

Use the two tests described below to determine whether the above three categories include one of the following items and whether the income received in the tax year from U.S. sources is effectively connected to your U.S. trade or business. If the test indicates that the income item is effectively connected, you must include it with other effectively connected income. If the income item is not effectively connected, you must include it with all other income in the 30% tax rules discussed in this chapter.
In this test, if the conduct of U.S. trade or business is a significant factor in generating income, that income is considered effectively connected.

When you provide personal services in the United States, you generally engage in U.S. trade or business. Income from personal services you render in the U.S. trade or business tax year is generally effectively connected with your U.S. trade or business. If income received in a year other than the year in which you render the services would have been effectively connected, income received in a year other than the year in which you render the services is also effectively connected. Personal service income includes wages, salaries, commissions, fees, daily allowances, and employee benefits and bonuses. Income may be paid to you in cash, services, or property. If you only engage in U.S. trade or business by reason of providing personal services in the tax year, income, gains, or losses from assets and from the sale or exchange of capital assets are generally not effectively connected with your trade or business. However, if you hold assets with a direct economic relationship to your personal services trade or business, income, gains, or losses are effectively connected.

If you provided personal services in the United States after 1986 and received retirement or retirement distributions attributable to those services after that year, when you were a non-tax law resident, those distributions are considered to be effectively connected income. This is true whether or not you were engaged in U.S. trade or business in the year you received the retirement or retirement distributions.

A 'fixed place of business' is generally the location, place, structure, or other similar facility where you carry on trade or business. 'Regular shipping' is shipping that is carried out on a regular basis, on a published schedule, between the same points of departure and arrival. This definition applies to both scheduled and charter air and sea transport. If either of these two conditions is not met, the income is not effectively linked and is taxed at 4%. See the section on 'Transportation Tax' in this chapter for more information.

All U.S. source income or loss from business operations in the U.S. is effectively connected with U.S. trade or business. For example, income from the sale of inventory property purchased in the U.S. or abroad is effectively connected income to the extent it is related to trade or business income. A portion of U.S. source income or loss from a partnership engaged in U.S. trade or business is also effectively connected with U.S. trade or business.

Real estate interests do not include a class of stock in a company that is regularly traded on a mature securities market, unless you hold more than 5% of that class of stock (or, in the case of a real estate investment trust (REIT), more than 10%). Foreign companies' interests in U.S. real estate are generally not U.S. real estate interests, unless the company elects to be treated as a domestic corporation.

In most cases, any distributions from a qualified investment entity to a non-tax-resident, foreign corporation, or other qualified investment entity that are attributable to income from the sale or trading of U.S. real property interests are treated as income from the sale or trading of U.S. real property interests by the non-tax-resident, foreign corporation, or other qualified investment entity. The rules for viewing distributions from a qualified investment entity as income from the sale or trading of U.S. real property interests do not apply to distributions from a qualified investment entity on U.S. mature securities that are regularly traded on a U.S. securities exchange. Distributions from a real estate investment trust on U.S. mature securities that are regularly traded on a U.S. securities exchange are generally not treated as income from the sale or trading of U.S. real property interests. Distributions that are not treated as income from the sale or trading of U.S. real property interests may be included in your total income as regular dividends.

The shares of a real estate investment trust held directly (or held indirectly through one or more partnerships) by qualified shareholders are not considered U.S. real property interests. For more information, see sections 897(k)(2) through (4).

The following rules apply to determining whether a qualifying entity is controlled by domestic interests. 1. A person holding less than 5% of any class of stock in a qualifying entity will be considered an American unless the qualifying entity has actual knowledge that such person is not an American. 2. In the following circumstances, any stock in a qualifying entity held by another qualifying entity will be considered held by a foreign person: 1. Such other qualifying entity's any class of stock is regularly traded on an established securities market, or 2. Such other qualifying entity is a regulated investment company issuing specific redeemable securities. However, if the stock of such other qualifying entity is controlled by domestic interests, then the stock of the qualifying entity will be considered held by American persons. 3. Stock in a qualifying entity held by any other qualifying entity not described above will be considered held by American persons in proportion to the proportion of American persons (or deemed to be) holding (or deemed to hold) such other qualifying entity's stock.

If this occurs, you will be treated as having received income from the disposition of U.S. real property interests and the income will be equal to the amount that would have been treated as received from the disposition. This also applies to any alternative stock dividends. In the following cases, the transaction will not be treated as a qualified sale: You actually receive a distribution from a domestic controlled qualified investment entity that is related to the interests disposed of or acquired in the transaction; or You dispose of any class of stock of a qualified investment entity that is regularly traded on a U.S. stock exchange, but only if you did not hold more than 5% of the class of stock at any time during the 1 year period ending on the date of the distribution.

For example, if a foreign person actively engages in banking, financing, or similar business in the U.S. to earn income, the equivalent foreign source interest and dividends are considered effectively connected U.S. income.

You can choose to treat all income from real estate as a valid link. See the section on real estate income in this chapter.
30% tax rate (or lower tax treaty) applies to certain income or gains from the U.S. but only if there is no effective link between these items and your U.S. trade or business.

30% (or lower tax treaty rate) rate applies to the total amount of fixed, determinable, annual or periodic (FDAP) income, profits or gains from the United States. Income is fixed when the amount received is known in advance. Income is determinable when there is a basis for calculating the amount to be paid. Income can be periodic if the payments are not made annually or periodically. Payments do not have to be made annually or periodically. Even if the payments are made at increasing or decreasing intervals, income can be determinable or periodic. Income is clearly classified as fixed or determinable income if it is interest (excluding original issue discount (OID)) and dividends, stock dividends, stock dividends equivalent payments (as defined in Chapter 2), rents, insurance premiums, annuities, salaries, wages and other salaries. Alternative dividends or interest payments received in securities lending or repurchase transactions are treated as amounts received on the securities transferred. Other income items such as royalty fees may also be subject to the 30% tax rules. Some fixed or determinable income may be exempt from US tax. See Chapter 3 of this chapter for more information.

Generally, if a non-tax resident of the United States wins total gambling income from gambling in the United States that is not effectively linked to United States trade or business and is not exempt by treaty, the income is subject to a 30% tax rule. However, for non-tax residents of the United States who win non-commercial gambling income from blackjack, baccarat, dice, roulette, or six-wheel roulette, no tax is levied. Non-tax residents of the United States who win net gambling income that is effectively linked to United States trade or business are subject to progressive tax rates.

Non-tax law residents must include 85% of any U.S. Social Security benefits (and equivalent parts of 1st-level railroad retirement and social welfare benefits) in their U.S. FDAP income. Social security benefits include monthly retirement, survivor, and disability benefits. This income is exempt from U.S. taxation under specific tax treaties. Please refer to the Treaty Tables section of this chapter for Table 1, which can be found at IRS.gov/TreatyTables (English). You can obtain a list of U.S. Social Security benefits exempt from U.S. taxation on the website. For more information, please refer to Publication 915 (English).

If you choose to treat income as being effectively connected with the U.S. trade or business, income under item (1) is not subject to the 30% (or lower treaty) rate. See the discussion of real property income in the text following this item.

Report on Form NEC (Schedule 1040) any gains or losses from the sale or exchange of assets that are not effectively connected with the conduct of a U.S. trade or business. Report on Schedule D (Form 1040) or Form 4797 any gains or losses from the sale or exchange of assets that are effectively connected with the conduct of a U.S. trade or business (including real property). Attach them to Form 1040-NR.

If you receive income from real property located in the United States, you own or hold an interest in and hold for the production of income, you may elect to treat all income from that property as effectively connected with a U.S. trade or business. This election applies to all income from real property located in the United States and used for the production of income, and all income from interests in such property. This includes rental income, mineral, oil or gas well, or other natural resource royalty income. It also includes proceeds from the sale or exchange of timber, coal, or domestic iron ore that have an economic interest. You may make this election only for real property income that is not effectively connected with other U.S. trade or business. If you make the election, you may claim a deduction for the amount of income that is effectively connected with a U.S. trade or business, and you are taxed only on the net income from the real property. This election does not treat a nonresident who is not a U.S. tax law definition of a resident as engaged in a U.S. trade or business during the year.
Unless you cancel it, this choice will be valid for all subsequent tax years.

You do not need to obtain approval from the IRS to revoke your election by filing Form 1040-X in the year you make the election and subsequent years. You must file Form 1040-X within 3 years of the filing of your return or 2 years of payment of the tax, whichever is later. If the time period for the year of election has expired, you cannot revoke the election for that year. However, you can only revoke the election for subsequent tax years after obtaining approval from the IRS. For information on how to obtain approval from the IRS, see Section 1.871-10(d)(2).

This 4% rate applies to your total transportation income in the U.S. If transportation begins or ends in the U.S., this includes only transportation income considered to be from the U.S. Transportation for personal services must be between the U.S. and U.S. territories for this to apply. For personal services from non-tax-law residents, this applies only to income from aircraft or aircraft-related activities.

After taking into account any applicable treaty benefits, unless you are subject to the higher rate of tax under Section 871 (which generally applies to non-tax-resident income, as described above), you will be taxed on your total income and gains in the US at the progressive rate applicable to your personal period of non-tax-resident status (and subject to any applicable deductions). For information on how to calculate the special rate, see the section on exit tax in the text below.

If you need to pay this tax during any year you are a non-tax-law resident, you must file Form 1040-NR for that year. The tax return should be filed by the due date for filing your U.S. income tax return for that year (including extensions). If you have already filed a tax return for that period, you must file an amended tax return. You must attach a statement to your tax return that explains the sources of all your U.S. and foreign total income and the items of income subject to this special rule.

The abandonment tax rules apply to U.S. citizens who have abandoned citizenship and to long-term residents who have terminated their residency. The following describes the abandonment rules under section 877A, which apply to individuals who abandoned citizenship on or after June 17, 2008. Please see the text of this chapter for 2008 June 16 and later abandonment. If you moved abroad before June 17, 2008, please see 2004 June 3 and later abandonment, which is contained in the 2018 edition of the 519th chapter and the instructions for Form 8854. If you abandoned your citizenship or terminated your long-term residency after June 3, 2004, and before June 17, 2008, you will still be considered a U.S. citizen or a U.S. resident for tax purposes until you notify the Department of State or the Department of Homeland Security (as applicable) of your alien status and file Form 8854 with the IRS.
Your date of abandonment is the date you gave up your U.S. citizenship (if you were a former citizen) or terminated your long-term residency (if you were a former U.S. resident).

Even if you do not meet a specific abandonment of citizenship condition, you must file a Form 8854 for the year you abandon U.S. citizenship or terminate your long-term residency. In addition, if you meet a specific abandonment of citizenship condition and you meet any of the following, you must file a Form 8854 each year: 1. Taxable income from a foreign trust or estate. 2. A deferral item. 3. An interest in a nongrantor trust.

You will be considered to have terminated your long-term residence on the earliest of the following dates: 1. The date on which you voluntarily renounced your lawful permanent resident status by filing Form I-407 with the U.S. Consulate or Immigration Officer. 2. The date of the final administrative order binding you to renounce your lawful permanent resident status (or, if an appeal is filed against such an order, the date of the final judicial order relating to such an administrative order). 3. The date of your final departure from the United States under an administrative order of removal. 4. If you are a dual resident of a country or area with which the United States has an income tax treaty, the date on which you notify the Internal Revenue Service by filing Form 8833 and Form 8854 and are considered a resident of that country for tax purposes under the treaty. See Chapter 1, Impact of Tax Treaties , for more information on dual residents.

After you determine your alien status, your sources of income, and whether and how that income is taxed in the United States, your next step is to calculate your tax. The information in this chapter is not as comprehensive for tax-defined residents as it is for non-tax-defined residents. Tax-defined residents should obtain the forms and instructions for U.S. citizens, because the information reported on the tax return for tax-defined residents is usually the same as that for U.S. citizens. If you are both a tax-defined resident and a non-tax-defined resident in the same tax year, see Chapter 6 for information about aliens with dual status.

Non-tax-law residents can claim some itemized deductions that tax-law residents can claim. However, non-tax-law residents can only claim itemized deductions if their income is effectively linked to U.S. trade or business. Your itemized deductions on Schedule A may be subject to limitations. See the instructions for Schedule A (Form 1040) or Schedule A Instructions for Form 1040-NR — Itemized Deductions , which are included with Form 1040-NR.

You can claim the same itemized deductions as a U.S. citizen. For more information, see the instructions for Schedule A (Form 1040). If you don't list your deductions item by item, you can claim standard deductions based on your filing status. For more information, see the instructions for Form 1040 and Form 1040-SR.

If you receive income from trade or business in the U.S., you can deduct a specific itemized deduction. You generally can only include deductions and losses that are correctly classified and allocated to income from trade or business in the U.S. You cannot include deductions and/or losses related to exempt income or income from trade or business in which you have no effective connection. However, you can deduct specific charitable contributions and losses from theft and damage, even if they are not related to your effective connection income. Use Schedule A (Form 1040-NR) to claim itemized deductions. For more information, see the instructions for Form 1040-NR.
Non-tax resident individuals cannot claim the standard deduction amount. However, there is a special rule for certain non-tax residents from India, as described below.
For more information on qualifying disaster losses, see the instructions for Form 4684. To determine whether you were affected by a federally declared major disaster, go to IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief.

A special rule applies to students and apprentices who are eligible for the benefits of Section 21(2) of the US-India Income Tax Treaty. If you do not claim itemized deductions, you can claim the standard deduction. Use Table 5-1 to calculate your standard deduction for 2023. If you are married and your spouse files a separate tax return and itemizes deductions, you cannot take the standard deduction.

If you are a student or an apprentice in a trade or business and you qualify for the 21(2) treaty exemption of the United States and India and you were affected by a major disaster declared by the federal government in 2023 (see IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief and FEMA.gov/Disasters (English)), you can choose to increase your standard deduction by including any qualified disaster-related personal loss on your 2023 tax return. Use Schedule 5-1 to calculate your 2023 standard deduction. See Schedule 4684 and its instructions for more information about the tax benefits for qualified disaster-related personal losses.

You can deduct from your income the state and local income taxes you paid on income you received from sources in the United States. Your deduction is limited to a total of $10,000 (or $5,000 if married filing separately). If you received a refund or credit of taxes you paid in the previous year, do not reduce your deduction by that amount. Instead, if you took a deduction in the previous year and your deduction reduced your tax, you must include the refund or credit in your income. See the itemized deductions section of Publication 525 (English) for details on how to figure the amount to include in your income.

Donations made directly to foreign organizations are not deductible. However, donations made to U.S. organizations that are controlled by U.S. organizations and that direct funds to foreign charitable organizations, or that are foreign organizations that are the U.S. organization's administrative department, may be deductible. Under a limited number of income tax treaties, you may be eligible to deduct donations to foreign charitable organizations. See Publication 526 (English) for more details.

You can claim a foreign tax credit for foreign source income taxes paid or accruing to a foreign country, but there are limits. You cannot claim a credit for taxes paid or accruing on foreign income that is excluded. If you want to claim a credit for foreign source income taxes paid or accruing, you usually file Form 1116 with your Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. For more information, see Publication 514 (English).

If you pay someone to care for your qualifying dependent child under age 13, or your disabled dependent or disabled spouse, so you can work or look for work, you may be able to claim this credit. For more information, see Form 2441 and Publication 503 (in English).

If you paid qualified education expenses for yourself, your spouse, or your dependents, you may be eligible for these deductions. There are two education deductions: the American Opportunity Deduction and the Lifetime Learning Deduction. If you are married and filing separately, you cannot claim these deductions. Use Form 8863 to figure the deductions. For more information, see Publication 970 (English). See the definition of resident in the text below for information on the definition of resident.

You may be eligible for this credit (also called the Saver's Credit) if you contributed a qualified amount to an employer-sponsored retirement plan or to a personal retirement plan (IRA) in 2023. Use Form 8880 and its instructions to figure the credit. For more information about the requirements for claiming the credit, see Publication 590-A (English).

Adopted children are always treated as your own. Adopted children include those legally placed with you for adoption. If you did not issue a Social Security Number (or Individual Taxpayer Identification Number) for your adopted child(ren) by the filing deadline for your 2023 return (including extensions) or before, you cannot claim the child tax credit on your original or amended 2023 return. If your child did not have a Social Security Number (or Individual Taxpayer Identification Number) issued by the filing deadline for your 2023 return (including extensions) or before, you cannot claim the child tax credit for that child, but you can claim the other dependent credit for that child. See Other Dependent Credit. Use Schedule 8812 (Form 1040) and its instructions to calculate the child tax credit and other dependent credit for your adopted child(ren).

Other dependents' deductions are available to dependents who are not eligible for the child tax credit. To qualify, a dependent must be a U.S. citizen, U.S. national, or U.S. resident as defined by the tax code, and must have had a Social Security Number (SSN), Individual Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN), or Adoption Taxpayer Identification Number (ATIN) on the date of your 2023 tax filing deadline (including extensions) or before. For more information, see Form 8812 (Schedule 1040) and its instructions.

You may be eligible for a maximum $15,950 tax credit for qualifying expenses incurred in adopting a child who is eligible. Regardless of whether you have qualifying expenses, this amount can be used to adopt a child with special needs. To claim the adoption credit, attach Form 8839 to your Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR.

Low-income family benefit or labor income tax credit (EITC) is a benefit for low- and moderate-income workers. To qualify for the low-income family benefit, you must earn income from working for someone or from owning or operating a business or farm. You must also meet the basic rules. In addition, you must meet the extra requirements for workers who do not have qualifying children, or your children must meet all the requirements for qualifying children. The low-income family benefit will reduce the amount of tax you owe and may give you a refund. To learn more, go to IRS.gov/EIC. If you (and your spouse, if you file a joint return) did not get a Social Security number by the due date of your 2023 return (including an extended due date), you cannot claim the low-income family benefit on your original or amended 2023 return. In addition, if a child did not get a Social Security number by the due date of your return (including an extended due date), you cannot include that child as a qualifying child when you calculate the low-income family benefit on your original or amended 2023 return. If the Social Security card has a stamp that says «Not Valid for Employment» and the number was issued for you (or your spouse or your qualifying child) to get federal assistance, you cannot claim the low-income family benefit. Federal assistance benefits include Medicaid. If the card has this stamp and the person's immigration status has changed so that the person is now a U.S. citizen or legal permanent resident, ask the Social Security Administration to issue a new Social Security card without the stamp. To see if you qualify for the low-income family benefit, go to IRS.gov/EITCAssistant.
You can claim some of the deductions that residents can claim. You can also report any taxes you've paid, or that are considered paid, or that are withheld from your income.
You are only allowed to use the deduction when you receive the income from the valid link. You may be eligible for some of the following deductions.

If you receive foreign source income from trade or business with the United States, you may claim a foreign tax credit for any income taxes paid or accrued on that income to any foreign or U.S. property. If you do not have foreign source income from trade or business with the United States, you cannot claim a credit for taxes paid or accrued on taxes paid to foreign or U.S. territories. If you are a citizen or resident of a foreign or foreign property solely because taxes are levied on you on income from sources in the United States, you cannot claim a credit for taxes paid to foreign or U.S. property on your U.S. source income.

If you pay someone to care for your qualifying child under age 13, or your disabled dependent or disabled spouse, so you can work or look for work, you may be eligible for this credit. For definitions of these terms, see Publication 503 (English). Married non-tax-law definition residents can claim the credit only if they choose to file a joint return with a U.S. citizen or resident spouse, as described in How to Make the Election in Section 1 of Publication 503, or if they qualify as a separated married individual (see Joint Filing Test, in Publication 503 (English)). The amount of the child and dependent care credit you can claim in any tax year cannot exceed your income from the United States for that tax year. Wages for personal services performed are usually wages, salaries, and professional fees. For more information, see Publication 503 (English).

Adopted children are always treated as your own. Adopted children include those legally placed with you for legal adoption. If you did not issue a Social Security Number (or Individual Taxpayer Identification Number) for your adopted child(ren) by the due date of your 2023 tax return (including extensions) or before, you cannot claim the child tax credit on your original or amended tax return. If your child(ren) did not have a Social Security Number (or Individual Taxpayer Identification Number) issued by the due date of the 2023 filing deadline (including extensions), you cannot claim the child tax credit for that child, but you can claim the other dependent credit for that child. See Other Dependent Credit. Use Schedule 8812 (Form 1040) and its instructions to figure the credit.

The dependent who is not eligible for the child tax credit may still be eligible for other dependent deductions. This is a non-refundable tax credit of $500 per eligible individual. A qualifying dependent must be a U.S. citizen, U.S. national, or U.S. resident as defined by the tax code. See Form 1040-NR instructions. If you claim deductions for other dependents, your dependent must have received a Social Security number, individual taxpayer identification number, or adoption taxpayer identification number by the due date of your 2023 tax return (including extensions) or before. Only U.S. citizens who are not tax-law residents, Canadian, Mexican, or Korean residents, and students and apprentices from India who are eligible under the income tax treaty with India, Article 21(2), may claim deductions for other dependents.

You may be eligible for a maximum tax credit of $15,950 for qualifying expenses incurred in adopting a child who is eligible for the adoption tax credit. Regardless of whether you have qualifying expenses, this amount can be used to adopt a child with special needs. To claim the adoption credit, attach Form 8839 to your Form 1040-SR. Married non-tax-law residents can claim the credit only if they file a joint return with a U.S. citizen or resident spouse, as described in Nonresident Spouse Considered a Resident, in Chapter 1. A nonresident spouse is considered a resident if he or she meets the requirements for a separated married individual (see Separated Married Filing, in Form 8839 instructions).

If you were a non-resident for any part of the tax year, you generally cannot claim the Earned Income Credit (EIC). However, if you are married and file a joint return with a U.S. citizen or resident spouse, as a nonresident spouse considered a resident, you may be eligible for the credit. If you and your spouse did not obtain a Social Security Number by the due date of your 2023 tax return (including extensions) or before, you cannot claim the credit on your original or amended 2023 tax return. In addition, if your child did not obtain a Social Security Number by the due date of your return (including extensions) or before, you cannot include that child as a qualifying child when calculating your original or amended 2023 tax return. If the Social Security card has a stamp that says «Not Valid for Employment» and the number was issued for you (or your spouse or your qualifying child) to receive a federal benefit, you cannot claim the credit. For example, Medicaid is a federal benefit. If the card has this stamp and the individual's immigration status has changed so that the individual is now a U.S. citizen or legal permanent resident, ask the Social Security Administration to issue a new Social Security card without the stamp. See Publication 596 (English) for more information about this credit.

When you are a resident for tax purposes, any federal income tax withheld from your salary during the tax year can be credited against your U.S. income tax liability for that year. Whether you were engaged in trade or business in the U.S. during the year, and whether your salary (or any other income) was derived from trade or business in the U.S., you may claim the withheld income tax credit.

If you have two or more employers, you may be able to claim a credit for income taxes paid to the United States that exceed the Social Security tax maximum. See Chapter 8, Social Security and Medicare Tax, for more information.

For payments of more than $20,000 to you in 2023 that are subject to the Railroad Retirement Tax Act (RRTA) supplement, your employer must withhold 0.9% (0.009) additional Medicare tax. If you do not owe additional Medicare tax, you can report the total amount of your tax liability on your tax return by deducting any withheld additional Medicare tax from the total amount of your tax liability reported on your tax return.

If you are a shareholder of a mutual fund (or other regulated investment company (RIC)) or real estate investment trust (REIT), you may claim a portion of the tax paid by your company on your unallocated long-term capital gains. You will receive this information on Form 2439, which you must attach to your tax return.

You can claim any taxes withheld from your investment source and other FDAP income when you receive the payment. Fixed or determinable income includes interest, dividends, rent, and royalties that you do not claim as being linked to you. Wages or salary payments can be fixed or determinable income, but are usually subject to the above withholding tax. Tax on fixed or determinable income is withheld at a 30% or lower rate of agreement tax.

If your foreign partner in a partnership, the partnership will withhold tax on your share of the partnership's effective connected earnings (ECE) income. The partnership will provide you with a statement showing the withheld tax on Form 8805. A publicly traded partnership will withhold tax on the actual distribution of ECE. In this case, the partnership will provide you with a statement on Form 1042-S. Claim the withheld tax as item 25e or 25g on Form 1040-NR, depending on the circumstances.

For amounts in excess of this amount, the withholding and payment rules are similar to those for the withholding tax on the sale of U.S. real property. You will receive Form 8288-A, which reflects the withheld amount, and you then may claim the withheld amount as a tax credit on your Form 1040-NR, line 25f. You may be able to provide the transferee with certain information to reduce or eliminate the withholding tax. If you are a transferee subject to withholding, the partnership may withhold tax on the allocation to you under section 1446(f)(4).
