You can claim any taxes withheld on the disposition of U.S. real property interests (or income derived from the disposition of U.S. real property interests) as a credit. See Chapter 4, Real Property Dispositions. The buyer will provide you with a statement of the withheld amount on Form 8288-A. Claim the withheld taxes as a credit on line 25f of Form 1040-NR.

If you are a non-tax-law resident and you are a true resident of American Samoa or Puerto Rico for the entire tax year, your tax obligations are generally the same as those of a tax-law resident. You should file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR and report all income from U.S. sources and from abroad. However, you can exclude the income discussed in the following paragraphs. In reporting income for tax purposes other than income tax, you will be considered a non-tax-law resident. For example, you are not allowed to use the standard deduction, you cannot file a joint return, and you cannot claim a dependent unless the person is a U.S. citizen or national. There are limits on the deductions and credits you can claim. See Tax-Law Resident for more information.

If you are a true resident of Puerto Rico for the entire year, you can exclude from your total income all income from Puerto Rico sources (except for amounts earned as an employee of the United States or any of its agencies). If you report income on a calendar year basis and you do not have payroll taxes withheld in 2023, file your tax return and pay your tax by June 15, 2024. You must also pay the first estimated tax payment for 2024 by June 15, 2024. You cannot file a joint income tax return or pay joint estimated taxes. However, if you are married to a U.S. citizen or resident, see Chapter 1, Nonresident Spouses Considered Residents. If you earn income that requires payroll taxes to be withheld, your U.S. income tax return should be filed by April 15, 2024. You must also pay the first estimated tax payment for 2024 by April 15, 2024. For information about payroll taxes and estimated taxes, see Chapter 8.

If you are a true resident of American Samoa for the entire year, you can exclude from your total income all income from American Samoa (except for amounts earned as an employee of the government of American Samoa or any of its agencies). Under the exclusion, employees of the government of American Samoa are not considered employees of the government of the United States or any of its agencies. For more information on this exclusion, see Form 4563 and Publication 570 (English).

You must calculate your income and file a tax return for the tax year in which you are required to file. If you have not established a fiscal tax year, your tax year is the calendar year. A calendar year is a 12-month period ending on December 31. If you have established a normal fiscal year (a 12-month period ending on the last day of the month other than December or a 52- to 53-week year) and are considered a U.S. resident for any part of a calendar year, your fiscal year will be considered a U.S. resident for that calendar year.

Tax forms, statements, and other tax-related documents must include a tax identification number (TIN). For individuals, this is a social security number (SSN). If you do not have and are not eligible for a social security number, you must apply for a personal tax identification number (ITIN). If you are a sole proprietor conducting trade or business and have employees or a qualified retirement plan, you need an employer identification number (EIN). If you meet the following conditions, you must provide a tax identification number (TIN): You are a non-tax law resident's spouse who is considered a resident, as described in Chapter 1; or You file a tax return, an amended tax return, or a refund claim (but not an information return) as a non-tax law resident.

Generally speaking, if you are a legal permanent resident of the United States or in an authorized employment-based immigration category, you can obtain a Social Security Number. To apply for a new Social Security Number, you must personally go to your local Social Security Administration (SSA) office to fill out and submit Form SS-5, Application and Instructions for a Social Security Number. To obtain Form SS-5, you can download it from SSA.gov/forms (English) or call 800-772-1213 to contact the SSA, or visit your local SSA office to obtain the form. For more information, visit Social Security Number and Social Security Card (English).

If you already have a personal tax identification number, you must enter it in any place on your tax return that requires a social security number. If you do not have an ITIN and are not eligible for a social security number, you must apply for a personal tax identification number. For detailed instructions on how to do this, see Form W-7 and its instructions. If you are eligible for a personal tax identification number and you have completed your application, you will usually receive a letter from the IRS within 7 weeks that assigns your tax number. If you have not received a personal tax identification number or other letter from the IRS within 7 weeks after you apply, call the IRS toll-free at 800-829-1040 (if in the United States) to inquire about the status of your application. If you are outside the United States, call 267-941-1000 (not a toll-free number). A personal tax identification number is used only for tax purposes. By law, you are not eligible for social security benefits or to change your employment or immigration status. In addition to those who need to provide a tax identification number (TIN) and are not eligible for a social security number, you must file Form W-7 for the spouse or dependent of a qualified individual who is eligible for permitted tax benefits but is not eligible for a social security number. For more information about obtaining a personal tax identification number, see the instructions for Form W-7 or go to IRS.gov/ITIN.

Some ITINs must be renewed. If you did not use your ITIN at least once on a federal tax return in 2020, 2021, or 2022, it will expire on December 31, 2023, and if you need to file a federal tax return in 2023, you must renew it. If you do not need to file a federal tax return, you do not need to update your individual tax identification number. To update your individual tax identification number, see the instructions for Form W-7 at IRS.gov/FormW7. To learn more, go to IRS.gov/ITIN. ITINs assigned before 2013 have expired, and if you need to file a tax return in 2023, you must renew it. If you previously filed a renewal application and it was approved, you do not need to renew again, unless you did not use your ITIN at least once on a federal tax return in 2020, 2021, or 2022.

Your tax liability depends on your filing status. Your filing status is important in determining whether you can take certain deductions and credits. The rules for determining your filing status are different for tax-defined residents and non-tax-defined residents.
Tax law defines residents as those who can file a tax return using the same tax status as a US citizen. For more information on tax status, please refer to your Form instructions or Publication 501.

Generally, you may file a joint return only if you and your spouse are U.S. citizens or residents for the entire tax year, or if you choose to be treated as a resident spouse of a resident spouse, as described in Chapter 1.

If your spouse died in 2021 or 2022 and you were not remarried by the end of 2023, you may be eligible to file as a qualified surviving spouse and use the joint filing tax rate. This applies only if you were able to file a joint return with your spouse in the year of his or her death. For more information on the qualified surviving spouse tax filing status, see Qualified Surviving Spouse, which is in the 2023 instructions for Form 1040.

If you are unmarried or deemed unmarried at the end of the year and you pay more than half of the housing maintenance expenses for you and a qualifying person, you are eligible to be a head of household. You must be a resident for the entire tax year. If your spouse is a non-resident for any part of the year and your spouse does not elect to be treated as a resident, you will be deemed unmarried, as described in Chapter 1, Nonresident Spouse Treated as Resident.

Married non-tax residents who are not married to US citizens or residents are generally required to use the married filing separately tax form line or tax calculation worksheet when determining whether they have income tax reporting obligations in the US.

Married non-tax residents generally cannot use the single-person tax tables or tax-calculation worksheets. However, if you were separated from your spouse for the last 6 months of the year and you are a resident of Canada, Mexico, or Korea, or a married U.S. citizen, you may be able to file as single. See the instructions for Form 1040-NR to determine if you qualify. A U.S. citizen is defined in this section. Non-tax residents generally cannot file as married. However, a non-tax resident who is married to a U.S. citizen or resident may choose to be treated as a resident and file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. For information about these choices, see the instructions for Form 1040. If you do not choose to file jointly, file Form 1040-NR and use the tax tables or the tax-calculation worksheets for married individuals who file separately.

If your spouse died in 2021 or 2022 and you did not remarry before the end of 2023, you may be eligible to file as a surviving spouse and use the joint filing tax rate. For more information about the surviving spouse filing status, see the surviving spouse section, which is included in the 2023 instructions for Form 1040-NR.

If you are not a tax resident at any time during the tax year, you cannot file as head of household. However, if you are married, your spouse may be eligible to file as head of household if: Your spouse is a tax resident or U.S. citizen for the entire tax year; You do not elect to be treated as a tax resident; and Your spouse meets the other requirements for this filing status, as described in the previous section, Tax resident.
For purposes of determining whether income from a resident estate or trust is effectively connected with a U.S. trade or business, the tax rate schedule W must be used in filing Form 1040-NR.

You must report each item of income in accordance with the rules in Chapters 2, 3, and 4. For tax-defined residents, this includes income from sources within and outside the United States. For non-tax-defined residents, this includes income that is effectively connected with U.S. trade or business (subject to the progressive rate) and income from sources outside the United States that is not effectively connected with U.S. trade or business (subject to the 30% flat rate or lower tax treaty rate).
Residents and non-tax residents can claim similar deductions on their US tax returns. However, non-tax residents can only claim deductions for income related to their trade or business in the US.

If you are a resident for the entire tax year, you can claim the same deductions as a U.S. citizen. Although the following discussion of "tax-resident" involves some rules and instructions that are also applicable to you, they are specifically for non-tax-resident individuals. You should get Form 1040 instructions to get more information about how to claim the allowed deductions.

You can claim a deduction for your ECTI. You generally cannot claim a deduction for income that is not related to your U.S. business activities. However, the specific itemized deductions described below are the only deductions you can claim in relation to your ECTI.

You can deduct all ordinary and necessary expenses incurred in your U.S. trade or business that are directly connected to that trade or business. For more information about other business expenses, see the guide to Business Expenses resources at IRS.gov/Pub535 (English).

If you paid interest on student loans in 2023 for a qualified student, you can deduct up to $2,500 of the interest you paid. Generally, if you meet all the requirements, you can claim the deduction. The deduction is reported on line 21 of Form 1040, Schedule 1 (Form 1040). Attach Schedule 1 (Form 1040) with your Form 1040-NR. To calculate the deduction, see the instructions for Form 1040-NR. For more information, see Publication 970 (English).

If your income is effectively connected with U.S. trade or business, you may deduct up to 20% of your qualified trade or business income, plus 20% of your qualified real estate investment trust (REIT) dividends and qualified publicly traded partnership (PTP) income. For more information, see line 13a of the instructions for Form 1040-NR. For more information about the deduction for qualified trade or business income, see Form 8995, Form 8995-A, and their attachments, and the instructions for those forms.

As long as the income is related to your trade or business with the U.S., you can deduct losses you incur in trades that are intended to make a profit, provided you do not receive compensation for the losses from insurance or otherwise.

If you are an eligible educator in 2023, you can deduct up to $300 of your qualified expenses for specific professional development courses and books, supplies (excluding non-運動 supplies for health or physical education courses), computer equipment (including related software and services), and other auxiliary aids and materials that you use in your classroom. For more information, see your tax form instructions. Qualified expenses include amounts paid or incurred in 2023 for personal protective equipment, disinfectants, and other supplies to prevent the spread of COVID-19.

If you contributed to a traditional IRA in 2023, you may be able to claim a traditional IRA deduction. However, you must have taxable compensation from a U.S. trade or business to do so. You should receive Form 5498 by May 31, 2024, which shows all your contributions to your traditional IRA for 2023. If you participate in a retirement plan through work or self-employment (qualified pension, profit-sharing (including 401(k)s), annuities, simplified employee pension, employee savings incentive match plan for employees, etc.), your traditional IRA deduction may be reduced or eliminated. However, even if you can't deduct, you can still contribute to a traditional IRA. If you contributed to a non-deductible traditional IRA in 2023, you must report it on Form 8606. For more information, see Publication 590-A.

Do not include the value of government-provided moving and storage services, because this is based on a military move and the permanent change of station event. Similarly, do not include amounts received as moving allowance, temporary lodging expenses, temporary lodging allowance, or moving-in allowance. For more information, see Publication 3 (English).

If you are self-employed, you can deduct the amounts you contribute to a simple employee pension plan, employee savings incentive plan or qualified retirement plan for yourself and your common-law employees (if any). To make a deductible contribution for yourself, you must have net self-employment income related to your U.S. trade or business that is effective. Refer to Publication 560 (English) for more information.

You must include in your income all interest income that you received or that was credited to your account during the year. Do not deduct any penalties you must pay when you withdraw money from a savings account before its maturity date. However, if the interest income is related to your trade or business in the United States, you may deduct the amount of any penalty charged by the financial institution for early withdrawal on line 17 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040). Attach Schedule 1 (Form 1040) to your Form 1040-NR.

If you do not provide the SSN, ITIN, or Adoption Taxpayer Identification Number (ATIN) of the person(s) claimed as a dependent on your tax return, or if the number you provide is incorrect, certain tax benefits may be denied. See the identification numbers section above.

If you are a tax-defined resident, qualifying dependents include your qualifying children or qualifying relatives. A child must pass five tests to be reported as your qualifying child. A person must pass four tests to be reported as your qualifying relative. For more information, see Form 1040 instructions. If you fail to report the SSN, ITIN, or Adoption Taxpayer Identification Number (ATIN) of your reported dependents or you report an incorrect number, certain tax benefits may be denied. See the section on identification numbers.

If you are a resident of Mexico or Canada, or a U.S. citizen, you can claim your each qualifying dependent. Mexican or Canadian residents or U.S. citizens must use the same rules to determine who is a qualifying dependent. See Publication 501 (English) to learn about these rules.

As a non-tax resident of South Korea (excluding government employees), non-tax residents can claim their children as dependents. In addition to using the same rules as US citizens to determine who is a dependent, under the income tax treaty with South Korea, children must be living with a non-tax resident of the US during the tax year.
Students and apprentices who are eligible for the benefits of Article 21(2) of the US-India Income Tax Treaty, if they meet the same rules applicable to US citizens, may claim their dependents.

If you are both a tax-defined resident and a non-tax-defined resident in the same year, you have a dual-status tax year. Dual status does not involve your citizenship; it only refers to your U.S. resident status. When determining your U.S. income tax liability in a dual-status tax year, you are subject to different rules for that year's portion of the year that you are a U.S. resident and for that year's portion of the year that you are a nonresident. The most common dual-status tax year is the year you enter and leave the United States. See Foreign Person with Dual Status in Chapter 1. If you are a married person who has elected to be treated as a tax-defined resident spouse, the rules in this chapter do not apply to you for that year.

If you are a resident for tax purposes on the last day of the tax year and you file your income on a calendar year basis, you must file your return by April 15 of the following year (but see the description of the tips in the text). If you do not file on a calendar year basis, you must file your return by the 15th day of the 4th month after the end of the tax year. In either case, you must file your return to the address shown on the back of Form 1040 for filing by foreign persons with dual status. If you are a nonresident for tax purposes on the last day of the tax year and you file your income on a calendar year basis, you must file your return by April 15 of the following year. If you do not file on a calendar year basis, you must file your return by the 15th day of the 4th month after the end of the tax year. If you have not received any income subject to withholding and you file on a calendar year basis, you must file your return by June 15 of the following year. If you do not file on a calendar year basis, you must file your return by the 15th day of the 6th month after the end of the tax year. In either case, you must file your return to the following address: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Austin, TX 73301-0215 If you are attaching payment, you must file your return to the following address: Internal Revenue Service P.O.Box 1303 Charlotte, NC 28201-1303 If the normal filing date falls on a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday, you must file on the next day (not a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday).

You must file your tax return within the tax year in which you are required to file. If you have not established a fiscal tax year, your tax year is the calendar year. A calendar year is 12 months ending on December 31. If you have established a normal fiscal year (12 months or a 52 to 53 week year ending on the last day of the month other than December) and are considered a U.S. resident for any part of a calendar year, your fiscal year will be considered a U.S. resident for that calendar year.

For that portion of the year that you are a resident for tax purposes, all sources of income are taxable. If you receive income from sources outside the United States during the period that you are a resident for tax purposes, it is taxable. Even if you earned this income during a period that you are not a resident for tax purposes, or if you received it after becoming a nonresident for tax purposes and before the end of the year, it is taxable. For that portion of the year that you are a nonresident for tax purposes, you must pay tax on income from the United States and on certain foreign income that is considered to be effectively connected with United States trade or business. Chapter 4 discusses the rules for considering foreign source income to be effectively connected, which are contained in Foreign Income. If you receive income from sources outside the United States that is not effectively connected with United States trade or business, it is not taxable. Even if the income is earned during a period that you are a resident for tax purposes, or if you receive it after becoming a resident for tax purposes or a United States citizen before the end of the year, the income is not taxable. Unless there is a specific exemption under the provisions of the tax treaty or tax convention, income from the United States, whether you are a nonresident for tax purposes or a resident for tax purposes, is taxable. Generally, treaty provisions apply only to that portion of the year that you are a nonresident. However, in certain circumstances, treaty provisions may apply when you are a resident for tax purposes. See Chapter 9 for more information. In determining which income is taxable in the United States, you must consider the exemptions from United States tax law and the low-tax and exemption provisions of tax treaties with certain foreign countries. For further discussion of tax treaties, see Chapter 9.
You cannot use the standard deductions allowed on Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. However, you can list any allowed deductions individually.
You cannot file a joint tax return. However, please see the content in Chapter 1, Choosing Tax Law Definitions of Resident Status, which is located in Double-Status Foreigners.

As a dual-status taxpayer, you may be able to claim a dependent on your tax return. Generally, a dependent is a qualifying child or a qualifying relative. If you have a qualifying dependent, you may be entitled to claim additional deductions and credits. For more information, see the instructions for Form 1040 or Form 1040-NR. If you are a U.S. citizen or a resident of Canada or Mexico, you can claim a dependent under the same conditions as a U.S. citizen. If you are a resident of South Korea or India, see Chapter 5.

All income you receive during your period of residence, and all income you receive during your non-residence period that is effectively connected with U.S. trade or business, will be added to and taxed at the rate applicable to U.S. citizens and residents after any allowable deductions are taken. Income from non-residence periods that is not effectively connected with U.S. trade or business will be taxed at a flat 30% rate or a lower treaty rate. You cannot deduct any expenses from this income.

In the year you are a resident for tax purposes, 85% of any Social Security benefits (and equivalent part of 1st-level Railroad Retirement benefits) you receive are subject to a flat 30% tax, unless you are exempt or subject to a lower treaty rate. (See Chapter 4, 30% Tax Rules.) If you are a resident for part of the year, and your adjusted gross income plus half of these benefits exceeds a certain base amount, part of the Social Security benefits and an equivalent part of the 1st-level Railroad Retirement benefits will be taxed at progressive rates. Use the Social Security benefits worktable in the instructions for Form 1040 to help you calculate the part of your Social Security benefits and an equivalent part of the 1st-level Railroad Retirement benefits that are taxable as a resident for the year. If you received Social Security benefits during a non-resident period, the Social Security Administration (SSA) will send you a Form SSA-1042S showing your total benefits for the year and the amount of tax withheld. You will not receive a separate tax form for each benefit you receive. Therefore, you must keep a record of these amounts. You will need this information to complete your tax return correctly and calculate your tax liability.

As a dual-status alien, you generally can claim the same tax exemption rules as residents defined by tax law. There may be specific restrictions. These restrictions will be discussed here, and will briefly describe the exemptions that individuals often claim. Unless you are married and you choose to file a joint return with your U.S. citizen or resident spouse, you cannot claim the education credit, the low-income family benefit (EIC), or the elderly or disabled exemption, as described in Chapter 1, for 2023.

If you have already paid or are responsible for paying income tax on income from foreign sources, you can claim a foreign tax credit. If you claim a foreign tax credit, you usually must attach a statement with your income tax return. For more information, see the instructions for Form 1116 and Publication 514 (English).

If you pay someone to care for your qualifying dependent child under age 13, or your disabled dependent or disabled spouse, so you can work or look for work, you may be eligible for this credit. Foreigners who are married to someone of a different citizenship must file a joint return, as described in Chapter 1, or if they qualify as separated married persons, as described in Chapter 1. The amount of the child and dependent care credit you can claim in any tax year cannot exceed your income for that tax year. For more information, see Publication 503 (English) and Form 2441.

Adopted children are always treated as your own. Adopted children include those legally placed with you for adoption. If you did not issue a Social Security Number (or Individual Taxpayer Identification Number) for your adopted child(ren) by the due date of your 2023 tax return (including extensions) or before, you cannot claim the child tax credit on your original or amended 2023 tax return. If your child did not have a Social Security Number (or Individual Taxpayer Identification Number) issued by the due date of the 2023 filing deadline (including extensions), you cannot claim the child tax credit for that child, but you can claim the other dependent credit for that child. See Other Dependent Credit. Use Schedule 8812 (Form 1040) and its instructions to figure the credit.

Other dependents' deductions are available to dependents who are not eligible for the child tax credit. To qualify, a dependent must be a U.S. citizen, U.S. national, or U.S. resident for tax purposes, and must have had a Social Security number, individual taxpayer identification number, or adoption taxpayer identification number on the date of your 2023 tax filing deadline (including extensions) or before.

You may be eligible for a tax credit of up to $15,950 for qualifying expenses incurred in adopting a child who is eligible for adoption assistance. Regardless of whether you have qualifying expenses, this amount can be used to adopt a child with special needs. To claim the adoption credit, attach Form 8839 to your U.S. income tax return. Only married individuals who are foreign nationals may claim the credit if they are considered residents for U.S. tax purposes or if they qualify as separated married individuals (see the instructions for Form 8839 for more information).

You can also report as payments to your U.S. income tax obligations any specific taxes you have paid, are considered to have paid, or have been withheld from your income. This includes: taxes withheld from your wages earned in the U.S., taxes withheld from various sources of U.S. income (other than wages), estimated taxes paid using Form 1040-ES or Form 1040-ES(NR), and taxes paid using Form 1040-C when you leave the U.S.
You must file a U.S. income tax return as a dual-status foreign national depending on whether you are a tax resident or non-tax resident at the end of the tax year.

If you are a dual-status taxpayer and become a resident in the tax year and are a resident on the last day of the tax year, you must file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. Enter 'Dual-Status Return' at the top of your tax return. Attach a statement to your tax return to show your income for the part of the year that you were a nonresident. You can use Form 1040-NR as the statement, but be sure to enter 'Dual-Status Statement' at the top.

If you are a dual-status taxpayer, you must file Form 1040-NR if you give up your U.S. residency during the tax year and are not a U.S. resident on the last day of the tax year. On the top of your tax return, enter “Dual-Status Return”. Attach a statement to your tax return to show the part of the year you were a resident. You can use Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR as the statement, but you must enter “Dual-Status Statement” on the top. If you abandon or terminate your residency in 2023, you may need to file a statement of abandonment (Form 8854). For more information, see Chapter 4, Abandonment Tax.

Tax law defines residents as required to file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR, reporting address as shown on the instructions for Form 1040. The filing deadline for tax returns and payment of any taxes due is April 15 of the year following the year in which you file your tax return (but please see the description in the Tips above). Under US immigration law, legal permanent residents who fail to file as residents are considered to have renounced their status and may lose their permanent resident status.

If you file Form 4868 and do not file your tax return by the due date, you will automatically receive an extension of 6 months (for calendar-year taxpayers, October 15). For more information, see Form 4868. The automatic 6-month extension will not extend the time to pay your tax. If you do not pay your tax by the original due date, you will incur interest on the unpaid tax and may be subject to penalties. If your principal place of business and residence are outside the United States and Puerto Rico on April 15, you will automatically be granted an extension to June 15. If you need more time, and file Form 4868 before June 15, you may be granted an additional 4 months until October 15. In addition to the 6-month extension, a foreign taxpayer (as defined in Form 4868) may request a 2-month extension of time to file (for calendar-year taxpayers, December 15). To request this extension, you must send a letter to the IRS explaining why you need the extra 2 months. Mail the letter to the following address before the extended due date (for calendar-year taxpayers, October 15): Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Center Austin, TX 73301-0215 Unless your request is denied because it is not timely, the IRS will not send you a notice. A taxpayer who files Form 2350 is not eligible for a 2-month extension of time to file (for U.S. citizens and foreign nationals who are eligible for special tax treatment). If the filing deadline is a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday, the deadline is the next business day. You can file your tax return electronically. Go to IRS.gov/Efile for more information.

If you want to accomplish the following, you must also file: Claim excess withheld or overpaid taxes for refund, or Claim any deductions or credits. For example, if you do not engage in business in the United States but have income from real property (as described in Chapter 4) that you choose to treat as effective connected income, you must file a true and accurate tax return on time to deduct any allowable deductions. For information on what is timely, see When to claim deductions and credits. The content is in the What is timely section of the text.

Even if you have left the United States and filed Form 1040-C at departure, you still must file a U.S. income tax return. If you are married and you and your spouse both need to file, you must each file a separate return.

If you are an employee and you receive wages that are subject to US income tax, you usually file your tax return before the 15th day of the 4th month after the tax year ends. For 2023 calendar year, please file your tax return by April 15, 2024. If you are not an employee who receives US income tax withheld from your wages, you must file your tax return before the 15th day of the 6th month after the tax year ends. For 2023 calendar year, please file your tax return by June 17, 2024.

If you cannot file your tax return by the due date, file Form 4868 or use one of the electronic filing options described in the instructions for Form 4868. For calendar year 2023, the due date will be extended to October 15, 2024. If your normal due date is June 17, 2024, this will extend the due date to December 15, 2024. You must file an extension request before your return's normal due date. An automatic 6-month extension of time to file will not extend your time to pay taxes. If you do not pay your taxes by the original due date, you will owe interest on the unpaid taxes and may be subject to penalties. See Form 4868.

The following deductions are not subject to the time requirements. Withholding tax deductions. Deductions for specific uses of gasoline and special fuels. Tax deductions for the distribution of long-term capital gains from mutual funds (or other regulated investment companies) or real estate investment trusts.

If your activities in the United States are restricted and you believe that you have no effective connection with the United States during the tax year, you can file a protective return (Form 1040-NR). By filing a protective return, you can preserve your right to claim certain deductions and credits in the future if it is later determined that you have an effective connection with the United States with respect to a portion or all of your income. You do not need to report any income that has an effective connection or any deductions on a protective return, but you must state the reason for filing the return. If you believe that you have income that has an effective connection, file your return by the regular due date, reporting that income and the related deductions. To preserve your right to claim deductions or credits with respect to other activities, include a statement with your return stating that you wish to preserve your right to claim deductions or credits with respect to other activities if it is later determined that they have an effective connection with the United States. If you believe that you are not subject to United States taxation because of a tax treaty, follow the same procedure. Be sure to also include item L on Form 1040-NR (Attachment OI).

Based on the facts and circumstances, you took reasonable and diligent actions in failing to file a U.S. income tax return (including a protective return), and you coordinated with the IRS to determine your U.S. income tax liability for the tax year for which you failed to file a return, then the IRS may waive the filing deadline.

Report all income from the United States and all other sources on your tax return. For information on filing a tax return for the U.S. Virgin Islands, contact the Bureau of Internal Revenue of the U.S. Virgin Islands. If you are a true resident of the U.S. Virgin Islands for the entire tax year and temporarily work in the United States, you must file a tax return with the U.S. Virgin Islands and file your income tax return at the following address. Bureau of Internal Revenue 6115 Estate Smith Bay Suite 225 St. Thomas, VI 00802 Chapter 8 discusses the withholding of U.S. Virgin Islands residents' U.S. payroll taxes.

If you are a true resident of Guam or the Northern Mariana Islands (CNMI) for the entire tax year, you must file a tax return with Guam or the Northern Mariana Islands and pay any taxes due to Guam or the Northern Mariana Islands. Report all income on your tax return, including income from the United States. You do not need to file a separate United States income tax return. True residents of Guam should file their tax return at the following address. . Department of Revenue and Taxation Government of Guam P.O.Box 23607 Barrigada, GU 96921 . True residents of the Northern Mariana Islands should file their tax return at the following address. . Department of Finance Division of Revenue and Taxation Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands P.O.Box 5234 CHRB Saipan, MP 96950 . If you are not a true resident of Guam or the Northern Mariana Islands, please refer to Publication 570 (English) for information on where to file your tax return.

If you find that you need to make changes to your income, deductions, or credits after you have filed your return, file Form 1040-X. If you should have filed Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR instead of Form 1040-NR, or vice versa, use Form 1040-X. If you are changing Form 1040-NR or filing the correct return, enter "Amended (Modified)" at the top and attach the corrected return (Form 1040, Form 1040-SR, or Form 1040-NR) with Form 1040-X. Generally, an amended return to claim a refund must be filed within 3 years of the date you filed your original return or within 2 years of the date you paid the tax, whichever is later. A return filed before the due date is considered filed on the due date.
You may need to file an information return to report certain foreign income or assets or monetary transactions.

Unreported, reported with significant omissions or false statements, or false or fraudulent reporting will be subject to civil and criminal penalties. Moreover, the full amount of the currency or monetary instrument may be seized and forfeited.

If the total value of these assets exceeds the applicable threshold (that is, the 'reporting threshold'), you must file Form 8938. The reporting threshold varies depending on whether you are a U.S. resident, married, or filing a joint return. Specific foreign financial assets include any financial accounts held by a foreign financial institution, and any holdings of securities, stocks, or other rights in a foreign entity, and any financial instruments or contracts with a non-U.S. issuer or counterparty. If you are required to file Form 8938 but do not, or you underreport taxes because of a failure to disclose a foreign financial asset in which you have an interest, you may be subject to penalties. For more information about filing Form 8938, see the instructions for Form 8938.

If any item on your tax return can be classified as a tax avoidance device, it will not be reduced by full disclosure. However, if it is due to substantial authority, it will be reduced, but only if you reasonably believe that your tax treatment is the proper treatment.

The tax treatment of a tax item may be different depending on the facts and circumstances. The factors to be considered include court opinions, regulations of the Ministry of Finance, tax rulings, tax provisions, and notices and announcements issued by the National Tax Service and published in the National Tax Bulletin.

If you have provided sufficient reasons (reasonable grounds) for your actions in dealing with the matter, you will not have to pay a penalty. You must also show that your actions were done in good faith. This does not apply to transactions that lack economic substance.

If you file an incorrect tax return to claim a refund or credit, you may have to pay a penalty. The penalty is 20% of the amount of the claim that is denied, unless you can show that you have a reasonable basis for the claim. However, a claim that is denied because of a lack of economic substance will not be considered a reasonable basis. Any amount of the claim that is denied because of a lack of accuracy or fraud will not be included in the calculation. Frivolous tax returns.

If you fail to include your Social Security Number (SSN) or Individual Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN) or another person's Social Security Number or Individual Taxpayer Identification Number on your tax return, statement, or other document, you may be subject to a penalty of $50 per missing number. If you fail to provide your Social Security Number or Individual Taxpayer Identification Number to others when required on a tax return, statement, or other document, you may also be subject to a penalty of $50 per missing number. For example, if you have an interest-bearing bank account, you must provide your Social Security Number or Individual Taxpayer Identification Number to the bank. The number must appear on Form 1099-INT or other bank statements sent to you. If you do not provide your Social Security Number or Individual Taxpayer Identification Number to the bank, you will be subject to a penalty of $50. (You may also be required to pay estimated tax.) If you can show that the omission was due to reasonable cause rather than willful neglect, you will not be subject to the penalty.
If you can prove that you failed to file your tax return on time for reasonable cause rather than willful neglect, you won't have to pay a penalty.

When you fail to pay your tax after the due date, you will be charged 1% of the unpaid tax (1/2 of 0.005) for each month you fail to pay (one month is counted for each partial month past the due date). If you pay at least 90% of your actual tax liability by the filing deadline and pay the balance when you file your return, you will not be subject to penalties during the 6-month automatic extension period. If a payment arrangement is in effect for that month, the penalty rate is half the general rate, 1/4% (0.0025, not 1/2% (0.005)). You must file your return by the due date (including the extension) to qualify for the penalty abatement. If a notice of intent to levy is issued, the rate will increase to 1% on the first month after the date of the notice is issued, at least 10 days after the date of the notice. If a notice of immediate payment and demand is issued, the rate will increase to 1% on the first month after the date of the notice and demand is issued. The penalty may not exceed 25% of the unpaid tax. If you can demonstrate that you have a sufficient reason for failing to pay your tax on time, you will not be required to pay the penalty.

If you fully disclose on your tax return the conduct that at least has a reasonable basis, you can avoid penalties for ignoring the rules or regulations. See Disclosure Statement. This exception does not apply to items that are attributable to tax avoidance. In addition, if you do not keep adequate books or records, or do not properly substantiate the items, this will not apply.

This chapter discusses how to pay U.S. income tax when you earn or receive income during the year. Generally, federal income tax is a pay-as-you-go tax. Pay-as-you-go has two forms. 1. Withholding. If you are an employee, your employer may withhold income tax from your paycheck. Certain other income may also be withheld, including retirement income, bonuses, commissions, and gambling winnings. In each case, the amount withheld will be paid to the U.S. Treasury on your behalf. 2. Estimating taxes. If you are not paying taxes through withholding, or not paying enough through withholding, you may have to pay estimated taxes. Self-employed people usually pay taxes this way. If you receive dividends, interest, rent, and royalties, you may have to pay estimated taxes. Estimated taxes are used not only to pay income tax, but also to pay self-employment tax and alternative minimum tax.

You must inform your employer whether you are a resident or a nonresident for tax purposes so that your employer can withhold the correct amount of tax from your salary. If you are a resident for tax purposes under the rules discussed in Chapter 1, you must file Form W-9 or a similar form with your employer. If you are a nonresident for tax purposes, you must file Form 8233 or Form W-8BEN with your employer to prove that you are a nonresident, or Form W-4 to prove that your salary is withheld at the same rate as a resident or U.S. citizen. If you are a resident for tax purposes and you receive income from sources within the United States other than salary (e.g., dividends and royalties), you must file Form W-9 or a similar form with the withholding agent (usually the source of the income) so that the agent does not withhold tax at a 30% (or lower treaty) rate. If you receive this type of income as a nonresident, you must file Form W-8BEN with the withholding agent so that the agent withholds tax at a 30% (or lower treaty) rate. However, if the income is linked to U.S. trade or business, you must file Form W-8ECI.

The following description generally applies only to non-tax-defined residents. Tax-defined residents pay taxes on their income and self-employment income at the same rates as U.S. citizens. Wages and other compensation paid to non-tax-defined residents for services as employees are generally subject to the same tax rates as tax-defined residents and U.S. citizens. Therefore, unless your compensation is specifically excluded from the definition of 'wages' by law, or is exempt from tax under a treaty, you must pay tax on it at the flat rate.

If you are an employee and your income is subject to withholding, you must file Form W-4. If your scholarship or fellowship is based on past, present, or anticipated service, and you do not qualify for the tax treaty withholding exemption described in the instructions for Form 8233 (as described later in this publication), you must also file Form W-4. These are the services that you must provide as a condition of receiving a scholarship or fellowship (or tuition reduction). Non-tax-law residents who file Form W-4 based on services performed in the United States must follow the special instructions in Notice 1392 (English version). Services performed in the United States include compensation paid as salary, wages, fees, bonuses, commissions, educational assistance, scholarship income, and similar payments to employees. To determine whether you need to increase or decrease your withholding, use the IRS Withholding Calculator. See Scholarships and Fellowships Withholding Tax, to determine how to file Form W-4 when you receive a non-service scholarship or fellowship grant from the United States.
If you are eligible for the benefits of Article 21(2) of the US-India Income Tax Treaty, you can apply for an additional standard deduction allowance.

If you are a domestic employee, your employer does not have to withhold income tax from your wages. However, you can elect to have income tax withheld by completing Form W-4, Employee's Withholding Allowance Certificate, with your employer. The election is effective when your employer begins withholding. You or your employer can terminate the election by written notice to the other.

If you are an H-2A agricultural worker, your employer does not need to withhold income tax. However, your employer will only withhold income tax if you and your employer agree to do so. In this case, you must provide your employer with a properly completed W-4 form. You can find more information about not withholding taxes at IRS.gov/ForeignAgriculturalWorkers.

Income from employment in the United States is generally exempt from withholding tax. For information on how to claim this exemption, see the section on Income eligible for tax treaty benefits in the text. Wages paid to residents of American Samoa, Canada, Mexico, Puerto Rico, or the U.S. Virgin Islands may be exempt from withholding tax. The following paragraphs describe these exemptions.
The statement may be in any form, but must be dated and signed by the employee, and must include a written statement indicating that the statement is made under the penalty of perjury.

If you are a non-resident foreign employee of the U.S. Virgin Islands or Puerto Rico, then the wages you receive for services provided in the U.S. Virgin Islands or Puerto Rico are generally not subject to withholding, unless you are an employee of a U.S. institution in the U.S. Virgin Islands or Puerto Rico.

Residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands who are not tax law residents of the U.S. are not required to pay U.S. income tax on income earned while working in the U.S. This is because they pay income tax to the U.S. Virgin Islands. To avoid being taxed on income earned in the U.S., U.S. Virgin Islands residents should write a letter to their employer on two copies, stating that they are U.S. Virgin Islands residents and expect to pay all income tax on their income to the U.S. Virgin Islands.

If you receive retirement payments from the United States, they are usually subject to a 30% (or lower treaty) withholding tax rate. However, for part of the retirement payments earned in the United States after 1986, you can withhold tax at the progressive rate. You must complete Form W-8BEN or Form 8233 and submit it to the withholding agent or payer before the payments are made or credited to your account.

If you and the person for whom you provide services do not have an employer-employee relationship, your compensation must be subject to a 30% (or lower treaty) withholding tax rate. However, if you engage in trade or business in the United States during the tax year, if you enter into an agreement with the IRS, your personal services compensation as an independent contractor (independent individual service) may be wholly or partially exempt from the necessary withholding amounts. The agreement between you and the IRS regarding the withholding of amounts from your independent individual service compensation is valid for the amounts agreed upon by both parties. You must agree to file a tax return for the current tax year.

If you are a nonresident alien artist or athlete performing or participating in sports in the United States, you can enter into a central withholding agreement with the IRS to reduce withholding tax if you meet certain requirements. In any case, a central withholding agreement will not reduce withholding tax to less than the expected amount of income tax liability. Use Form 13930 to claim a central withholding agreement for nonresident alien artists or athletes whose total income from U.S. sources for the year is at least $10,000. Form 13930 must be mailed to the following address. Central Withholding Agreement Program Internal Revenue Service 24000 Avila Road, MS 6040 Laguna Niguel, CA 92677 We have temporarily waived the requirement to use a particular form when claiming a central withholding agreement. Currently, Form 13930-A cannot be used. During the waiver period, individuals with income less than $10,000 may use Form 13930 (Instructions for Claiming a Central Withholding Agreement) to claim a central withholding agreement. For more information on how to claim a central withholding agreement, see Form 13930. For more information, go to IRS.gov/Individuals/International-Taxpayers/Central-Withholding-Agreements (in English). The IRS must receive your request for a central withholding agreement at least 45 days before the effective date of the agreement to ensure that it is properly prepared before your trip begins or your first activity occurs. Exceptions will be considered on a case-by-case basis.

If you are satisfied with this information, the Internal Revenue Service will determine the provisional amount of income tax due for the current tax year on the total income from your trade or business in the United States. If the evidence presented is satisfactory to the Commissioner or his representative, ordinary and necessary business expenses may be considered. The Commissioner or his representative will send a letter to you, addressed to your withholding agent, stating the final amount of the tax withheld and the amount that can be paid to you because of the exemption. You must give your withholding agent two copies of the letter and attach them to your income tax return for the tax year in which the exemption is effective. For more information, see Publication 515 (English).

If you are a distributor of a multi-level marketing company and made an error in the withholding tax, you must file a U.S. income tax return (Form 1040-NR or Form 1120-F); or, if you have already filed a tax return, you must file an application for refund (Form 1040-X or Form 1120-F) to recover the amount of the error. You must also attach supporting documentation to your U.S. income tax return or refund application, including but not limited to the following. Form W-2, Form 1042-S, or Form 1099 to show the amount of withholding tax. A statement that the income reported on Form W-2, Form 1042-S, or Form 1099 is not subject to U.S. income tax. A statement of all dates of entry into the United States during the tax year for which the withholding tax was made. If the salary is for more than one year, the statement must list all dates of entry into the United States during each year of the salary. Any document or record that shows the number of days you actually resided in the United States during the tax year(s) listed. A statement that (a) the number of days you spent in the United States on personal services related to recruiting, training, and supporting lower-level distributors was less than one day; and (b) the total number of days you spent on personal services related to recruiting, training, and supporting lower-level distributors was less than one day. Any other supporting documentation or records related to your application for refund of the error in the withholding tax.

Other income subject to 30% withholding tax generally includes fixed or determinable income, such as interest (excluding investment portfolio interest), dividends, pensions and annuities, and certain sales and transaction proceeds, as discussed in Chapter 4 (English). It also includes 85% of social security benefits paid to non-tax-law residents.
The following will introduce the special rules for the withholding tax on partnership income, scholarships and study grants.

If you are a foreign partner in a U.S. or foreign partnership, the partnership will withhold tax on your share of the effective connected earnings (ECE) of the partnership. Your partnership may be able to reduce your ECE share by considering certain partner level deductions. Generally, you must file Form 8804-C for this purpose. For more information, see the instructions for Form 8804-C. Your share of the ECE is generally taxed at the highest rate (37%) under Section 1. However, if you provide the partnership with appropriate documentation, the partnership will withhold tax at the highest rate applicable to the type of income you receive. Long-term capital gains are an example of a type of income for which the highest rate applies. Report the withheld tax as a tax benefit on Form 1040-NR. The partnership will provide you with a statement showing the withheld tax on Form 8805. A partnership with transactions in the public market will withhold tax on the actual distribution of ECE. In this case, the partnership will provide you with a statement on Form 1042-S.

"English": "If you are a U.S. or foreign partnership's direct or indirect foreign partner and you directly or indirectly dispose of the interest income, for transfers after 2017, the transferee generally will withhold and pay to the IRS an amount equal to 10% of the sales proceeds. For amounts in excess of this amount, the withholding and payment rules are similar to the rules for withholding on the sale of U.S. real property. You will receive Form 8288-A, which reflects the withheld amount, and you then may claim the amount as a tax credit on your Form 1040-NR, line 25f. You may be able to provide the transferee with certain information to reduce or eliminate the withholding tax. For example, if the IRS's non-recognition rules apply to the transfer of all of the income, when you provide a notice of the non-recognition rules, the transferee is not required to withhold tax. If you are a transferee who did not withhold tax, the partnership must withhold under section 1446(f)(4) an amount equal to the amount of the partnership interest (except for certain PTP interests) that was not withheld (plus interest, if applicable). Scholarship and Fellowship Income Tax Withholding. See Chapter 3. If you are a nonresident alien student or hold an F, J, M, or Q visa and you receive a scholarship or fellowship that is not fully exempt from tax, the withholding agent (usually the scholarship payor) will withhold 14% (or less under an agreement) of the taxable portion of the scholarship or fellowship as income tax. However, if you are not a degree candidate and the scholarship does not meet certain requirements, it will be withheld at 30% (or less under an agreement) rate. Any portion of the scholarship or fellowship that is treated as a service payment will be withheld on a progressive basis, as discussed in the discussion of Withholding on Wages (English).
You may exclude from income any scholarships or fellowship grants that are not taxable under US law or tax treaty.
If you are a student who qualifies under Section 21(2) of the US-India Income Tax Treaty, you may take the standard deduction. The standard deduction for 2023 is $13,850.

Fill out the appropriate line on the W-4 form. Sign and date the form and give it to your tax withholding agent. If you file a W-4 to reduce or eliminate your scholarship or main course of study tax withholding, you must file a U.S. income tax return to claim any withholding credit reported on the form. If you are a resident in the United States for more than one tax year, you must attach a statement to your W-4 form stating that you have filed a U.S. income tax return for the previous year. If you are a resident in the United States for an insufficient length of time to meet the filing requirements, you must attach a statement to your W-4 form stating that you will file a U.S. income tax return when required. After your tax withholding agent accepts your W-4 form, your scholarship or grant income will be withheld at the applicable progressive tax rate. The total amount of income will be reduced by the amount shown on the W-4 form, and the remaining portion will be calculated as withholding tax. You will receive a Form 1042-S from your tax withholding agent (usually the grantor) showing the total amount of taxable scholarship or grant income less any withholding tax credits, rates, and amounts withheld. Use this form to complete your U.S. income tax return. For more information, go to IRS.gov/FormW4.

If the tax treaty between the United States and your country of residence provides for exemptions or lower tax rates for certain types of income, you should notify the payer of the income (withholding agent) of your foreign status to apply for withholding exemption under the treaty. In general, you can do this by submitting form W-8BEN or form 8233 to the withholding agent. For non-personal service income, submit form W-8BEN. For personal service income discussed below, submit form 8233. If you are eligible for exemption under the treaty but did not submit form 8233 to your withholding agent to apply for withholding exemption, you can still claim the exemption by filing form 1040-NR. Follow the instructions on line 1a of form 1040-NR.

If you are an employee or independent contractor performing personal services and you are eligible for a tax treaty exemption, you must file Form 8233 with the payor of the income. If you file Form 8233, the payor must still withhold tax from the income. This is because the factors on which the exemption is based may not be known until the end of the tax year. In this case, you must file Form 1040-NR to recover any withheld tax and provide the IRS with evidence that you are eligible for the treaty exemption.

Students, teachers, and researchers must attach the appropriate statement shown in Appendix A (for students) (English) or Appendix B (for teachers and researchers) (English) to Form 8233 by the end of the period in which the tax is withheld. For the agreements listed in the appendices, attach a statement in a similar format to the other agreement. If you receive a scholarship or fellowship and personal services income from the same withholding agent, use Form 8233 to apply for tax exemption for both types of income under the tax treaty.

To non-tax law residents or foreign corporations paying for music festivals, boxing promotions, and other entertainment or sports events, ticket revenues (or television or other revenues) need to be withheld at a 30% maximum rate, unless the IRS has otherwise specially notified the withholding tax agent. Depending on the calendar year in which the U.S. total income is earned, you can apply for withholding tax exemption using Form 13930. Even if a tax treaty provides that the income is exempt from tax, withholding tax may still be required. One reason is that exemptions from tax are often based on factors that cannot be determined until after the tax year ends. We have temporarily waived the income requirements for applying for a CWA when using which form. Form 13930-A is currently unavailable. During the exemption period, individuals with income less than $10,000 may use Form 13930 to apply for a CWA. For more information on how to apply for a CWA, see Form 13930. For more information, visit IRS.gov/Individuals/International-Taxpayers/Central-Withholding-Agreements (English). When you leave the United States, you will need to pay U.S. taxes on any income for which you incorrectly applied for an exemption under the agreement. For more information on the withholding tax agreement provisions applicable to wages, see Publication 901 (English).

The buyer must file and pay the withholding tax within 20 days of the transfer using Form 8288. The form with a copy of Form 8288-A, Part A and B, is filed with the IRS. If the statement is complete and includes your tax identification number (TIN), the copy B of the statement will be returned to you (the seller) after the IRS has stamped and approved the statement. You must file copy B with your tax return to receive the withholding tax benefit. If the statement does not include your TIN, you will not receive a stamped copy of Form 8288-A. The IRS will send you a letter requesting your TIN and providing instructions on how to obtain it. When you provide the IRS with your TIN, the IRS will send you a stamped copy of Form 8288-A, Part B.

If you are an employee working in the United States, in most cases, you must pay Social Security and Medicare taxes. Your Social Security tax payments will go toward your Social Security insurance contributions. Social Security insurance provides retirement, survivor, and disability benefits, as well as Medicare health insurance benefits, to individuals who meet certain eligibility requirements. In most cases, you must pay Social Security tax on the first $160,200 of your 2023 income earned in the United States. All taxable income must also be subject to Medicare tax. Your employer will deduct these taxes from each of your paychecks. Even if you do not expect to qualify for Social Security or Medicare benefits, your employer must still deduct these taxes. If you have multiple employers and your total Social Security taxes deducted from your 2023 income exceed $9,932.40, you can claim a tax credit for excess Social Security taxes on your income tax return. If any one employer deducts more than $9,932.40, you cannot claim a credit for that amount. Ask your employer to refund the excess. If your employer does not refund the excess, you can file a refund claim using Form 843. Generally, Social Security and Medicare taxes apply to wages earned as an employee in the United States, regardless of the citizenship or residence of the employee or employer. In limited circumstances, these taxes may apply to wages earned outside the United States. Your employer should be able to tell you whether Social Security and Medicare taxes apply to your wages. If you have no taxes to pay, you cannot make voluntary payments.

For the additional Medicare tax, there are no special provisions for non-tax law-defined residents. Income subject to the Medicare tax, RRTA benefits, and self-employment income that exceed the applicable threshold must be subject to the additional Medicare tax. For calendar year income that exceeds $200,000, your employer must withhold 0.9% (0.009) additional Medicare tax on your salary or RRTA benefits. If you plan to file a joint return and you expect your individual income to be less than $200,000, but your total income and self-employment income will exceed $250,000, you may need to apply for additional withholding and/or pay estimated tax on Form W-4. If you file Form 1040-NR, you must pay the additional Medicare tax if: you are married and your total income and self-employment income exceed $125,000 (you checked the box for married filing separately on page 1 of Form 1040-NR); you are single or a qualified surviving spouse and your total income and self-employment income exceed $200,000 (you checked the box for single or qualified surviving spouse on page 1 of Form 1040-NR). See Form 8959 and its instructions to determine if you must pay the additional Medicare tax. For more information about the additional Medicare tax, go to IRS.gov/ADMTfaqs. Self-employed individuals may also need to pay the additional Medicare tax. See the text on self-employment tax (English).

Generally, as a nonimmigrant under Section 101(a)(15)(F), (J), (M), or (Q) of the Immigration and Nationality Act, your services as a non-tax-law resident (English) in the United States are not covered by the Social Security program if the services are provided to further your purpose of entering the United States. This means that Social Security and Medicare taxes will not be withheld from your salary for these services. These types of services are very limited and generally include on-campus work, practical training, and employment due to economic hardship. If you are considered a tax-law resident (English) under Chapter 1 discussed above, even if your nonimmigrant classification («F-2», «J-2», «M-2», or «Q-3») remains unchanged, Social Security and Medicare taxes will be withheld from your salary for these services. Services provided by the spouse or minor child of a nonimmigrant alien with a «F-2», «J-2», «M-2», or «Q-3» classification are covered by the Social Security program.

If you are a non-tax resident of the United States by virtue of your student status, you are generally not allowed to work for wages or from business activities during your stay in the United States. In certain cases, students who enter the United States as an F-1, M-1, or J-1 nonimmigrant may be eligible to work. Unless the student is considered a tax resident, no Social Security and Medicare taxes will be withheld from wages earned from work. Any student who is enrolled and regularly attending school may be exempt from Social Security and Medicare taxes on wages earned for services provided by the school. The United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) allows F-1 students to work off-campus without replacing a U.S. resident. “Off-campus work” means work performed at a location outside of the school’s campus. Off-campus work includes work performed at an off-campus location that is related to the school’s educational purpose. Working under the terms of a scholarship, fellowship, or teaching assistantship is considered part of a student’s full-time course of study and is permitted by USCIS. Unless the student is considered a tax resident, no Social Security and Medicare taxes will be withheld from wages earned. If the services provided by a non-resident alien student are not considered to be in furtherance of the student’s purpose for entering the United States, unless the wages are exempt from taxation under the Internal Revenue Code, taxes will be withheld from wages earned.

Exchange visitors enter the United States under the provisions of the Immigration and Nationality Act, Section 101(a)(15)(J). Unless the exchange visitor is considered a resident for tax purposes, no Social Security and Medicare taxes will be withheld from the compensation for services rendered by an exchange visitor who has received a work authorization or who has been sponsored by an employer. If the services rendered by the exchange visitor are not considered to be in furtherance of the purpose for which the exchange visitor entered the United States, unless the compensation is exempt from tax under the provisions of the Internal Revenue Code, Social Security and Medicare taxes will be withheld from the compensation. Under the provisions of the Immigration and Nationality Act, Section 101(a)(15)(Q), non-tax-resident participants in an international cultural exchange program may be exempt from Social Security and Medicare taxes. The employer must be a sponsor of a foreign national who has applied for a 'Q' visa. Unless the foreign national is considered a tax-resident, no Social Security and Medicare taxes will be withheld from the compensation for services rendered.

Please send Form 843 (and attachments) to: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Center Ogden, UT 84201-0038 Do not use Form 843 to claim an additional Medicare tax refund. If you were overpaid additional Medicare tax from your payroll, you can claim the overpayment by filing Form 8959 and Form 1040, 1040-SR, or 1040-NR with your tax return. If you were overpaid additional Medicare tax in the prior year and you filed Form 1040, 1040-SR, or 1040-NR, you must file Form 1040-X to claim the overpayment. See the instructions for Form 1040-X.

Foreign agricultural workers who enter the United States on an H-2A visa can earn income from providing services related to the H-2A visa without having Social Security and Medicare taxes withheld. For more information, visit IRS.gov/ForeignAgriculturalWorkers (in English).

The United States has entered into social security agreements (usually called 'Totalization agreements') with foreign countries to coordinate social security insurance and taxes for workers who have worked in one or both countries during their careers. Under these agreements, double insurance and double contributions (taxes) for the same work are eliminated. These agreements usually ensure that social security tax (including self-employment tax) is paid only to one country. For a current list of international social security agreements, go to SSA.gov/international/status.html (English). As these agreements begin to go into effect, they will be posted on this website. For more information about international social security agreements, go to SSA.gov/international/totalization_agreements.html (English).

Generally, under these agreements, you will only be required to pay social security tax in the country where you work. However, if you are temporarily assigned to the United States to work for the same employer and your salary is subject to social security tax in both countries, most agreements provide that you are only entitled to the benefits of the social security system of the country where you were originally assigned. To determine that your salary is only subject to foreign social security tax and is exempt from paying US social security tax (including the Medicare tax), you or your employer should obtain a certificate of coverage from the appropriate foreign agency. This is usually the same agency to which you or your employer pay the foreign social security tax. The foreign agency will be able to tell you what information they need to issue the certificate. Your employer should retain a copy of the certificate because it may be needed to explain why you are exempt from paying US social security tax. Only salary earned after the effective date of the agreement will be exempt from US social security tax.

According to most agreements, self-employed individuals are covered by the social security system of the country in which they reside. However, under certain agreements, if you temporarily move your business activities to the United States or from the United States, you may be exempt from paying United States self-employment taxes. If you believe that your self-employment income is only subject to United States self-employment taxes and is exempt from foreign social security taxes, obtain an insurance certificate from the Social Security Administration. See the link in the notes above. The certificate will determine that you are exempt from paying foreign social security taxes. To determine that your self-employment income is only subject to foreign social security taxes and is exempt from United States self-employment taxes, obtain an insurance certificate from the foreign corresponding institution.

If you did not file a return for 2023, (2) does not apply. Non-tax law residents should use Form 1040-ES (NR) to calculate and pay estimated taxes. If you use a check, write the check to 'United States Treasury'.

If you filed Form 1040-NR for 2023 and expect your income and total deductions to be about the same for 2024, you should use your 2023 return as a guide to fill out the estimated tax work sheet in the instructions for Form 1040-ES (NR). If you did not file a 2023 return or if your income, deductions, or credits will be different in 2024, you must estimate these amounts. Use the tax rate tables in the instructions for Form 1040-ES (NR) that apply to your filing status to calculate your estimated tax liability.

If your tax return is not filed on a calendar year basis, your due date is the 15th day of the 4th, 6th, and 9th months of your fiscal year, and the 1st month of the following fiscal year. If any date is a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday, use the next day (not a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday).

Even if you don't need to pay estimated tax in April or June, your circumstances may change, so you will have to pay estimated tax later. This will happen if you get extra income, or if your deductions decrease or disappear. If this happens, see Form 1040-ES (NR) instructions and Publication 505 (pdf) to learn about how to figure your estimated tax.

If in your estimated tax payments after you find that your estimated tax payments due to changes in income or exemptions are significantly increased or decreased, you should adjust the remaining estimated tax payments. To do this, see the instructions for form 1040-ES (NR) and publication 505 (pdf) (English).

This publication explains the tax treatment of accidents, thefts, and deposit losses. An accident occurs when your property is damaged by a storm, fire, car accident, or similar disaster. A theft occurs when someone steals your property. A deposit loss occurs when your financial institution is insolvent or bankrupt. This publication discusses the following topics. Definitions of accidents, thefts, and deposit losses. How to calculate your income or loss amount. How to handle insurance and other compensation you receive. Deduction limits. When and how to report accidents or thefts. Special rules for disaster areas.

The 584 Form — Personal Use Property Loss Workbook (Personal Use Property) can help you report stolen or damaged personal use property and calculate your loss. This workbook includes schedules to help you calculate losses for your home and its contents and motor vehicles. The 584-B Form — Business Personal Use Property Loss Workbook can help you report stolen or damaged business property or income-producing property and calculate your loss.
