Accidents can be deducted in the tax year in which the loss occurs. This is usually the tax year in which the loss occurs. However, accidents may continue to occur in the year after the accident. See the text in the following What to report income and losses and Table 3.

The three types of losses are all losses attributable to a federal disaster declaration, but each type of loss has different requirements. A federal disaster declaration is a disaster declared by the President of the United States under the Stafford Act, which is a federal law that provides for federal assistance in the event of a disaster. A federal disaster declaration includes (a) a major disaster declaration, or (b) an emergency declaration under the Stafford Act.

Federal accident loss is personal accident or personal use property theft loss caused by a federal declared disaster. The accident must occur in a state where a federal disaster statement has been issued. If you have suffered a federal accident, you are eligible to claim an accident loss deduction. If you have suffered non-federal declared disaster caused personal accident or personal use property theft loss, it does not qualify as federal accident loss, unless an exception applies, in which case you may not claim an accident loss deduction. Theft losses arising from exchanges for profit still qualify. See the warning in the text on Deductible losses for more information.

Disaster losses are those that are attributable to a federal-declared disaster and that occur in a disaster area as defined in the President's declaration. Disaster losses must occur in a county that is eligible for public or individual assistance (or both). Disaster losses are not limited to an individual's personal use property, but may also include an individual's business or income-producing property or property reported by a corporation, S corporation, or partnership as a disaster loss. If you have suffered a disaster loss, you are eligible to claim an accident loss deduction and may elect to report the loss in the previous tax year. See the section on disaster area losses in this publication.

Disaster losses that qualify include personal property losses due to personal use property accidental injury and theft resulting from the following: a president-declared major disaster; Harvey Hurricane; Harvey Tropical Storm; Maria Hurricane; 2017 and 2018 January California wildfires; a president-declared major disaster that occurred on or after January 1, 2018, and continued through January 19, 2020 (except those attributable to the 2018 January California wildfires and for which a deduction was allowed); and a president-declared major disaster, the disaster period of which began on or after January 1, 2020, and ended on or before February 10, 2025. In addition, the disaster period of the disaster must have begun on or after December 28, 2019, and ended on or before December 12, 2024.

If you are a personal taxpayer, personal use property accidental loss in 2018 through 2025 tax years is only deductible when the loss is attributable to a federal declared disaster (federal accident loss). Personal use property does not include business property or income-producing property. If an event causing you to suffer a personal accident (not attributable to a federal declared disaster) occurs before January 1, 2018, but the accident does not continue after January 1, 2018, the accident is not deductible. For more information on when an accident occurs, see When to Report Income and Losses in the text below.

Because the personal accident loss reported under this special provision is not attributed to a federal declared disaster, it can only be deducted up to the amount of your personal accident income. If you suffer property damage as a result of installing certain imported drywall in your home between 2001 and 2009, under the special provision, you can deduct the repair costs incurred to repair your home and household appliances damaged by the corrosive drywall. Under this provision, you will treat the repair costs you pay during the year as a personal accident loss. For example, the repair costs you pay in 2024 can be deducted on your 2024 tax return, and the repair costs you pay in 2023 can be deducted on your 2023 tax return.

If you choose not to follow this special procedure guide, you must follow all the rules applicable to the deduction of accident losses, and you must complete lines 1 through 9 of form 4684 as described. For example, this means you must prove that the damage, destruction, or property loss was caused by the recognizable event defined above in the definition of accident. In addition, you must have evidence showing the following. The loss can be deducted from the tax year in which you file the return, and not in any other year. See the section What to report when you file your return for more information. The amount of the loss you report. See the section Proof of loss for more information. There is no claim for a reasonable recovery of any part of the loss. See the section What to report when you file your return for more information.

Enter the amount you paid to repair damage to your home and household appliances caused by corrosion. Enter only the amount you paid to restore your home to its condition before the damage. Do not enter the amount you paid to repair or add to your home, which increased the value of your home beyond its value before the loss. If you replaced rather than repaired your appliances, enter the lesser of the following two amounts: the current cost of replacing the original appliance, or the base (usually the cost) of the original appliance.

If you have an undecided compensation claim (or you intend to seek compensation), depending on the actual compensation received, you may have income or additional deductions in future tax years. Individuals report losses from capital assets on Schedule A (Form 1040). Businesses and income-producing assets report income and losses from business assets on Form 4797. If you do not need to file Form 4797, you mark the line on your tax return as coming from Form 4797 (for individuals filing Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR, this will be Schedule 1 (Form 1040), line 4) and enter 'Form 4684' next to it. Partnerships and S corporations should see the instructions for Form 4684 to find out where to report these gains and losses.

如果您的企業財產或創收財產發生的損失超過此類財產的收益，請將您的企業意外事故損失與企業和創收財產的總收益相抵。在表格 4797 上將淨收益或損失報告為普通收益或損失。如果您無需提交表格 4797，在您的報稅表上， 只需在確定來自表格 4797 一行輸入淨收益或損失（對於提交表格 1040 或表格 1040-SR 的個人，則為附表1（表格 1040 ）第 4 行）。在該行一旁，輸入「Form 4684 」（表格 4684）。 個人在附表 A（表格 1040）報告創收財產的損失。合夥企業和 S 型企業應參閱表格 4684 以找出在哪里報告這些收益和損失。 如果企業和創收財產的損失小於或等於這些財產的收益，則在表格 4797 報告淨額。依據您是否存在其他交易，您可能還需要在附表 D（表格 1040）報告收益。合夥企業和 S 型企業應參閱表格 4684 以找出在哪里報告這些收益和損失。

If the property that was damaged or stolen is a depreciable property held for more than 1 year, you may have to treat all or part of the gain as ordinary income. You will use Form 4797, Schedule 3, to calculate the ordinary income portion of the gain. See Publication 544, Chapter 3, Depreciation Recapture, for more information about the rules for recapture.

If you have an accident or theft loss, you must reduce your property base by any insurance or other compensation you receive and any deductible you pay. The result is your adjusted base. If you make any of the above base adjustments, the cost of repairs to restore your property to its pre-loss condition will increase your adjusted base. You cannot increase your adjusted base by using any qualified disaster relief amount (discussed in the previous Disaster Loss). See Adjusted Base Amounts in Publication 551 for more information about base adjustments.

If your accident or theft loss deduction amount exceeds your income for the year, you may have an operating loss (OL). Usually, you can use an OL to reduce your tax for a later year. You don't have to have business activity to have an OL from an accident or theft loss. To learn more, see the instructions for Form 172.

If you have tax questions, need help filing your tax return, or want to download free publications, forms, or instructions, visit IRS.gov (English) and find the resources that can help you right away.

After receiving all your wage and income statements (form W-2, form W-2G, form 1099-R, form 1099-MISC, form 1099-NEC, etc.), unemployment compensation statements (mailed or digital format), other government payment statements (form 1099-G), and interest, dividends, and retirement income statements (form 1099) from banks and investment companies, you have several options for filing and submitting your tax return. You can file your taxes yourself, check to see if you qualify for free tax preparation services, or hire a tax professional to do your taxes for you.

You need an IRS online account (OLA) to fill out the forms that require a signature. You can choose to file the forms online or download a copy to mail in. You need your scanned documents to support your filing. Go to IRS.gov/MobileFriendlyForms (English) for more information.

Please visit IRS.gov/Account to securely access information about your federal tax account. Browse your balance due and break it down by tax year. View payment plan details or apply for a new payment plan. Make a payment or view your 5-year payment history and any pending or scheduled payments. Visit your tax records, including key data and tax returns from your most recent filing. View digital copies of IRS-selected notices. Approve or deny tax preparer authorization requests. View your filed address or manage your communication preferences.

Through your online account, you can access a variety of information to help you during tax season. You can obtain copies, view recently filed tax returns, and get adjusted gross income. Go to IRS.gov/Account to set up or access your online account.
This tool allows your tax professionals to submit an authorized request to access your personal tax filer IRS OLA (Online Account). For more information, visit IRS.gov/TaxProAccount.

E-filing your tax return and choosing direct deposit is the safest and easiest way to get your refund. This can safely and electronically transfer your refund directly into your financial account. Direct deposit also avoids the possibility of lost, stolen, damaged, or returned checks that cannot be returned to the IRS. 80% of taxpayers use direct deposit to get their refund. If you don't have a bank account, go to IRS.gov/DirectDeposit to learn more about where to find a bank or credit union that offers online accounts.

View your options for filing and submitting your tax return online or through a local community (if you qualify). Direct File. Direct File is a permanent option to file and submit your personal federal tax return directly, securely, and free online to the IRS. Direct File is a choice for filers with relatively simple tax returns who are filing certain types of income and claiming certain deductions and credits. Although Direct File is not used for state tax returns, if you live in a participating state, Direct File will guide you to use a state-supported tool that can be used to file and submit your state tax return for free. For more information, planning updates, and frequently asked questions, visit IRS.gov/DirectFile (English). Free File. The program allows you to use software or a free tax preparation product to file and submit your federal individual income tax return for free. However, Free File may not be able to provide state tax return filing. Visit IRS.gov/FreeFile to see if you qualify for free online filing, e-filing, and direct deposit or payment options. VITA. The Volunteer Income Tax Education (VITA) program provides free tax assistance to low- and moderate-income individuals, people with disabilities, and those with limited English-speaking ability who need help preparing their tax returns. Visit IRS.gov/VITA, download the free IRS2Go app, or call 800-906-9887 for more information about VITA. TCE. The Tax Counseling for the Elderly (TCE) program provides free tax assistance to all taxpayers, especially those age 60 and older. TCE volunteers specialize in answering questions about retirement-related issues specific to seniors. Visit IRS.gov/TCE, or download the free IRS2Go app, for more information about free tax assistance. MilTax. Members of the U.S. Armed Forces and eligible veterans can use MilTax, a free tax service provided by the Department of Defense through Military OneSource. For more information, visit MilitaryOneSource (English) (MilitaryOneSource.mil/MilTax (English)). Additionally, the IRS provides free fillable forms that can be filed online regardless of income and submitted electronically.

The IRS cannot issue refunds to taxpayers who have filed tax returns claiming the EITC or the additional child tax credit (ACTC) before mid-February. This applies to the entire refund, not just the portion related to these tax benefits.

U.S. tax payments must be made in U.S. dollars to the IRS. We do not accept cryptocurrency. Visit IRS.gov/Payments to learn about using any of the following methods to make your payment. IRS Direct Pay: Pay your personal tax bill or estimated tax from your checking or savings account without additional fees. Debit card, credit card, or digital wallet: Choose an approved payment processor and pay online or by phone. Electronic Funds Transfer (EFT): Provide payment instructions when filing your federal tax return using tax software or through a tax professional. Electronic Federal Tax Payment System (EFTPS): This is the best option for businesses. You must register. Check or money order: Mail your payment to the address listed on your notice or instruction. Cash: You can pay your taxes in cash at participating retail stores. Wire transfer: You may be able to make a same-day wire transfer from your financial institution. Contact your financial institution to learn about feasibility, fees, and timeframes.

Please visit IRS.gov/Payments to learn more about your options. Apply for an Online Payment Agreement (IRS.gov/OPA) to make monthly payments to meet your tax obligations (if you cannot pay your tax bill in full today). You will immediately receive a notice after you complete the online process letting you know whether your agreement has been approved. Use the Online Payment Agreement Eligibility Pre-Screening Tool (English) to see if you may be able to settle your tax debt for less than the amount you owe. For more information about the Online Payment Agreement, visit IRS.gov/OIC.

Please visit IRS.gov/WMAR to track the status of your amended 1040-X tax return. It may take up to 3 weeks from the date you file your amended return for it to appear in our system, and it may take up to 16 weeks to process your return.

The Taxpayer Advocacy Service (TAS) is an independent organization within the IRS that helps taxpayers resolve problems with the IRS, makes administrative and legislative recommendations to prevent or correct problems, and protects taxpayers' rights. We strive to ensure that every taxpayer is treated fairly and that you know and understand your rights under the Taxpayer Bill of Rights. We are your voice at the IRS.

TAS can help you resolve problems you can't solve on your own with the IRS. Be sure to try to solve your problem with the IRS first, but if you can't, go to TAS. Our service is free. TAS helps all taxpayers (and their representatives), including individuals, businesses, and tax-exempt organizations. If your IRS problem results in financial difficulty, if you have tried but cannot solve your problem with the IRS, or if you think the IRS system, processes, or procedures are not working properly, you may be eligible for TAS assistance. To get help with general tax topics at any time, visit www.TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov (English). That website can help you with common tax problems and situations, such as what to do if you made a mistake on your tax return or if you received a notice from the IRS. TAS is committed to solving large-scale (systemic) problems that affect many taxpayers. You can report system problems at www.IRS.gov/SAMS. (Please do not include any personal identifying information.)

The Taxpayer Rights Act describes the 10 basic rights of all taxpayers when dealing with the Internal Revenue Service. Visit www.TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov/Taxpayer-Rights (English) to learn more about these rights, what they mean to you, and how they apply to specific IRS situations you may encounter. TAS is committed to protecting taxpayer rights and ensuring IRS implements the tax code fairly and impartially.

Although the tax preparer will sign the tax return, you are ultimately responsible for providing all the information necessary for the tax preparer to prepare the tax return and for the accuracy of each item reported on the tax return. Any person who prepares a tax return for another person should have a comprehensive understanding of tax issues. For more information on how to choose a tax preparer, visit IRS.gov's Choose a Tax Preparer Tips.

The Social Security Administration (SSA) offers online services for registered accountants, certified public accountants, registered tax preparers, and individuals who prepare and file Form W-2, W-2c, and tax returns at SSA.gov/employer (English). These services provide a fast, free, and secure option for filing Form W-2, W-2c, and tax returns.

If you are a sole proprietor, partnership, or S corporation, you can view tax information on your IRS account and perform more operations using the Business Tax Account. Go to IRS.gov/businessaccount for more information.

The IRS is committed to serving limited English proficient (LEP) taxpayers through the OPI service. OPI service is a federally funded program that is available at Taxpayer Assistance Centers (TACs), most IRS offices, and at every VITA/TCE tax site. OPI service is available in over 350 languages.
If it is illegal under state or local law to obtain money or property by fraud or false representation, then the act is theft.

In tax years 2018 to 2025, if you are a personal taxpayer, only losses attributable to federal declared disasters (federal accident losses) are deductible for personal use property. If you have personal accident income, the deduction for personal accident and theft losses is only applicable to the exception to the rules for federal accident losses. In this case, you can deduct personal accident losses that are not part of a federal declared disaster, provided that the deduction does not exceed your personal accident income.

If the stock is purchased on the open market and the stock value declines because of accounting fraud or senior executives or directors involved in other illegal or improper conduct, you cannot deduct the stock's value as a theft loss. However, if the stock is sold or exchanged or becomes totally worthless, you can deduct it as a capital loss on Schedule D (Form 1040). For more information about stock sales, worthless stock, and capital losses, see IRS Publication 550, Chapter 4.

Money or property that simply disappears is not theft. However, if the accidental loss or disappearance of property is caused by a sudden, unexpected, or unusual recognizable event, it can be considered an accident. In the above text, an accidental event, an unexpected event, and an unusual event are defined as an accident.

If you are eligible to use the Tax Procedure Guide 2011-58 as modified by Tax Procedure Guide 2009-20 and you choose to follow the procedures in that guide, first complete Schedule 4684, Part C, to determine the amount to be entered in line 28 of Part B. Skip lines 19 through 27, but you must complete lines 29 through 39 of Part B as needed. Schedule 4684, Part C, replaces Appendix A of Tax Procedure Guide 2009-20. You do not need to complete Appendix A. For more information, see the above Tax Rulings and Tax Procedure Guides and the instructions for Schedule 4684. If you choose not to use the Tax Procedure Guide 2011-58 as modified by Tax Procedure Guide 2009-20, you can report the theft loss (as applicable) by completing lines 19 through 39 of Part B. Note that the personal use property limits do not apply to losses of income-producing property, such as losses from a Ponzi scheme investment plan, for 2018 through 2025 tax years.
You cannot claim any other miscellaneous itemized deductions, including ordinary losses from deposits in financial institutions that are insolvent or bankrupt.

You can elect to deduct deposit losses as accident losses in any year, provided you can reasonably estimate how much of that year's deposits you lost in a financially insolvent or bankrupt financial institution. Typically, you make the election on your tax return for that year, and the election applies to all deposit losses in that financial institution for that year. If you elect to treat the loss as an accident loss, you cannot deduct an equivalent amount as a nonbusiness bad debt when the loss becomes worthless. However, you can deduct any amount in excess of the amount you elect to deduct as an accident or ordinary loss as a nonbusiness bad debt. Once you make an election, you cannot change it without the IRS's permission.

If you are a personal taxpayer, personal use property casualty losses are only deductible if the loss is attributable to a federal declared disaster. If you have personal casualty and theft gains, then the personal casualty and theft loss limitation rules for federal casualty losses will apply. Since deposit losses are not attributable to a federal declared disaster, you can deduct deposit losses as personal casualty losses, provided that the losses do not exceed your personal casualty gains.

If you recover any amount previously taken as a deduction for losses, you may have to include the recovered amount in your income for the year in which you recovered it. If any part of the original deduction did not reduce your tax for the previous year, you do not have to include the recovered amount in your income. For more information, see the content of Recovery of Deductions in Publication 525.
If you want to deduct losses from accidents or theft, you must be able to prove that an accident or theft occurred. You must also be able to support the amount you deduct.
If you want to determine your deduction for an accident or theft loss, you must first calculate your loss.

If you receive insurance compensation or other types of compensation, you must subtract that amount from your loss when calculating the loss. You have not suffered an accident or theft loss in the range of funds you receive. If you file a claim in the year of the accident and there is a reasonable prospect of compensation, in the range of funds you reasonably determine you will receive such compensation, the loss has not occurred. If you expect to receive all or part of the loss as compensation, you must subtract the expected compensation from the loss. Even if you do not receive the funds until the next tax year, you must reduce the loss amount. See the section on Deducting compensation received after the loss in the previous text.

If your property is insured, you should file a claim with your insurance company in a timely manner for your loss. If you do not file a claim, you cannot deduct the full amount of the unrecovered amount as an accident or theft loss, you can only deduct that portion of the loss that is not covered by the policy. Generally, non-covered portions (such as deductibles) are not subject to this rule.

If you receive funds from your employer's emergency disaster fund and you must use the money to repair or replace property that you claimed as a loss on your accident loss deduction, you must include the money in your calculation of the accident loss deduction. You must only include the amount you use to replace the damaged or destroyed property.

If you as a disaster victim received cash gifts that are not included in your income, and you have no restrictions on how you use this money, you do not have to deduct these non-income cash gifts from your disaster losses. Even if you use this money to pay for repairs to property damaged in the disaster, it still applies.

In the year you can again use the principal residence, include the taxable portion of the insurance proceeds in your income, or later, include the taxable portion of the insurance proceeds in your income for the year you receive the insurance proceeds.

If you use the expected amount of compensation to calculate your loss from an accident or theft, you may need to adjust your tax return for the tax year in which you actually receive the compensation. This section describes the adjustments you may need to make. If you paid for repairs that deteriorated the concrete foundation of your personal residence, and claimed a deduction on your original or amended federal individual income tax return for the repairs, and the Connecticut Foundation Solutions Indemnity Company (CFSIC) paid you (or the contractor representing you) some or all of the payment, you must include some or all of the payment in your gross income. See Announcement 2020-5, 2020-19 I.R.B. 796 (available at IRS.gov/irb/2020-19IRB#ANN-2020-5 (English)).

If the amount of compensation you later receive exceeds your expectation, you may need to include the extra amount in your gross income in the year you receive the extra amount after you claim the loss deduction. However, if any part of the original deduction amount did not reduce your tax for the prior year, do not include that part of the compensation amount in your gross income. You do not need to recalculate your tax for the year you claimed the deduction. See Publication 525, Tax Guide for Estate and Gift Tax and Estate and Gift Tax Return Preparers, at page 15 to see how much extra compensation amount to include in your gross income.
If the amount of compensation you receive in the future exactly matches your expectations, you do not have to include any compensation in your income, nor can you deduct any additional losses.

You can deduct losses from accidents or theft of inventory, including items you hold for sale to customers, in two ways. One way is to deduct the losses by properly reporting your beginning and ending inventory, by increasing the cost of goods sold to deduct the losses. Do not report this loss again as an accident or theft loss. If you suffer a loss due to the increase in cost of goods sold, include any insurance or other compensation you receive in total income. The other way is to deduct the loss individually. If you deduct the loss individually, then adjust your beginning inventory or purchases downward and deduct the affected inventory items from the cost of goods sold. Deduct the loss by the amount of the compensation you receive. Do not include the compensation in total income. If you do not receive the compensation before the end of the year, in the event you have a reasonable expectation of receiving the compensation, you may not claim the loss.

If you are liable for damage to the property you rent due to an accident, your loss is the amount you must pay to repair the property minus any insurance or other compensation you receive or expect to receive.

Generally, if one accident or theft involves more than one property, you must calculate the loss of each property separately. Then combine these losses to determine the total loss caused by the accident or theft.

Fair market value (FMV) is the price at which a willing seller would sell and a willing buyer would buy an asset in an open and orderly market. For purposes of determining the amount of any loss due to an accident or theft, the decrease in FMV is the difference between the FMV of the property immediately before and immediately after the accident or theft.
The fair market value of property after theft is immediately considered to be zero, because you no longer own the property.

In order to calculate the fair market value decline due to an accident or theft, you usually need a full appraisal. However, you can also use other methods to confirm some value declines. See the sections on  Valuation, Cleaning or Repair Costs, and  Special Rules — Safe Harbor for Accident and Theft Losses for more information.

You can use the appraised value of your property that you used to obtain a federal loan (or a federal loan guarantee) because of the disaster to determine the amount of your disaster loss. For more information about the disaster, see Disaster Loss.

Books published by various car organizations that list car manufacturers and models may help calculate the value of your car. You can use the retail value of the car listed in the book, and adjust it by factors such as mileage and condition of the car, to determine the value of your car. These prices are not official, but they may help determine value and suggest relative prices so you can compare with current sales and models in your area. If your car is not listed in the book, determine its value from other sources. The trade-in value quoted by a dealer for your car is usually not a good measure of its true value.

If you want to calculate the amount of your accidental loss and theft, you usually have to use a qualified appraisal or your actual repair costs to determine the actual reduction in the fair market value of the property lost or damaged. However, the Tax Procedure Guide 2018-08, 2018-2 I.R.B.286 special safe harbor method allows you to determine the fair market value reduction in another way. If you are a personal taxpayer, only when the loss is attributable to a federal declared disaster, may you deduct personal use property accidental loss and theft. If you have personal accident income, the deduction for personal accidental loss and theft is only applicable to the exception to the federal accident loss rules. In this case, you may deduct personal accidental loss that is not attributable to a federal declared disaster, provided that the deduction does not exceed your personal accident income.

Tax Procedure Guide 2018-08, 2018-2 I.R.B. 286 (available at IRS.gov/irb/2018-02_IRB#RP-2018-08 (English) ) provided a safe harbor method, you can use these methods to calculate the amount of your personal residential real property and personal property that was damaged by an accident or stolen. If you qualify for and use the safe harbor method described in Tax Procedure Guide 2018-08, the IRS will not question your determination. Using the safe harbor method described in Tax Procedure Guide 2018-08 is not mandatory.

The Federal Disaster Replacement Cost Safe Harbor method allows you to determine the fair market value of your personal property located in a disaster area before the disaster occurred, to calculate the amount of your casualty or theft loss. To use the replacement cost safe harbor method, you must first determine the cost of replacing your current personal property with new property, and then reduce that amount by 10% for each year you own the property. See the Personal Property Valuation Table in Tax Procedure Guide 2018-08. Except for the specific exceptions named in Tax Procedure Guide 2018-08, if you choose to use the replacement cost safe harbor method, you must use it for all of your personal property. Each of these safe harbor methods is subject to other rules and exceptions. For more information, see Tax Procedure Guide 2018-08.

Any losses determined by the safe harbor method must be reduced by the value of any repairs provided to you by a third party (e.g., work done by volunteers or work done by donations). In addition, any insurance, indemnity, or other compensation you receive must be deducted from your losses.

Please attach a statement to Form 4684 showing the amount of your casualty loss determined using Tax Guide 2018-08. Include the specific safe harbor method used. When completing Form 4684, do not enter the amount in the fifth line or sixth line for each property. Instead, enter the amount determined under the applicable safe harbor method in the seventh line. For losses from Harvey, Irma, and Maria, see Tax Guide 2018-09, 2018-2 I.R.B. 290, to learn about the cost index safe harbor method.

Personal-use residential real property is typically real property owned by an individual that is damaged by an accident, including improvements, and that contains at least one personal residence. If any part of a personal residence is used as a rental property or includes a family office used for trade or business or for a profit-making transaction, it is not included in personal residence. For more information, see Tax Procedure Guide 2018-08. The following are the safe-harbor methods for personal-use residential real property provided by Tax Procedure Guide 2018-08. Estimate repair cost method. Minimum method. Insurance method. Federal disaster declaration — contractor safe-harbor. Federal disaster declaration — disaster loan valuation.

The cost of repairs safe harbor method allows you to use the smaller of two repair estimates prepared by individual and independent licensed contractors to calculate the amount of decrease in the fair market value of your personal use residential real property. The estimate must itemize the cost of restoring your property to its pre-accident condition. The cost of repairs safe harbor method is limited to losses of $20,000 or less from an accident.

The minimum safe harbor method allows you to calculate the amount of decrease in the fair market value of your personal use residential real property by estimating the cost of repairs needed to restore your property to its condition before the accident occurred. You must keep records showing how you estimated the amount of loss. The minimum safe harbor method applies to losses of $5,000 or less from an accident.

The insurance safe harbor method allows you to calculate the amount of the decrease in the fair market value of your personal residential real estate based on the estimates of loss described in the reports prepared by the owner or flood insurance company. These reports must list the estimated loss you suffered due to property damage or destruction.

If the loss occurs in a disaster area and is caused by a federal disaster declaration, you can use the contractor safe harbor method or the disaster loan assessment method. Under the contractor safe harbor method, you can use the repair contract price specified in the contract prepared by an independent and licensed contractor to determine the amount of the decrease in the fair market value of your personal use residential real estate. Unless you are bound by a contract you and the contractor have signed and the contractor has specified the itemized costs of restoring your personal use residential real estate to its pre-loss condition, the safe harbor method does not apply to you.

In the Disaster Loan Assessment Safe Harbor method, you can use a prepared assessment of your estimated loss in a federal disaster to determine the amount of the decrease in the fair market value of your principal residence. You can use a prepared assessment of your estimated loss in a federal disaster to determine the amount of the decrease in the fair market value of your principal residence.

Personal property generally includes tangible personal property owned by an individual and not used in trade or business. Personal property does not include items that retain or increase in value over time or certain other types of property. For more information, see Tax Procedure Guide 2018-08. The personal property safe harbor method is the minimum federal disaster declaration amount and the replacement cost safe harbor method.

The cost of protecting your property from accidents or theft is not part of the loss from accidents or theft. The amount you spend on insurance or to protect your home from storms is not part of your loss. If the property is business property, these costs can be deducted as business expenses. If you make permanent improvements to your property to protect it from accidents or theft, add the cost of these improvements to the base amount of your property. An example of this is the cost of a flood-prevention levee.

Accidental or theft-related expenses, such as medical treatment for personal injury, temporary housing, or rental car costs, are not part of your accidental injury or theft loss. However, if the damaged or stolen property is corporate property, it can be deducted as a business expense.
The cost of replacing stolen or damaged property is not part of the loss by theft or accident.

Photographs taken after an incident will help to show the condition and value of the property after damage. Photos showing the condition of the property after repairs, repairs or replacements may also be helpful. Valuation is used to calculate the fair market value decrease caused by an accident or theft. For information on valuation, see the previous section Valuation, which is included in Calculating the decrease in fair market value — Items to consider. Photos and valuation costs of property damaged by an accident are not included in the loss. They are costs used to determine your tax obligations. From 2018 to 2025 tax years, they can no longer be claimed as a miscellaneous deduction.

If you inherited property from someone who died in 2010 and the executor of the deceased's estate made an election under section 1022, the special rules for the basis of the property will apply. The executor of the deceased's estate may elect to treat the property as being transferred to the estate by the deceased at the adjusted basis. For more information about the election under section 1022, see Notice 2011-66, 2011-35 I.R.B. 184, available at IRS.gov/irb/2011-35IRB#NOT-2011-66 (English). For more information about the safe harbor election under section 1022, see Tax Procedure Guide 2011-41, 2011-35 I.R.B. 188, available at IRS.gov/irb/2011-35IRB#RP-2011-41 (English).

When you have property, there may be various events that change your base amount. Events such as additions to property or permanent improvements will increase the base amount. The aforementioned events of accidents and depreciation deductions, etc. will decrease the base amount. After you add the upward amount to the base amount or subtract the downward amount from the base amount, the result is your adjusted base amount. Please refer to the previous text of the 551th edition for more information on calculating your property's base amount.

In the event that you calculate the amount of your accidental injury or theft loss, you must calculate the amount of loss that you can deduct. The deduction for accidental injury and theft loss of personal property is limited. For tax years 2018 through 2025, personal accidental injury and theft loss is only deductible within the scope of a federally declared disaster. Personal accidental injury and theft loss resulting from a federally declared disaster is subject to the $100 and 10% rule, discussed in more detail below. The $100 and 10% rule is also organized in Table 2. The limitations on the deduction for personal accidental injury and theft loss resulting from a federally declared disaster apply in the event that you have a personal accidental injury gain in the current tax year. In this case, you can reduce your personal accidental injury gain by any accidental injury loss that is not due to a federally declared disaster. Use any excess gain to reduce the loss due to a federally declared disaster. The 10% rule applies to any federal disaster loss. The loss of business or rental property is not subject to these rules. However, if your accidental injury loss or theft loss involves a house used for business or rental, your deductible loss may be limited. Please refer to Section 4684 of the instructions. If accidental injury loss or theft loss involves property used in a passive activity, please refer to Section 8582 of the instructions and its instructions.

After you calculate your personal use property's accident or theft loss, (as discussed below), you must subtract $100 from the loss. This deduction applies to each total accident or theft loss, including those not resulting from a federal government-declared disaster, to reduce your personal accident income losses. The number of properties involved in an event is irrelevant. Only subtract $100.
If you have more than one accident or theft loss in your tax year, you must deduct $100 from each loss.
If two or more individuals (excluding spouses who file joint tax returns) are involved in the same accident or theft, the $100 rule applies to each individual.

If you and your spouse file a joint tax return, you are considered one person when you use the $100 rule. Whether you jointly or separately own property is irrelevant. If you and your spouse suffer a loss of property due to an accident or theft, you file separate tax returns, you must each deduct $100 from the loss. Even if you jointly own property, this is the case. If one spouse owns property, only that spouse can claim the loss deduction on a separate tax return. If you completely own property as a tenant, you can each calculate only half of the loss deduction on a separate tax return. You cannot calculate the full loss deduction on a separate tax return. You must each deduct $100 from the loss.

If two or more individuals (excluding spouses who file joint tax returns) jointly own property that is damaged, the $100 rule applies to each individual. For example, if two sisters live together in a jointly owned house, the $100 rule applies to each sister if the house is damaged in an accident.

If you have more than one accident or theft loss in your tax year, subtract any compensation and $100 from each loss. Then, you must subtract 10% of your adjusted gross income (AGI) from your total federal accident loss.

If you and your spouse file a joint tax return, you are treated as one person. Whether you jointly or separately own property is irrelevant. If you file separate returns, the 10% rule applies to each return that claims a loss.
If property held jointly by two or more individuals (excluding spouses filing a joint tax return) suffers a loss, the 10% rule applies to each individual.

If you have accident or theft gains and losses and losses of personal use property, you must compare the total gains and total losses. In making this comparison, subtract from each loss any compensation and $100, and then subtract from this total the total federal accident loss before you subtract 10% of your adjusted gross income (AGI). Accident or theft gains and losses do not include any income you choose to defer reporting. See Deferral of Income below.

If your losses exceed your confirmed gains, subtract the gains from the losses and subtract the result from your adjusted gross income (AGI) by 10%. The remaining (if any) is your personal use property loss deduction. If your losses are not due to a federal government-declared disaster, see line 14 of the instructions for Form 4684. Non-disaster losses can only be used to offset gains. If you suffered a qualified disaster loss, see line 15 of the instructions for Form 4684 for details.

If you have more income than losses, subtract your losses from your income. The difference is treated as a capital gain and must be reported on Schedule D (Form 1040). The 10% rule does not apply to your income. If your losses are not from a federal government-declared disaster, see the instructions for line 14 in the instructions for Form 4684.

Property used for personal purposes and property used for business or income-generating purposes are treated separately for the purpose of determining the amount of loss or theft that may be deducted. You must calculate each loss separately because losses attributable to each use are calculated differently. When calculating each loss, you must allocate the total cost or base amount, the fair market value before and after the loss, and the insurance or other compensation received for the business and personal use of the property. The 100-dollar rule and the 10-percent rule apply only to losses of property used for personal purposes.

If you receive income from the destruction of your principal residence, you can generally deduct that income from your income, just as you would if you sold or bought a house. You can deduct up to $250,000 (up to $500,000 if you file a joint return) of the income. To deduct the income, you generally must have owned the residence for at least 5 years before it was destroyed and have lived in it as your principal residence for at least 2 years. For more information, see Publication 523. If you have income that exceeds the amount you can deduct, but you buy replacement property, you can defer reporting the excess income. See Deferring Income below.

Generally, you must report your compensation income for the year you receive it. However, if you meet certain requirements and choose to defer reporting the income based on the rules explained in Deferring Income, you do not have to report the income. To learn how to report income, see How to Report Income. If you have other personal-use property accident or theft losses (explained below) in addition to the personal-use property accident or theft losses you choose to defer reporting, when you calculate your accident or theft loss deduction amount, you do not consider the income you defer reporting. See the 10% rule, which is explained in the limits section above.

If you receive property similar to or in the same service or use as the stolen or damaged property as compensation, do not report the gain. Your new property's base is usually the same as the adjusted base of the property it replaces. If you receive money or other property as compensation, you generally must report the gain from the stolen or damaged property. However, if you purchase property similar to or in the same service or use as the stolen or damaged property within the specified replacement period, you can choose to defer reporting the gain, discussed below. If you purchase the controlling interest (at least 80%) in a company that owns property similar to or in the same service or use as the stolen or damaged property, you can also choose to defer reporting the gain. See Controlling interest in a corporation. If you have gain from damaged property, you can defer reporting the gain as long as you restore the property to its original condition with the compensation. To defer reporting all the gain, your cost of replacing the property must be at least equal to the amount of the compensation. If the cost of replacing the property is less than the amount of the compensation, you must include the gain in your income, but only to the extent of the unused compensation.

Regarding the accidents and thefts described in (3) above, any losses cannot be offset against the gross income in determining whether the gross income exceeds $100,000. If the property is owned by a partnership, the $100,000 limit applies to the partnership and each partner. If the property is owned by an S corporation, the $100,000 limit applies to the S corporation and each shareholder.

If a taxpayer dies after receiving income but before purchasing an alternative asset, the income must be reported in the year the taxpayer realized the income. The executor of a will or a person who receives funds from an accident or theft cannot delay filing the income by purchasing an alternative asset.

If the compensation you receive for a destroyed principal residence exceeds the amount you can exclude from your income (see Principal Residence destroyed, which is discussed in the Calculating income section above), you can defer reporting excess income by purchasing an alternative property that is similar or related in service or use. If you defer reporting all of your excess income, the cost of the alternative property must be at least equal to the amount you received for the destruction, minus the amount of income excluded. In addition, if you defer reporting any part of your income under these rules, you will be treated as having owned and used the alternative property as your principal residence during the period you owned and used the destroyed property as your principal residence.

If two or more properties are of the same class, the reduction is allocated to each property in proportion to the adjusted base of all properties in that class. The base of any single property's reduction cannot be less than zero.

If you want to postpone reporting your income, you must purchase alternative property within the specified time period. This is the replacement period. The replacement period begins on the date of your property's damage, destruction, or theft. The replacement period usually ends two years after the first tax year in which you realize any part of the income.

For principal residences (or personal property within a principal residence) located in a declared disaster area, the replacement period generally ends after the first tax year in which you realize any part of the gain. See the section on disaster losses in this publication.

Your request must include all the details of why you need the extension. Include: 1. The name, address, and taxpayer identification number of the taxpayer, 2. A detailed description of the property being exchanged, 3. The date the property was exchanged, 4. The adjusted basis of the property being exchanged, 5. The date and amount of payment received, 6. Copies of the tax returns that contain the non-voluntary exchange of property income and related income deferral, and 7. A description of the action taken in connection with the exchange of property.

You can delay reporting your income from an accident or theft by choosing to report it on your tax return in the year you receive the insurance payout or other compensation that creates the income. If the stolen or damaged property is owned by a partnership or corporation, only the partnership or corporation can choose to delay reporting the income.

You should attach a statement to your tax return for the year you received the income. The statement should include the following. Date and details of the accident or theft. Any insurance compensation or other compensation you received from the accident or theft. How you calculated the income.

If you purchased an alternative asset before filing your tax return in the year you received the income, your return should also include detailed information on the following. Alternative asset. Deferred income. Adjusted basis reflecting deferred income. Any income you report as income.

Once you have acquired an eligible alternative property specified as an alternative property in the statement attached to the tax return, you cannot replace other eligible alternative property. Even if you acquire other property during the replacement period, this also applies. However, if you find that the original alternative property is not an eligible alternative property, you can (within the replacement period) replace a new eligible alternative property.

In either of the following situations, you must file an amended return (form 1040-X) for the tax year in which you received the income. You did not receive alternative property within the required replacement period and extension period. In the amended return, you must report the income and pay any additional tax due. You received alternative property within the required replacement period and extension period, but the cost was less than the amount you received from the accident or theft. In the amended return, you must report the non-deferred portion of the income and pay any additional tax due.

If the insurance or other compensation you receive exceeds your adjusted basis in your destroyed or stolen property, you will have a gain from the accident or theft. You must include this gain in your income for the year you receive the compensation, unless you choose to defer reporting the gain, as discussed earlier.

Generally, you can only deduct the loss of property that was not compensated for in the tax year in which the accident occurred. Even if you do not repair or replace the damaged property until the following year, this is also true. (However, please see the exception in the following text for the loss of disaster area.) You can only deduct the loss of theft in the year in which you discover the theft of the property. If there is a reasonable expectation of compensation in the year in which the accident occurred, the loss has not been established until you have reasonably determined that you will receive such compensation. If you are unsure whether part of your accident or theft loss will be compensated, do not deduct that part of the loss until you have reasonably determined that you will receive compensation in the tax year in which the loss was established. The later tax year is the year in which the loss was established.
If your loss is due to a financial institution that is unable to repay or bankrupt, please refer to the previous text on deposit losses.

If you rent property from others, you can deduct the loss of that property in the year in which you determine the liability for the loss. Even if the loss occurs in a different year or the year in which you fulfill your obligation to make a claim is different, this is still true. You are not entitled to a deduction until your obligation under the lease can be determined with reasonable accuracy. Your obligation can be determined when the claim is settled, adjudicated or abandoned.

This section discusses special rules for losses declared by the federal government. It contains information on when you can deduct losses, how to file a claim, how to handle your home in the disaster area, and which tax deadlines can be extended. It also lists the phone numbers for the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA). (See the contact information for the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) in the text below.) Disaster losses are losses that occur in a disaster area declared by the President of the United States under the Stafford Act, which can be attributed to a disaster declared by the federal government. A disaster area includes a place that requires public or private assistance (or both). A federal disaster declaration includes a major disaster or an emergency declaration. The list of areas that require public or private assistance (or both) under the Stafford Act can be found at FEMA.gov/Disasters (English).

If you are reporting an accidental injury or theft resulting from a federally declared disaster, check this box and enter the FEMA Disaster Declaration Number (DR or EM) provided on the 2024 Form 4684, line 1 above the blank space provided. The list of federally declared disasters and the FEMA Disaster Declaration Numbers can be found at FEMA.gov/Disasters (English). The FEMA Disaster Declaration Number consists of the letters “DR” and four digits or the letters “EM” and four digits. For example, for the tornado in Tennessee, enter “DR-4832” in the corresponding input box.

Your home is only considered unsafe when both of the following conditions are true. After a disaster, your home is more dangerous than before the disaster. The danger comes from the greatly increased risk of future disasters causing damage.

When you elect to deduct losses in the year before the disaster, unless you have a qualified disaster loss as discussed above, you must calculate the loss as if it occurred in the year before the disaster.

You should adjust your deductions on Form 1040-X. The instructions for Form 1040-X show how to do this. Explain the reason for the adjustment and attach Form 4684 to show how you calculated your loss. See the discussion of Calculating Losses in this chapter. If the property damaged or destroyed is nonbusiness property and you did not list the deduction on your original return line by line, you must first determine whether the loss deduction from an accidental loss is favorable to you. If the loss deduction from an accidental loss and any other line item deductions total more than your standard deduction, listing line item deductions is favorable. If you list line item deductions, attach Schedule A (Form 1040) or Schedule A (Form 1040-NR), and Form 4684 to your modified return. File Form 1040-X to recalculate your tax to arrive at your refund amount.

If you have a copy of your tax return from last year, filling out Form 1040-X will be easier. If your tax return was prepared by a tax preparer, he or she should be able to provide you with a copy of your tax return. If not, you can obtain a copy by submitting Form 4506 to the IRS. Each request for a tax return requires a fee. However, if your principal place of residence, principal place of business, or tax home is located in a federal disaster area, the fee will be waived. Write the name of the disaster (for example, 'Tennessee Tropical Storm Helene') in the blank space at the top of Form 4506.

If your inventory loss qualifies as an accidental loss and is due to a disaster that occurred in a public or private assistance (or both) area designated by the Federal Emergency Management Agency, you may choose to deduct the loss on your tax return for the year in which the loss occurred. However, reduce the loss by the beginning-of-year inventory when reporting the loss again in inventory.
If your portion of the federal disaster loan is forgiven under the Stafford Act, it is considered compensation for the loss. The forgiveness will reduce your loss of accident deduction.

If disaster relief grants received under the Stafford Act are used to help you meet the necessary expenses or severe needs for medical, dental, housing, personal property, transportation, or burial expenses, do not include them in your income. Do not deduct these disaster relief grants as compensation for an accident loss or medical expenses. If an accident loss is specially compensated by the grant, and you receive the grant after deducting the accident loss in the year following the accident, see the discussion of compensation received after deducting losses in the preceding section. Unemployment compensation under the Stafford Act is taxable unemployment relief.

Companies that receive and use grants from state plans to compensate for property damage or destruction caused by disasters are not allowed to treat the grants as general benefits, gifts, or qualified disaster relief (discussed below), or as an investment in capital from which income is excluded. However, if a company purchases eligible replacement property within a specified period, the company may elect to defer reporting the income realized from the grant. Please refer to the section on Deferring Income for more information on the applicable rules.

The eligible disaster assistance also includes amounts paid by the federal, state, or local government to individuals affected by the declared disaster. These amounts must be paid from government funds, based on the need of the individual or family, rather than on the basis of service rendered. Assistance provided to businesses is generally not eligible.

Under the Stafford Act or the National Flood Insurance Act (effective April 15, 2005), eligible disaster relief payments are not included in income. These are payments you receive as a property owner to reduce the risk of damage to your property in the future. After using these payments, you cannot increase your property base by using them, nor can you claim a deduction or credit.

Generally, if you sell or otherwise dispose of property, unless the property is your principal residence, you must report any gain or loss for tax purposes. You report the gain or deduct the loss on your tax return for the year in which you realize the gain or loss. (You cannot deduct a loss from the sale of personal-use property, unless the loss is from an accidental event, as described above.) However, if you dispose of property by disaster relief sale to a federal, state, or local government or Indian tribal government, and you purchase a qualifying replacement property within a specified time, you may be able to defer reporting the gain for a specified period. See the discussion of  deferred gain  in this chapter for the rules that apply.

The IRS may defer the filing deadlines for specific taxes for taxpayers affected by a federally declared disaster. The IRS may defer filing deadlines for filing income tax, business tax, and employment tax returns, paying income tax, business tax, and employment tax, and making contributions to traditional or Roth IRA accounts. If any filing deadlines are deferred, the IRS will announce the deferral in your area and issue a press release. The IRS will also publish the deferral in the Internal Revenue Bulletin (IRB) in the form of tax rulings, tax procedure guides, notices, announcements, or other guidance as needed. Visit IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief to find out if filing deadlines have been deferred in your area.

If the IRS delays filing deadlines, the following taxpayers are eligible for the delay. Any individual whose principal residence is located in the affected area. Any business entity or sole proprietor whose principal place of business is located in the affected area. Any individual who is a relief worker and is providing assistance in the affected area. Any individual, business entity or sole proprietor whose records are needed to meet the filing deadline for the delay and who maintains those records in the affected area. The principal residence or principal place of business need not be located in the affected area. Any estate or trust that possesses tax records necessary to meet the filing deadline for the delay and who maintains those records in the affected area. The spouse of a taxpayer who is eligible for the delay. Any individual, business entity or sole proprietor who maintains tax records necessary to meet the filing deadline for the delay and who maintains those records in the affected area, but who is not located in the affected area. Any individual who visits the affected area and suffers injury as a result of the disaster. Any other individual, business entity or sole proprietor determined by the IRS to be affected by a federal disaster declaration.
This is a disaster area declared by the federal government, and the IRS has decided to extend the filing deadline by up to one year.

Some taxpayers affected by disasters declared by the federal government after December 20, 2019, may be eligible for certain mandatory extensions of 60 days of filing and payment deadlines for income, sales, and employment taxes; and contributions to traditional or Roth IRAs. The period of time during which the filing and payment deadlines are extended is the 60-day period beginning on the earliest date of the disaster-related events specified in the disaster declaration and ending on the later of the earliest date of the disaster-related events or the date of the declaration. For information about disaster assistance available in your area, including information about whether you may be eligible for the extension, visit IRS News for Your Area (English).
The IRS may reduce the interest and penalties charged on underpaid income taxes during the filing extension period.

You can get information by going to DisasterAssistance.gov (English) or calling the following numbers. These numbers are only activated after a federal disaster is declared. 800-621-3362. If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech disability, call 711 and tell the TRS operator 800-621-3362.

Disaster year is the tax year in which you suffered a loss due to a federal disaster. Generally, disaster losses are continuous in the tax year in which the disaster occurred. However, disaster losses may also be continuous in the tax year following the disaster. For example, if there is a reasonable prospect of recovery, then any part of the loss that is not recovered in a reasonable amount of time may not be allowed.

You generally must deduct accidents incurred in a disaster year. However, if you suffer an accident in an area that requires public or personal assistance (or both) as a result of a federal disaster, you may choose to deduct the loss on your tax return or amended return for the tax year immediately preceding the disaster year. If you make this choice, the loss will be treated as occurring in the previous year. A list of areas requiring public or personal assistance (or both) is available on the Federal Emergency Management Agency website, FEMA.gov/Disasters (English). You must make your election to deduct disaster-related accident losses no later than six months after the normal due date of your disaster year return (original or amended) or before the due date of the return for the tax year immediately preceding the disaster year. If you are a calendar year taxpayer, you must amend your 2023 return by October 15, 2025, to claim a loss incurred in 2024.

If you filed your tax return for the previous year, you can choose to report a disaster loss on your tax return for that year by filing an amended tax return. You can report a disaster loss on Form 1040-X. (See How to Report a Loss on Form 1040-X in this publication.) If you choose to do so, you must report the disaster loss on Form 4684, Part D, Line 1, and attach it to your disaster loss deduction tax return or amended tax return for the year you are reporting the disaster loss. You must make the election to deduct the loss before the normal filing deadline for the tax year in which you filed your original tax return for the disaster year (not extended). For individual calendar-year taxpayers, the deadline to make the election to report a disaster loss on your 2023 tax return is October 15, 2025. See Form 4684, Instructions, for more information about how to report these losses on your original or amended 2023 tax return.

If you want to revoke your election to deduct federal government-declared disaster losses for the 2024 disaster year, you must file Form 4684, Part D, Section 2, for the 2023 tax year. Attach the completed D section to your modified return for the previous year (that is, the modified 2023 return you filed to revoke the 2024 disaster year election). You must file your modified return to revoke the election within 90 days after the deadline for making the election and before you file your return for the year in which you claimed the disaster loss. Your modified return (revoking the previous disaster loss election) should recalculate your tax liability after the election is revoked. You must pay or arrange to pay any taxes and interest due as a result of the revocation.

Eligible disaster losses also include personal accident losses or theft losses of personal property used for personal purposes caused by the following: a major disaster declared by the President pursuant to Section 401 of the Stafford Act; Hurricane Harvey; Hurricane Harvey; Hurricane Irma; Hurricane Maria; 2017 and 2018 California wildfires; a major disaster declared by the President pursuant to Section 401 of the Stafford Act, occurring on or after January 1, 2018, and continuing through January 19, 2020 (except for losses attributable to the 2018 California wildfires for which a waiver has been granted); and a major disaster declared by the President on or after January 1, 2020, and before February 10, 2025. In addition, the disaster must have an incident period that begins on or after December 28, 2019, and ends before January 11, 2025.

Standard Deduction Alternative Minimum Tax Adjustments are not allowed for qualified disaster net losses. See the instructions for Form 4684 for more information on filing Form 6251, Alternative Minimum Tax for Individuals, for the same tax year.

If your home is located in a disaster area declared by the federal government, your state or local government may order you to demolish or move it, because the disaster makes it unsafe to live there. If this happens, treat the loss of value as an accidental loss caused by the disaster. Your state or local government must issue an order requiring you to demolish or move your home within 120 days of the area being declared a disaster. Calculate your loss in the same way as you would an accidental loss of personal-use property. (See the section on Calculating your loss earlier in this publication.) When determining the amount of the decrease in fair market value, use the value of your home before the accident and its fair market value after the accident.

If the above statements do not apply to you, your tax form instructions may contain all the information needed to determine whether you can claim and calculate EIC. You may not need this publication. However, you can read it to find out if you can claim EIC and to learn more about EIC.
No, if you are at least 25 but not yet 65 and your labor income is less than $18,591 (for married filing jointly, $25,511), you can get EIC without a qualifying child. See Chapter 3.

Your adjusted gross income (AGI) must also be less than the amount just listed for you. For more information, see Rules 1 Limit and Rule 15. Investment income. Your maximum amount of investment income that you can own and still be eligible for the exemption is $11,600. See Rule 6—Your investment income must be $11,600 or less.

Your Adjusted Gross Income (AGI) must be less than: If you have three or more qualifying children with valid SSNs, $59,899 (married filing jointly $66,819), If you have two qualifying children with valid SSNs, $55,768 (married filing jointly $62,688), If you have one qualifying child with a valid SSN, $49,084 (married filing jointly $56,004), or If you have no qualifying children with valid SSNs, $18,591 (married filing jointly $25,511).

Adjusted gross income is the amount shown in line 11 of Form 1040 or 1040-SR. If your adjusted gross income is equal to or greater than the amounts listed above, you cannot claim EIC. You do not need to read the rest of this publication.

If you are married but eligible to file as head of household or as a separate taxpayer under the special rules for married taxpayers separated under the laws of a state that has community property laws (see Rule 3), and you reside in a state that has community property laws, your adjusted gross income includes the portion of your and your spouse's wages that must be included in your total income. This is different from the community property rules applicable to Rule 7.

To claim EIC, you (and your spouse, if you file a joint return) must have a valid Social Security Number (SSN) issued by the Social Security Administration (SSA) by the due date of your 2024 tax return (including any extensions). Your eligible children must have a valid SSN by the due date of your return or before to be able to claim higher EIC benefits for that child. If you have at least one child who qualifies to claim EIC, but that child does not have a valid SSN by the due date of your return or before, if you meet other conditions, you may be eligible to claim EIC only for yourself. If one or more of your children do not have a valid SSN by the due date of your return or before, to get information about how to complete Schedule EIC, see Schedule EIC. An SSN is valid for EIC unless it is issued after the due date of your 2024 tax return (including any extensions) or it is issued solely for the purpose of applying for or receiving a federal benefit that does not authorize you to work. Medical assistance is an example of a federal benefit. If you, your spouse, or your child has a Social Security card that has the words “Not valid for employment” printed on it, and you, your spouse, or your child’s immigration status changes so that the individual becomes a U.S. citizen or permanent resident, request the SSA to issue a Social Security card without the words “Not valid for employment” printed on it.

If your SSN is on a Social Security Card that says "Valid for work only with INS authorization" or "Valid for work only with DHS authorization", then your SSN is only valid while the authorization is still valid.

{ "English": "If your tax return is missing your or your spouse's SSN or your or your spouse's SSN is incorrect, you may not be able to claim EIC. If your tax return is missing your or your spouse's Social Security Number because you or your spouse did not have a valid Social Security Number at the time of your 2024 tax return deadline (including extensions) or before, and you later obtained a valid Social Security Number, you cannot file an amended tax return to claim EIC. However, if you or your spouse obtained an SSN that is invalid for EIC, but before your 2024 tax return deadline (including extensions), you or your spouse were eligible for a Social Security card that did not have the "Not valid for employment" stamp, even if the Social Security card was not updated before your 2024 tax return deadline (including extensions), you can claim EIC on your original or amended 2024 tax return." }{ "English": "If your tax return is missing your or your spouse's SSN or your or your spouse's SSN is incorrect, you may not be able to claim EIC. If your tax return is missing your or your spouse's Social Security Number because you or your spouse did not have a valid Social Security Number at the time of your 2024 tax return deadline (including extensions) or before, and you later obtained a valid Social Security Number, you cannot file an amended tax return to claim EIC. However, if you or your spouse obtained an SSN that is invalid for EIC, but before your 2024 tax return deadline (including extensions), you or your spouse were eligible for a Social Security card that did not have the "Not valid for employment" stamp, even if the Social Security card was not updated before your 2024 tax return deadline (including extensions), you can claim EIC on your original or amended 2024 tax return." }

If you (or your spouse, if filing a joint return) have an Individual Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN) instead of a Social Security Number, you cannot receive the EIC. An ITIN is issued by the Internal Revenue Service to non-citizens who are not eligible for a Social Security Number.
