If you (or your spouse, if filing a joint return) do not have a Social Security number, you can apply for one by filing Form SS-5 with the Social Security Administration. You can get Form SS-5 at SSA.gov/forms/ss-5.pdf (English), at your local Social Security office, or by calling 800-772-1213 to contact the Social Security Administration.

If the filing deadline is approaching and you still do not have a Social Security number, you can apply for an automatic 6-month extension of time to file your tax return. You can obtain this extension by filing Form 4868, Application for Automatic Extension of Time to File U.S. Individual Income Tax Return. For more information, see the instructions for Form 4868. In addition to filing Form 4868, you can also apply for an automatic extension by making an electronic payment before the filing deadline.
If you are married, you usually have to file a joint tax return to claim EIC. However, there is a special rule for separated spouses.

If you meet these requirements, check the box at the top of the EIC (1040) schedule. Make sure you file and attach the EIC schedule, listing your eligible children. Whether your eligible children have a valid SSN or not, make sure you file and attach the EIC schedule. If you meet the requirements to claim EIC for your eligible children who do not have a valid SSN, you may still be eligible to claim EIC for yourself only.

If you are a non-tax resident at any time during the year, unless your filing status is married filing jointly, you cannot claim EIC. You can only use this filing status if your spouse is a U.S. citizen or tax resident and you choose to be treated as a U.S. resident. If you make this choice, you and your spouse will be taxed on worldwide income. If you need more information about how to make this choice, get Publication 519. If you are a non-tax resident for the entire year and your filing status is not married filing jointly, enter a «No» in the space next to line 27 (form 1040 or 1040-SR). See form 1040 instructions for nonresident aliens and dual-status residents for more information, including information about making the choice to treat your nonresident alien or dual-status alien spouse as a U.S. resident for the entire tax year.

If you file Form 2555, Foreign Income, you cannot claim EIC. You file these forms to exclude from your total income income earned abroad, or to deduct or exclude foreign housing amounts. U.S. territories are not considered foreign. See publication 54 for more information.

Unless your investment income is $11,600 or less, you can't claim EIC. If your investment income is more than $11,600, you can't claim a deduction. Use the Work Sheet 1 in this chapter to figure your investment income.

This benefit amount is called the 'EIC' because to qualify, you must work and have earned income. If you are married and file a joint return, at least one spouse works and has earned income, you meet this rule. If you are an employee, earned income includes all taxable income you receive from your employer. The information in Rule 15 can help you calculate your earned income amount. If you are self-employed or a statutory employee, you can calculate your earned income on Form 1040 Schedule B, the EIC work sheet.

Labor income includes all types of income. 1. Wages, salaries, tips, and other compensation to employees. Employee compensation is only labor income when it is taxable. Non-taxable employee compensation, such as certain dependent care benefits and adoption benefits, is not labor income. However, non-taxable combat pay has an exception, you can choose to include it in labor income, as described in this chapter later. 2. Net self-employment income. 3. Total income received as an employee.
Your wages, salaries, and tips from work are reported in box 1a of your Form W-2. You must report this information on line 1 of your Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR.

Other types of labor income not reported in box 1 of your W-2, including household employee wages, unreported tip income, certain federal health insurance tax exemption payments (if you choose to include non-taxable amounts in your income for purposes of claiming EIC), taxable foster care payments, adoption assistance provided by your employer on Form 8839, wages reported on Form 8919, and other earned income. You should report these amounts on lines 1b through 1h of your 1040 or 1040-SR.
In the following circumstances, you may have self-employment income: You own a business, or You are a minister or member of a religious group.

As part of the pastor's salary, housing rent or housing allowance provided to the pastor is usually not subject to income tax, but is included in self-employment net income. For this reason, it is included in the labor income of the EIC (except for the description of the approved Form 4361 or Form 4029).
If you receive a Form W-2, and it is marked as 'Box 13, Statutory Employee', then you are a statutory employee. You report your income and expenses as a statutory employee on Schedule C (Form 1040).

As a benefit paid to you for a strike or lockout, including the fair market value (not a gift) of cash and other property, is generally taxable. If a strike or lockout benefit is taxable, it is generally treated as earned income. You should report the amount of your taxable strike or lockout benefit on line 1h of your Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR.
Each approved form can exempt certain income from social security tax. Here, we discuss each form based on whether it applies to EIC labor income.

Whether or not you have a Form 4361, any income you receive as a minister of the gospel is considered employment income. This includes wages, salary, tips, and other taxable employee compensation. If you have a Form 4361, non-taxable housing allowance or non-taxable rent on your home are not considered employment income. In addition, income you receive as a non-employee minister is not considered employment income. Examples include fees for officiating weddings and honorariums for speaking engagements.

Whether or not you have a Form 4029, all wages, salaries, tips, and other taxable employee compensation are considered labor income. However, amounts you receive as a self-employed person are not labor income. In addition, do not deduct losses from Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR, line 1a through 1h, from Form C or Form F when calculating your income.

If you retire because of a disability, your taxable disability payments before you reach your minimum retirement age will be considered as earned income. If you are not disabled, your minimum retirement age is usually the earliest age at which you can receive retirement or annuity benefits. You must report your taxable disability payments on line 1h of Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR until you reach your minimum retirement age. From the day after you reach your minimum retirement age, your payments will be treated as retirement income and not as earned income. Report your taxable retirement income on lines 5a and 5b of Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR.

The payments you receive from your disability insurance policy are not considered earned income. It doesn't matter if you've reached the minimum retirement age. If you received the policy through your employer, the amount may be reported in box 12 of your Form W-2, code J.

Examples of non-labor income include interest and dividends, pensions and annuities, social security and railroad retirement benefits (including disability benefits), alimony and child support, welfare benefits, workers' compensation benefits, unemployment insurance benefits (including unemployment compensation), exempt support payments, and veteran's benefits, including VA rehabilitation payments. Do not include any of these items in your labor income.

Non-taxable work benefits payments are not labor income under the EIC. These are cash payments received from state or local public assistance agencies that administer the federal Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) program, in exchange for certain work activities, such as (1) work experience activities (including rehabilitation or repair of public housing) if there are insufficient private sector employment opportunities, or (2) community service program activities.

If you are married but eligible to file as head of household or as a separate taxpayer under the special rules for married taxpayers who are separated (see Rule 3), and you reside in a state that has community property laws, your EIC does not include any amount that your spouse is considered to be yours under those laws. That amount is not labor income for the EIC, even if you must include it in your total income on your income tax return. Your labor income includes all of your income, even if under your state's community property laws, part of it is considered to be your spouse's.

If you are receiving Social Security retirement or disability benefits when you receive any payment under the Long-term Conservation Program, your Long-term Conservation Program payment is not considered earned income for the EIC.

If you meet all the rules in Chapter 1, use this chapter to see if you qualify for a qualifying child. This chapter discusses rules 8 through 10. In addition to the rules in Chapter 1 and Chapter 4, you must also meet all three of these rules to qualify for EIC. If you have one qualifying child who meets the requirements to claim EIC, follow these rules even if the child doesn't have a valid SSN by your 2024 tax return (including extension) deadline or before. When you file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR, if you have at least one qualifying child who meets the requirements to claim EIC, you must attach Schedule EIC to your tax return even if the child doesn't have a valid SSN by your tax return (including extension) deadline or before. If your qualifying child doesn't have a valid SSN, see Schedule EIC for information on how to complete Schedule EIC. If you meet all the rules in Chapter 1 and this chapter, read Chapter 4 to find out what to do next.

If you do not qualify under Rule 8, you do not have eligible children. Read Chapter 3 to see if you can claim EIC even if you do not have eligible children. If your children pass the test to become your eligible children, but also pass the test to become eligible children for someone else, only one of you can truly claim the children as eligible children to claim EIC. If others can claim the children as eligible children under the tie-breaker rule, unless you have another eligible child, you cannot claim EIC as a taxpayer with eligible children. However, you can claim EIC even if you do not have eligible children.

For EIC, if someone is placed with you by an authorized placement agency or by any court of competent jurisdiction, or by order of any other court, then that person is your foster child. Authorized placement agencies include: state or local government agencies, tax-exempt organizations authorized by the state, and Indian tribal governments or organizations authorized by Indian tribal governments to place Indian children.

Schools may be elementary, secondary, high school, college, university, or technical, trade, or mechanical schools. However, job training courses, correspondence schools, and schools that offer courses only via the Internet are not considered EIC schools.

Substantial earning activities are work that is performed for compensation or profit, or in circumstances where compensation or profit is typically received for work. Full-time work (or part-time work, if convenient for the employer) that is at least at the minimum wage in a competitive work environment indicates that the child can engage in substantial earning activities. Substantial earning activities are not performed to care for oneself or the family. They are not about hobbies, institutional treatment or training, school attendance, clubs, social activities, and similar unpaid work. However, doing such work may indicate that the child can engage in substantial earning activities. The fact that a child has not worked for a period of time does not prove that the child cannot engage in substantial earning activities. For examples of substantial earning activities, see the instructions for Form 1040, Schedule R (Form 1040), line 17.
Children must not file the appropriate joint tax return for the year in order to pass this test.
If your children and their spouses file a joint tax return only to claim a refund of withheld income tax or to pay estimated tax, the joint tax return test exception applies.

Others cannot claim any of these benefits based on this qualifying child. In other words, you and others cannot agree to split these tax benefits among yourselves. Others cannot enjoy any of these tax benefits unless that person has a different qualifying child. The final rule of the last-in-time rule explained who can claim EIC when there are more than one qualifying child. However, if the other person is your spouse and you file a joint tax return, the final rule of the last-in-time rule does not apply.

If your qualifying child is treated as another person's qualifying child under the final-order rules, you can report EIC for the year 2024 using the rules for taxpayers without qualifying children in Chapter 3. Under these final-order rules, you and the other person can choose which of you will report the child as a qualifying child. See Examples 1 through 12. If you can't report EIC because your qualifying child is treated as another person's qualifying child under the final-order rules for 2024, you can report EIC for different qualifying children or use the rules for taxpayers without qualifying children in Chapter 3.

If you and another person have the same qualifying child, but the other person is not eligible because he or she does not meet the requirements or his or her income or adjusted gross income is too high to claim EIC, you can treat the child as a qualifying child. See Examples 6 and 7. However, if the other person claims the child as a qualifying child for any of the five tax benefits listed above, you cannot treat the child as a qualifying child for EIC.
The following examples can help you determine when you can claim EIC when you and another person have the same eligible children.

If you want to know more, please refer to Publication 501. If a child is treated as a noncustodial parent's child under the special rules for child support orders of divorced or separated parents (or of separated parents), only the noncustodial parent can claim the child tax credit or other dependent deductions. However, only the custodial parent (if eligible) or other eligible taxpayers can claim a child as a qualifying child for the EIC. For more information and examples, see Publication 501, Section 501.10-1, Qualifying Child of Divorced or Separated Parents (or of Separated Parents).

For more information on the test to qualify as a dependent, see Rule 8. If you are a dependent of another taxpayer, you cannot claim EIC. Even if the person who is your dependent does not claim EIC or meets all the rules to claim EIC, this is still the case. Enter 'No' in the blank next to line 27 (Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR).

If you are not a qualifying child of another taxpayer (therefore may be eligible to claim EIC) and you do not file a tax return, or you file a tax return only to request a refund of withheld income tax or estimated tax paid, then you are not a qualifying child of another taxpayer (therefore may be eligible to claim EIC).

If you qualify under Rule 8, you have eligible children. If you qualify under Rule 8 and have not applied for the EIC when you had eligible children, you can apply for the EIC when you do not have eligible children. If your children passed the test to become your eligible children, but also passed the test to become eligible children for others, only one of you can truly claim the children as eligible children to claim the EIC. If others can claim your children as eligible children under the final-round rule, unless you have another eligible child, you cannot claim the EIC as a taxpayer with eligible children. However, you can claim the EIC when you do not have eligible children.

You must be between the ages of 25 and 65 at the end of 2024. If you are married and file a joint return, you or your spouse must be between the ages of 25 and 65 at the end of 2024. It doesn't matter which spouse meets the age test, only that one of you does. If you were born between December 31, 1959, and January 2, 2000, you meet the age test. If you are married and file a joint return, and either you or your spouse was born between December 31, 1959, and January 2, 2000, you meet the age test. If neither you nor your spouse meets the age test, you cannot claim EIC. Enter “No” (No) in the blank next to line 27 (form 1040 or 1040-SR).

You are a married individual who filed a joint tax return with your spouse who died in August 2024. Your age is 67. Your spouse will turn 65 in November 2024. Because your spouse died before turning 65, you meet the age test requirement.

A deceased taxpayer who is at least 25 but not yet 65 years old at the time of death is eligible for the age test. The taxpayer is considered to be 25 years old on the day before his or her 25th birthday. However, the age of 65 rule is different; the taxpayer is considered to be 65 years old on his or her 65th birthday. Even if the taxpayer was born before January 2, 2000, he or she will not be considered to be at least 25 years old at the end of 2024 unless he or she was at least 25 years old at the time of death.

If you are not filing a joint return and you did not check the box under your name for 'Other people may claim you as a dependent', you meet this rule. If you are filing a joint return and you did not check the box for 'Other people may claim you as a dependent' or 'Other people may claim your spouse as a dependent', you meet this rule. If you are unsure whether other people may claim you as a dependent, get Publication 501 and read the rules for claiming a dependent. If other people can claim you as a dependent on their tax return but did not, you still cannot claim the exemption unless you can claim the person who can claim you as a dependent does not have to file a return, does not file a return, or only files a return to request a refund of withheld income tax or paid estimated tax.

If you are married and file a joint tax return, you usually cannot be claimed as a dependent by someone else. However, if you and your spouse file a joint return only to claim a refund of withheld income tax or to pay estimated taxes, then others may be able to claim you as a dependent. However, if you apply for EIC on your joint return, you and your spouse cannot be claimed as a dependent by anyone else.

For more information on the test to qualify as a dependent, see Rule 8. If you are a dependent of another taxpayer, you cannot claim EIC. Even if the person who makes you a dependent does not claim EIC or does not qualify to claim EIC, this is still the case. Enter 'No' in the blank next to line 27 (Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR).

If you are married and file a joint tax return, you are usually not eligible to be a qualifying child of another taxpayer. However, if you and your spouse file a joint return only to claim a refund of withheld income tax or to pay estimated tax, you may be a qualifying child of another taxpayer. However, if you claim the EIC on your joint return, you and your spouse are both not eligible to be a qualifying child of another taxpayer.

If you meet the relationship, age, residence, and joint tax return test and do not need to file a tax return, and meet the following conditions, you are not a qualified child of another taxpayer (therefore may be eligible to apply for EIC): Do not file a tax return, or File a tax return only to request a refund of withheld income tax or paid estimated tax.
You (and your spouse, if you file a joint return) must have been a resident of the United States for more than six months. If not, enter 'No' in the blank next to line 27 (Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR).

Your earned income must be less than: If you have three or more eligible children with valid SSNs, $59,899 (married filing jointly $66,819), If you have two eligible children with valid SSNs, $55,768 (married filing jointly $62,688), If you have one eligible child with a valid SSN, $49,084 (married filing jointly $56,004), or If you have no eligible children with valid SSNs, $18,591 (married filing jointly $25,511).

Labor income generally includes wages, salaries, tips, other employee compensation and self-employment net income. Employee compensation is only labor income when it is taxable. Non-taxable employee compensation, such as certain dependent care benefits and adoption assistance, is not labor income. However, non-taxable combat pay has an exception, you can choose to include it in labor income. Labor income is detailed in Rule 7 of Chapter 1.

If you are a self-employed, statutory employee, minister, or church employee, you will report your net earnings from self-employment on Schedule C (Form 1040), then report your net earnings from self-employment on Schedule C, Form 1040, line 27, Step 5. Before completing Step 5, make sure to see Minister or Church Employee, as applicable.

Church employees are employees of a church or a qualified church-controlled organization (other than a pastor or a member of a religious order) that is exempt from paying employer social security and Medicare taxes. If you are a church employee and receive a salary, and you include any amounts on line 5a of Schedule SE and on line 1a of Form 1040, reduce the amounts on line 1a of Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR by the amounts included on line 5a of Schedule SE. On line 27 of Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR, enter the result on the first line of the table in step 5.

When completing your 1040 form, in step 5 of line 27 of the work sheet, enter the amount of your medical assistance exemption that you excluded from income on line 8s of schedule 1 (form 1040), unless you choose to include these amounts in your labor income. In this case, enter -0-. For more information about these amounts, see publication 525. Your exempt federal medical assistance payments may have been reported to you on form W-2, box 12, with code II. If you and your spouse received medical assistance exemption payments in this year, you can make different choices about whether to include all or part of your payments in your labor income. Enter the amount of your medical assistance exemption payments that you or your spouse (if you are filing a joint return) do not want to include in your labor income. If you want to include all of your exempt medical assistance payments in your labor income, enter -0-.

If you are not self-employed, a minister, a church employee reporting on Form 1040 Schedule SE, or a statutory employee reporting on Form 1040 Schedule C at any time during 2024, use Form 1040 Schedule A.

If you are self-employed, or a minister, church employee reporting on Form 1040 Schedule SE, or a statutory employee reporting on Form 1040 Schedule C, use Form EIC, Schedule B. If any of the following situations apply to you, read the paragraph and then complete Form EIC, Schedule B.

If your net self-employment income is $400 or more, be sure to fill out Schedule SE (Form 1040) correctly and pay the appropriate amount of self-employment tax. If you don't, you may not be able to get all the EIC you're entitled to. In calculating your net self-employment income, you must report all allowed business expenses.

Using the optional methods listed in Schedule SE may increase your self-employment income and your eligibility for the EIC or your deduction. If your net income (without using the optional methods) is less than $6,920, see the instructions for Schedule SE for details on the optional methods.

If all of the following conditions apply to you, you must complete Form 1040, Schedule C, Part 1 and Part 2. 1. You are married and file a joint tax return. 2. You and your spouse both have self-employment income. 3. You or your spouse file Form Schedule SE, but not both.

Statutory employees list their earnings and expenses in Schedule C. They do not file Schedule SE. If you are a statutory employee, enter the amounts in Schedule C, Line 1, Part 3, on your W-2 work sheet B.

If you have eligible children and you are filing for EIC, you must complete and attach Form 8849 to your tax return. Form 8849 provides the IRS with information about your eligible children, including their name, age, Social Security number, relationship to you, and the time they lived with you during the year. If you are required to complete and attach Form 8849 but you do not, it will take longer to process your tax return and issue your refund.

If your EIC was denied or reduced for any reason other than a mathematical error or a mistake in your handwriting in any year after 1996, you must attach Form 8862 to your next tax return to claim your EIC. You must also meet all the rules described in this publication to be eligible to claim your EIC.

Please do not file Form 8862 or report EIC: In the final determination that your EIC application is due to carelessness or willful disregard of the rules within 2 years, or in the final determination that your EIC application is due to fraud within 10 years.

If you need to attach Form 8862 to your 2024 tax return and you apply for the EIC without attaching the complete Form 8862, your application will be automatically rejected. This is considered a mathematical error or a mistake in the application. If you do not attach the complete Form 8862, you will not be allowed to claim the EIC.

If your EIC was denied after 1996 and it is determined that your mistake was due to carelessness or willful disregard of the rules, then you are disqualified from claiming EIC for the next 2 years. If your mistake was due to fraud, then you are disqualified from claiming EIC for the next 10 years. The date your EIC was denied and the date you file your 2024 tax return will determine the years you are disqualified from claiming EIC. The following examples illustrate the years you are disqualified from claiming EIC.

Jamie Smith is 63 years old and retired. Jamie received $7,000 in Social Security benefits this year and earned $17,000 in part-time income. Jamie also received $7,400 in taxable pension income. Jamie has no other income. Jamie's AGI is $24,400 (17,000 + 7,400). Jamie is unmarried and lived alone in the U.S. all year. Jamie cannot be claimed as a dependent on any other person's tax return. Jamie has no investment income and no qualifying children. Jamie reads the instructions for Form 1040. In Step 1, Jamie finds that his AGI ($24,400) is not less than $18,591, so Jamie is not eligible for EIC. Jamie completes the rest of Form 1040 and files it with the IRS.

Cameron and Jordan Grey have two children, ages 10 and 8. The children lived with Cameron and Jordan throughout 2024. Cameron's salary was $15,000, and Jordan's salary was $18,030. The Greys received $525 of interest from their savings account. They had no other income in 2024. Cameron and Jordan filed Form 1040 and Schedule 1. They want to determine if they are eligible for EIC, so they follow the instructions in Step 27 of the instructions for Schedule 1.

Cameron and Jordan entered $33,555 on line 11 of Form 1040. They both have valid and long-held Social Security Numbers (SSN). They are married and will file a joint tax return. Cameron and Jordan are not non-tax residents as defined by the tax code. Therefore, their answer to step 1 allows them to proceed to step 2.
Grey's only income from investments is $525. The amount is less than $11,600, so they answer the second question in step 2 as 'No' (No), and proceed to step 3.

Cameron and Jordan's children meet the relationship, age, residence, and joint tax return test, so Cameron and Jordan answer the first question in step 3 as 'Yes' (yes). Their children are not the qualified children of anyone else. Both children were assigned effective SSNs shortly after birth. Cameron and Jordan will file a joint tax return, so they answer the second question in step 3 as 'Yes' (yes). This means they can skip steps 3 through 6 and then proceed to step 5.

Cameron and Jordan completed their work sheets as instructed. 1. Cameron and Jordan entered their total labor income ($33,030) in row 1. 2. They moved to the EIC table to find their benefit amount. They found their labor income of $33,030 in the range of $33,000 to $33,050. Because their two children had valid SSNs, they looked under the Married Filing Joint item in the row corresponding to 2 children and found the shown amount of $6,247. They entered $6,247 in row 2. 3. They entered their Adjusted Gross Income ($33,555) in row 3 and found that it was different from the amount in row 1. 4. They looked up $33,555 in the EIC table and entered the amount of $6,131 in row 5. 5. They entered $6,131 in row 6. This is the smaller of the amounts in row 2 ($6,247) and row 5 ($6,131). 6. The Greys entered $6,131 in row 27 of their Form 1040. They will now complete the EIC work sheet and attach it to their tax return. They will keep the EIC work sheet as a record.

If you qualify, you have the option of filing and submitting your tax return online or in your local community, including the following. File Online. File Online is a permanent option to file your personal federal tax return directly and securely online for free. File Online is an option for filers with relatively simple tax returns who report certain types of income and claim certain deductions. Although File Online is not used to file state tax returns, if you live in a participating state, File Online will guide you to use a state-supported tool that can be used to file and submit state tax returns for free. For more information, updates on the program, and frequently asked questions, visit IRS.gov/DirectFile. Free File. This program allows you to use free tax software or free fillable forms to prepare and file your federal individual income tax return. However, state tax returns may not be available through Free File. To see if you qualify for free online federal tax preparation, e-file, and direct deposit or payment options, visit IRS.gov/FreeFile. VITA. The Volunteer Income Tax Education (VITE) program provides free tax assistance to low- and moderate-income taxpayers, people with disabilities, and those with limited English proficiency who need help preparing their tax returns. To find out more about VITA, download the IRS2Go app for free, or call 800-906-9887. Senior Tax Counseling (TCE). The Tax Counseling for the Elderly (TCE) program provides free tax assistance to all taxpayers, especially those age 60 and older. TCE volunteers specialize in answering questions about retirement-related issues specific to seniors. To find out more about TCE, visit IRS.gov/TCE, or download the IRS2Go app for free. MilTax. Members of the U.S. Armed Forces and eligible veterans can use MilTax, a free tax service provided by the Department of Defense through Military OneSource. For more information, visit MilitaryOneSource.mil/MilTax. In addition, the IRS provides free fillable forms that can be filed online regardless of income.

The IRS will not contact taxpayers via email, text messages (including shortened links), phone calls or social media to request or verify personal or financial information. This includes requests for personal identification numbers (PINs), passwords or similar information for credit cards, bank accounts or other financial accounts. Visit the IRS Identity Theft Center webpage at IRS.gov/IdentityTheft for information about identity theft and data security for taxpayers, tax professionals and businesses. If your Social Security number is lost or stolen, or you suspect you are a victim of tax-related identity theft, you can learn what steps to take. Get an Identity Protection PIN (IP PIN). An Identity Protection PIN is a six-digit number assigned to taxpayers to help prevent their Social Security number from being used in tax-related identity theft. When you have an Identity Protection PIN, you can prevent others from using your Social Security number to file a tax return.

U.S. tax payments must be made in U.S. dollars to IRS. Does not accept digital assets. Visit IRS.gov/Payments for information on how to use one of the following payment options. Direct Pay: Pay your personal tax bill or estimated tax bill directly from your check or savings account without additional fees. Debit card, credit card, or digital wallet: Choose an approved payment processor to pay online or by phone. Electronic Funds Withdrawal: Provide instructions to pay when filing your federal tax return using tax preparation software or through a tax professional. Federal Electronic Payment System: This is the best option for businesses. You must register. Check or money order: Mail your payment to the address listed on your notice or instruction. Cash: You can pay your tax bill in cash at participating retail stores. Wire transfer: You may be able to make a same-day wire transfer from your financial institution. Contact your financial institution to determine feasibility, fees, and time frame.

Go to IRS.gov/Payments to learn more about your options. Apply for an Online Payment Agreement (IRS.gov/OPA) to make monthly payments to meet your tax obligations (if you can't pay your tax bill in full today). You will immediately receive a notification about whether your agreement has been approved after you complete the online process. Use the Online Offer in Compromise (OIC) Pre-Screening Tool (English) to see if you may be able to settle your tax debt for less than the amount you owe. For more information about the OIC, go to IRS.gov/OIC.

TAS is an independent organization within the IRS that helps taxpayers resolve problems with the IRS, propose administrative and legislative recommendations to prevent or correct problems, and protect taxpayers' rights. We strive to ensure that every taxpayer is treated fairly, and that you know and understand your rights under the Taxpayer Bill of Rights. We are your voice at the IRS.

TAS can help you resolve problems you can't solve on your own with the IRS. Be sure to try to solve your problem with the IRS first, but if you can't, go to TAS. Our service is free. TAS helps all taxpayers (and their representatives), including individuals, businesses, and tax-exempt organizations. If your IRS problem results in financial difficulty, if you have tried but cannot solve your problem with the IRS, or if you think the IRS system, processes, or procedures are not working properly, you may be eligible for TAS assistance. To get help with general tax topics at any time, visit www.TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov (English). That website can help you with common tax problems and situations, such as what to do if you made a mistake on your tax return or if you received a notice from the IRS. TAS is committed to solving large-scale (systemic) problems that affect many taxpayers. You can report system problems at www.IRS.gov/SAMS. (Please do not include any personal identifying information.)

The Taxpayer Rights Act describes the 10 basic rights of all taxpayers when dealing with the Internal Revenue Service. Visit www.TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov/Taxpayer-Rights (English) to learn more about these rights, what they mean to you, and how they apply to specific IRS situations you may encounter. TAS is committed to protecting taxpayer rights and ensuring IRS implements the tax code fairly and impartially.

Although the tax preparer will sign the tax return, you ultimately have responsibility for providing all the information that the tax preparer needs to prepare the tax return and for the accuracy of each item reported on the tax return. Anyone who charges to prepare a tax return for someone else should have a thorough understanding of tax issues. For more information on how to choose a tax preparer, go to IRS.gov Choose a Tax Preparer Tips.

The Social Security Administration (SSA) offers online services at SSA.gov/employer (English) for Certified Public Accountants (CPAs), Certified Public Bookkeepers (CPBs), Registered Tax Preparers (RTPs), and individuals who file Form W-2 (Wage and Tax Statement) and Form W-2c (Corrective W-2 Wage and Tax Statement). These individuals can use the online services to file Form W-2c quickly, for free, and securely.

If you are a sole proprietor, partnership, or S corporation, you can view tax information on your IRS account and perform more operations using the business tax account. Go to IRS.gov/BusinessAccount for more information.

Visit IRS.gov/SocialMedia (English) to view the IRS’s various social media tools used to share the latest information on tax changes, fraud alerts, advocacy, products and services. At IRS, privacy and security are our top priorities. We use these tools to share public information with you. Do not post your Social Security Number (SSN) or other confidential information on social media sites. Always protect your personal identity when using any social media site. The following IRS YouTube channel offers short educational videos on a variety of tax-related topics in English, Spanish and American Sign Language (ASL). Youtube.com/irsvideos (English). Youtube.com/irsvideosmultilingua (English). Youtube.com/irsvideosASL (English).

The IRS is committed to serving our limited English proficient (LEP) taxpayers through the OPI service. OPI service is a federally funded project that is available at most IRS offices, all VITA/TCE tax sites, and at the Taxpayer Assistance Centers (TACs). OPI service provides over 350 languages of telephone interpreter services.

Middleman service providers. The 5a line of Form 2848 — Power of Attorney and Declaration has been updated to include a check box to authorize the taxpayer to grant a designated representative access to the taxpayer's IRS records through a middleman service provider. For more information, see the instructions for Form 2848 — Access to IRS Records Through a Middleman Service Provider. Partner representative. For partnerships beginning their tax year after December 31, 2017, the two-party power of attorney role has been replaced by the partner representative role. For more information, see the instructions for Form 2848 — Partner Representative. Representative title. The title of law student or certified public accountant has been changed to qualified student. Authentication alert. When an authorized representative who is acting on your behalf contacts the IRS, they must complete an authentication process before the IRS will discuss your tax information with them.

Tax professionals first® (PPS). Tax professionals first® is a nationwide free hotline that provides professional assistance to tax professionals on account-related issues. The toll-free number is 1-866-860-4259. Annual Filing Season Program (AFSP) and Federal Tax Return Preparer List. The Annual Filing Season Program is a voluntary program that allows tax return preparers who are not attorneys, certified public accountants, or registered tax return preparers to have limited practice rights. The IRS issues an Annual Filing Season Program (AFSP) Completion Certificate to tax return preparers who complete a specified number of hours of continuing education during a specific tax year. Annual Filing Season Program participants do not have unlimited practice rights (unless they are also attorneys, certified public accountants, or registered tax return preparers). Their rights are limited to representing their own clients in filing and signing tax returns, and to communicating with IRS employees, customer service representatives, and similar IRS employees, including the Taxpayer Advocacy Service. They may not represent clients on whom they have not filed and signed tax returns, or on appeals or collection functions. For more information about the Annual Filing Season Program, visit IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/Annual-Filing-Season-Program (in English). To access an online searchable database of tax return preparers who have a tax preparer tax identification number, visit IRS.Treasury.gov/rpo (in English).

This document describes the people who can represent taxpayers in dealings with the IRS, and what kinds of forms or documents authorize someone to act on behalf of a taxpayer. Generally, attorneys, certified public accountants (CPA), and registered tax preparers can represent taxpayers in dealings with the IRS. Registered retirement plan consultants and actuaries can represent taxpayers in dealings with the IRS in the specific areas of IRS regulations described in Notice 230. In special and limited circumstances, other individuals such as unregistered tax preparers, family members, employees, and students can represent taxpayers in dealings with the IRS. For more information on who can represent taxpayers before the IRS, see Who Can Practice Before the IRS in the text that follows.
Many of the terms used in this publication, such as "registered tax preparer" and "practicing professional" are defined in the Glossary and listed at the end of this publication.

We welcome your comments on this publication and your suggestions for future versions. You can send us your comments through IRS.gov/FormComments (English). Or, you can write to us at: Internal Revenue Service Tax Forms and Publications 1111 Constitution Ave. NW, IR-6526 Washington, DC 20224 Although we cannot reply to each comment individually, we appreciate your feedback and will consider it as we modify tax forms, instructions, and publications.

Any individual who fills out or assists in filling out tax returns or claims for refund may be interviewed by the IRS as a witness to the taxpayer's identity, or may be required to provide information to the IRS or its officers or employees upon request.

The following persons are subject to the regulations of Notice 230. However, any fully authorized individual (authorized representative) must be designated as the taxpayer's representative and file a written statement with the IRS, stating that he or she is authorized and qualified to represent a specific taxpayer. Form 2848 may be used for this purpose.

Because of their special relationship with taxpayers, the following individuals may, under the condition of providing satisfactory identification and authorization documents to represent the designated taxpayer with the Internal Revenue Service, except for the following (1) described situation. 1. Individual. An individual may represent himself or herself with the Internal Revenue Service and does not need to file a written qualification and authority statement. 2. Family. An individual may represent his or her immediate relatives. Immediate relatives include the individual's spouse, children, parents, brothers or sisters. 3. Officials. The officers of a true company (including the parent company, subsidiary or other affiliate company), association or organized group may represent the company, association or organized group. Governmental units, agencies or authorities' officers may represent the governmental units, agencies or authorities in carrying out their duties with the Internal Revenue Service. 4. Partners. General partners may represent the partnership with the Internal Revenue Service. 5. Employees. Formal full-time employees may represent their employer. The employer may be but is not limited to an individual, partnership, company (including the parent company, subsidiary or other affiliate company), association, trust, takeover, guardianship, estate, organized group, governmental units, agencies or authorities. 6. Trustees. Trustees (trustees, executors, personal representatives, administrators, takers over, guardians or guardians) act on behalf of the taxpayer as a taxpayer rather than as a representative. Please refer to Trustees in the section of No need for a power of attorney.

Students working at the Low Income Taxpayer Service Center (LITC) or the Student Tax Center Program (STCP) must obtain permission to represent themselves as a legal, business, or accounting major. Authorization requests must be sent to the Taxpayer Advocate Service. If approved, a letter will be issued granting the student special appearance and detailing any conditions related to the appearance. The student receiving the letter of authorization is typically able to represent the taxpayer in any manner consistent with the conditions outlined in the letter of authorization and must be under the direct supervision of an authorized individual who is able to practice before the IRS. If you intend to have a student represent you, review the letter of authorization and consult with your student, your supervisor, or the Taxpayer Advocate Service if you have any questions about the authorization terms.
"English": "Any licensed preparer who is not currently suspended or terminated by the IRS may practice before the IRS.

Any licensed registered retirement plans counselor who is not temporarily prohibited or terminated from practicing before the IRS may practice before the IRS. The practice of a registered retirement plans counselor is limited to specific IRS regulations related to their area of expertise, primarily those governing employee retirement plans.

Any individual who is registered as an actuary with the Actuarial Registration Council and is not temporarily suspended or terminated from practice before the IRS may practice before the IRS. The practice of registered actuaries is limited to specific IRS regulations related to their area of expertise, primarily those governing employee retirement plans.

In specific cases, students in law schools or equivalent courses who provide tax services to low-income taxpayers and are supervised by practicing professionals may request authorization to represent taxpayers in dealings with the IRS. For more information, see the section on Special Authorization for Limited Practice in the text below.

"English": "Unregistered tax preparers are individuals who are not lawyers, certified public accountants, registered tax preparers, registered retirement plan administrators, or registered actuaries. Unregistered tax preparers prepare and sign tax returns for taxpayers or prepare tax returns without signing them (as indicated in the instructions for the tax return or by law). Unregistered tax preparers may only represent taxpayers in communication with IRS employees, customer service representatives, and similar IRS employees (including Taxpayer Advocate Service) and in examining the tax returns they prepared and signed before December 31, 2015. Unregistered tax preparers may not represent taxpayers before appeal officers, IRS officers, advisors, or similar IRS or Treasury Department officers or employees. Unregistered tax preparers may not represent taxpayers in signing settlement agreements, extending the time to assess or collect taxes, claiming exemptions, or signing any documents. If an unregistered tax preparer does not meet the limited representation requirements, you can authorize an unregistered tax preparer to examine and/or request your tax information by filing Form 8821. Filing Form 8821 will not authorize an unregistered tax preparer to represent you in communication with IRS employees. For more information, see Form

Generally, a person will lose his or her qualification to practice before the IRS in the following ways. Failure to meet the requirements for renewal (such as continuing professional education). As a registered tax preparer, the person's application to continue as a registered tax preparer is rendered invalid. Being temporarily prohibited or terminated from practicing by the Professional Responsibility Office for violating the provisions of Notice 230 or the standards. IRS 81-38 procedure. Losing his or her state license as an attorney or certified public accountant, regardless of the basis for the revocation of the license.

Individuals who are required to be placed in inactive retired status must not be eligible to practice before the IRS. They must continue to comply with all renewal requirements. They may restore to renewal status by submitting a renewal application and providing evidence that they have completed the continuing professional education hours required for their registration period.

The IRS website IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/Enrolled-Agents/Become-an-Enrolled-Agent (English) provides complete information on how to become an Enrolled Agent. For complete rules on obtaining the Annual Filing Season Program Record of Completion, see IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/General-Requirements-for-the-Annual-Filing-Season-Program-Record-of-Completion (English).

The rules governing practice before the IRS are published in Title 10, Subtitle A, Chapter 31 of the Code of Federal Regulations, and are distributed in electronic form in the Department of the Treasury Notice 230 (Notice 230). These rules can be found at IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/Circular-230-Tax-Professionals. Authorized tax professionals, including attorneys, certified public accountants, registered tax return preparers, registered retirement plan administrators, registered retirement plan consultants, or registered retirement plan agents (collectively, tax professionals), and appraisers are required to perform certain acts and are restricted from performing other acts. In addition, tax professionals may not engage in conduct that is detrimental to their reputation. Any tax professional who fails to comply with the practice rules or engages in incompetent or unprofessional conduct will be subject to discipline. In addition, unregistered tax return preparers must comply with the practice rules and conduct rules in order to exercise limited practice authority before the IRS. There are two sets of applicable specific rules, both of which are described in Notice 230: 1. Professional Responsibilities and Limitations (Notice 230 B Subpart B), and 2. Conduct that is considered to be incompetent or unprofessional (Notice 230 10.51 B Subpart B).

Individuals subject to Notice 230 are required to immediately comply with the appropriate and lawful requests of IRS officials or employers for the records or information required, unless the practitioner reasonably and in good faith believes the information is privileged and therefore not required to be disclosed. Communication between authorized tax practitioners and taxpayers regarding tax advice (see IRC § 7525) is generally confidential, and is treated in the same manner as communication between a taxpayer and an attorney: with respect to non-criminal tax matters involving the IRS, or non-criminal tax litigation brought by the United States in a federal court, or non-criminal tax litigation in which the United States is a defendant.

If communication involves promoting a company's direct or indirect participation in any tax avoidance scheme, the tax advice communication protection does not apply to any written communications between federal authorized tax practitioners and any persons (including company directors, shareholders, officers, employees, agents or representatives) in relation to tax advice communications.

Individuals subject to Notice 230 are required to notify their clients of any non-compliance with tax laws, or any errors or omissions in any tax returns, documents, declarations, or other required forms. They must also notify their clients of the consequences of non-compliance, errors, or omissions.

230 Notice requires individuals to conduct due diligence when performing the following duties. Fill out or assist in filling out, approve and file tax returns, documents, declarations and other forms with the IRS. Determine the accuracy of any oral or written statements made to the Department of Treasury regarding IRS matters. Determine the accuracy of any oral or written statements made to clients regarding any matter under the jurisdiction of the IRS.

Individuals subject to Section 230 are prohibited from knowingly, directly or indirectly, engaging in the following conduct. Assisting or accepting assistance from any individual who is disqualified or temporarily disqualified from practice before the IRS in matters deemed to be practice before the IRS. Accepting assistance from any former government employee in a manner that violates Section 230 or any other federal law.

Individuals bound by Notice 230 may not act as a witness, notarize documents, or perform any official acts in matters in which they have a personal interest, including as an advisor, attorney, or officer of, or any other capacity involving, the Internal Revenue Service.

Individuals bound by Notice 230 may not endorse or otherwise negotiate any check issued by the taxpayer to a client (including by transferring funds to any account held by or under the control of a professional or any entity related to a professional) for any federal tax liability.

Individuals subject to Notice 230 may be temporarily prohibited or terminated from practicing before the IRS, or be censured, because of misconduct or dishonorable conduct. In addition to any other disciplinary action, fines may be imposed on the individual and his or her company. The following list contains examples of dishonorable conduct. For other examples, see Notice 230, Section 10.51(a). Convicted of any criminal offense under the Internal Revenue Code or any offense involving dishonesty or breach of trust. Deliberately providing false or misleading information, or participating in such activity, in matters related to federal taxes. Engaging in prohibited solicitation of employment, as described in Notice 230, Section 10.30. Deliberately failing to file a federal tax return, evading or attempting to evade any federal tax or payment, or participating in such action. Misappropriating or failing to properly and timely remit funds received from a client for the purpose of paying United States taxes or other obligations. Attempting to influence the official conduct of IRS employees by means of threats, false accusations, coercion or intimidation, or by offering gifts, benefits or any other inducement. Being terminated or temporarily prohibited from practicing before the District of Columbia or any U.S. state, territory, possession, district, federal or any federal court, or any federal agency, organization or committee. Deliberately assisting and abetting another person in practicing before the IRS during a period of temporary prohibition, termination of qualification, or ineligibility. Using obscene language, making deliberate false or misleading statements, or transmitting or disseminating malicious or libelous content, or engaging in any contemptible conduct, in matters related to practicing before the IRS. Deliberately, recklessly, or by gross incompetence, providing false opinions; or providing incompetent opinions on federal tax issues.

If an individual is found to be incompetent or engaged in conduct that is detrimental to reputation, or has failed to comply with the regulations of Subsection B, or has intentionally and knowingly misled or threatened a client or prospective client for the purpose of fraud, the Secretary of the Treasury or his designee may, after notice and an opportunity for a hearing, revoke, suspend or terminate the individual's practice before the Internal Revenue Service under the notice of 230. A revocation is a public revocation. An individual under the notice of 230 includes any lawyer, certified public accountant, registered tax preparer, registered retirement plan counselor, or registered actuary who engages in activities representing a taxpayer or providing advice, as well as any individual who holds an annual tax season closing certificate and who engages in activities for the purpose of federal tax purposes, and any appraiser who engages in activities for the purpose of federal tax purposes to value assets.

The power of attorney is your written authorization to an individual to receive your confidential tax information from the IRS and to act on your behalf in a particular matter. If the authorization is unrestricted, the individual can generally do all the things you can do, except negotiate or endorse a check. Granting power of attorney to a registered retirement plan counselor, a registered actuary, or a tax return preparer who is not registered is limited. For information about the restrictions on annual filing season plan preparers with an Enrolled Retirement Plan Representative (ERP) certificate, see IRS procedure 2014-42 and IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/Return-Preparers-Office-RPO-At-a-Glance (English).

Lawyers, Certified Public Accountants, and Registered Tax Preparers may engage in the following activities: 1. Represent you in any dealings with the IRS or its employees. 2. Sign agreements to extend the period of limitations for collection or assessment of taxes. 3. Sign agreements to waive the right to a refund or to claim a refund. 4. Sign agreements to transfer property.

Only authorized representatives who are specifically authorized to substitute or appoint another representative on the power of attorney may substitute or appoint another representative. After the substitution, only the new authorized representative will be authorized to represent the taxpayer. If the power is delegated, both the original and the appointed representatives will be authorized by the IRS to represent you.

You must also attach a statement signed and dated by your representative on the non-IRS letter of authorization. This statement, known as a representative statement, is included in Section 2 of Form 2848. The statement should include the following: 1. I am not currently prohibited or terminated from practicing before the IRS by any other authority and my occupation is not prohibited by any other authority, 2. I am subject to the rules governing practice before the IRS as set forth in Revised Notice 230 (Section 10(a), 31 CFR 10.31), 3. I am authorized to represent the taxpayer named in the letter of authorization, and 4. I am (the representative's identity, as listed in the qualified representative list in Section 2 of Form 2848).

If your Form 2848 does not list all of the above information, the IRS will not accept your Form 2848. You can sign and file a complete Form 2848 or a new Form 2848 that includes all of the information. If you cannot sign an acceptable alternative document, your representative can perfect (make acceptable to the IRS) your Form 2848 by the following process.

In the following situations, your non-IRS power of attorney can sign Form 2848. 1. The original non-IRS power of attorney grants power to handle federal tax matters (e.g., general power to act). 2. The agent attaches a statement (signed under penalty of perjury) to Form 2848, stating that the original non-IRS power of attorney is valid under the laws of the jurisdiction in which it is executed.

The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) has a centralized computer data base system called the Centralized Authorization File System. This system contains information about the authority of persons representing taxpayers. Generally, when you file a power of attorney form with the IRS, this form will be processed to be included in the Centralized Authorization File System. Entering your power of attorney into the Centralized Authorization File System will enable IRS personnel who do not have a copy of your power of attorney to verify the authority of your representative by accessing the Centralized Authorization File System. If you designate that your representative should receive a copy of the notices and communications from the IRS, this will also enable the IRS to automatically send these communications to your representative. You can have your power of attorney entered into the Centralized Authorization File System by attaching it to a completed Form 2848 and filing it with the IRS. Your signature is not required; however, your representative must sign a representation statement (see Form 2848, Part 2).

Generally, you can send or fax a paper copy of Form 2848 directly to the IRS. To determine where to file Form 2848, see the Where to File section of the instructions for Form 2848. If Form 2848 is for a specific purpose, mail or fax it to the office that handles that matter. For more information on specific purposes, see the Where to File section of Form 1028. Specific purposes not listed in the Concentrated Authorization File are not included in the instructions for Form 2848.

IRS accepts copies of the power of attorney transmitted by fax (fax). If you choose to file the power of attorney by fax, make sure the IRS office that corresponds to your area is equipped to receive this type of transmission. Your representative can file the Form 2848 electronically through the IRS website. For more information, your representative can visit IRS.gov/eServices to learn more. If you are filing the Form 2848 for electronic signature authorization, do not file the Form 2848 with the IRS. Instead, give the form to your representative, who will keep the document.

Submit any updates or amendments to the existing power of attorney in writing. Your signature (or the signature of the person authorized to sign on your behalf) is a required field. To do so, submit the updated Form 2848 or non-IRS power of attorney to the IRS office where you filed the original version, along with the past or future tax return(s) for which the power of attorney is being used. If you specifically authorized your representative to replace or delegate authority to another representative, the authorized representative may replace or delegate authority. To do so, the representative must file the following items with the IRS office where the power of attorney was filed. 1. A written notice of replacement or delegation signed by the authorized representative. 2. A written representative statement from the new representative. 3. A copy of the power of attorney that specifically authorizes the replacement or delegation.

Newly issued power of attorney will revoke the previously issued power of attorney in the same matter. However, if the new power of attorney specifically states that it will not revoke the previous power of attorney and if the new power of attorney is accompanied by one of the following conditions, the new power of attorney will not revoke the original power of attorney. A copy of the previously non-revoked power of attorney, or a statement signed by the taxpayer, listing the name and address of each representative authorized in the previously non-revoked power of attorney.

If you wish to revoke a previously signed power of attorney and do not wish to appoint a new representative, you must write 'Revoked' at the top of the first page of Form 2848 and add the current signature and date below the 'Revoked' notation. Then, you must mail or fax a copy of the power of attorney with the 'Revoked' notation to the IRS at the location shown on Form 2848, or if the power of attorney is for a specific matter, to the IRS office that handles that matter. If you do not have a copy of the power of attorney to revoke, you must send a statement of revocation to the IRS indicating that the power of attorney is being revoked, listing the matter and years/periods, and listing the name and address of the authorized representative whose power is being revoked. You must sign and date the statement of revocation. If you wish to revoke all authority, write 'Delete all years/periods' instead of listing specific matters and years/periods.

If your representative no longer wishes to act as a representative, he or she must write 'CANCELED' at the top of page 1 of Form 2848 and add the current signature and date below the notation. Then, he or she must provide a copy of the power of attorney with the notation to the IRS in the same manner as above by the taxpayer revoking. If your representative does not have a copy of the power of attorney that he or she wishes to cancel, he or she must send a statement of cancellation to the IRS indicating that the power of attorney granted has been canceled, listing the matters and years/periods, and listing the taxpayer's name, taxpayer identification number and address (if known). The representative must sign and date the statement. Student-held powers of attorney will be recorded in the centralized authorization file system for 130 days from the date of receipt. If you authorize a student to represent you after that time, you will need to submit another updated Form 2848.

For partnership tax years beginning after December 31, 2017, the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act partnership audit and litigation procedures and rules applicable to elected large partnerships were repealed by the 2015 Bipartisan Budget Act and replaced by a new centralized partnership audit regime, and the term 'partnership representative' replaced the term 'tax matters partner'. Under Treasury Regulation 301.9100-22T, certain partnerships may elect to use the new regime for partnership tax returns for tax years beginning between November 2, 2015 and January 1, 2018.

The IRS uses the most up-to-date encryption technology to ensure that your electronic filing is secure and reliable. You can file electronically by using the IRS2Go mobile app, by phone, or online at IRS.gov/Payments. Electronic filing is simple and quick, and it's faster than mailing a check or money order. Visit IRS.gov/Payments and use one of the following options to file. IRS Direct Pay: Pay your personal tax bill or estimated tax directly from your checking or savings account without paying extra fees. Debit or credit card: Choose an approved payment processor to file online, by phone, or on a mobile device. Electronic Funds Withdrawal: Only available when using tax preparation software or filing through a tax professional. Federal Electronic Tax Payment System: Best for businesses. You must register. Check or money order: Mail your payment to the address listed on your notice or instruction. Cash: You can pay your taxes in cash at participating retail stores.

The Taxpayer Advocacy Service (TAS) is an independent organization within the IRS that helps taxpayers and protects their rights. Our work is to ensure that every taxpayer is treated fairly, and that you know and understand your rights under the Taxpayer Bill of Rights (English).

The Taxpayer Rights Act describes 10 basic rights that all taxpayers have when dealing with the IRS. Our Taxpayer Advocate Toolkit at TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov (English) can help you understand what these rights mean to you (English), and when they apply. These are your rights. Know them. Use them.

The Low Income Taxpayer Clinic (LITC) is separate from the IRS. The LITC represents individuals with income below a certain level who need to resolve tax problems with the IRS, such as audits, appeals, and tax disputes. In addition, the clinic can provide information about taxpayer rights and responsibilities in different languages for individuals whose second language is English. These services are provided free of charge or for a low fee. To find a clinic near you, visit TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov/LITCmap (English) or see IRS Publication 4134 — Low Income Taxpayer Clinic List (English) combined.
請前往 IRS.gov/Account 安全存取您的聯邦稅務帳戶資訊。 檢視您的稅款欠數、線上繳納或設定線上付款協議。 線上存取您的稅務紀錄。 查看您過去 18 個月之稅務繳納歷史。 前往 IRS.gov/SecureAccess 檢視必要之身份驗證程序。

The fastest way to get your tax refund is to combine direct deposit and e-file with the IRS. Direct deposit can safely transfer your tax refund e-check to your financial account. Over 80% of taxpayers use direct deposit to get their tax refund. The IRS will issue over 90% of refunds in less than 21 days.

Due to changes in the law, the IRS cannot issue tax returns with the correct EITC or ACTC amounts before mid-February 2018. This applies to the entire refund amount, not just the amount of the benefit.
